text: Conventional nickel‐rich cathode materials suffer from reaction heterogeneity during electrochemical cycling particularly at high temperature, because of their polycrystalline properties and secondary particle morphology. Despite intensive research on the morphological evolution of polycrystalline nickel‐rich materials, its practical investigation at the electrode and cell levels is still rarely discussed. Herein, an intrinsic limitation of polycrystalline nickel‐rich cathode materials in high‐energy full‐cells is discovered under industrial electrode‐fabrication conditions. Owing to their highly unstable chemo‐mechanical properties, even after the first cycle, nickel‐rich materials are degraded in the longitudinal direction of the high‐energy electrode. This inhomogeneous degradation behavior of nickel‐rich materials at the electrode level originates from the overutilization of active materials on the surface side, causing a severe non‐uniform potential distribution during long‐term cycling. In addition, this phenomenon continuously lowers the reversibility of lithium ions. Consequently, considering the degradation of polycrystalline nickel‐rich materials, this study suggests the adoption of a robust single‐crystalline LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 as a feasible alternative, to effectively suppress the localized overutilization of active materials. Such an adoption can stabilize the electrochemical performance of high‐energy lithium‐ion cells, in which superior capacity retention above ≈80% after 1000 cycles at 45 °C is demonstrated.

text: Low performance of cathode materials has become one of the major obstacles to the application of lithium-ion battery (LIB) in advanced portable electronic devices, hybrid electric vehicles, and electric vehicles. The present work reports a versatile oxygen-deficient LiV3O8 (D-LVO) nanosheet that was synthesized successfully via a facile oxygen-deficient hydrothermal reaction followed by thermal annealing in Ar. When used as a cathode material for LIB, the prepared D-LVO nanosheets display remarkable capacity properties at various current densities (a capacity of 335, 317, 278, 246, 209, 167, and 133 mA h g-1 at 50, 100, 200, 500, 1000, 2000, and 4000 mA g-1, respectively) and excellent lithium-ion storage stability, maintaining more than 88% of the initial reversible capacity after 200 cycles at 1000 mA g-1. The outstanding electrochemical properties are believed to arise largely from the introduction of tetravalent V (∼15% V4+) and the attendant oxygen vacancies into LiV3O8 nanosheets, leading to intrinsic electrical conductivity more than 1 order of magnitude higher and lithium-ion diffusion coefficient nearly 2 orders of magnitude higher than those of LiV3O8 without detectable V4+ (N-LVO) and thus contributing to the easy lithium-ion diffusion, rapid phase transition, and the excellent electrochemical reversibility. Furthermore, the more uniform nanostructure, as well as the larger specific surface area of D-LVO than N-LVO nanosheets may also improve the electrolyte penetration and provide more reaction sites for fast lithium-ion diffusion during the discharge/charge processes.

title: Understanding Degradation at the Lithium-Ion Battery Cathode/Electrolyte Interface: Connecting Transition-Metal Dissolution Mechanisms to Electrolyte Composition

openAccessPdf.disclaimer: Notice: This abstract is extracted from the open access paper or abstract available at https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10156081, which is subject to the license by the author or copyright owner provided with this content. Please go to the source to verify the license and copyright information for your use.

text: Lithium transition-metal oxides (LiMn2O4 and LiMO2 where M = Ni, Mn, Co, etc.) are widely applied as cathode materials in lithium-ion batteries due to their considerable capacity and energy density. However, multiple processes occurring at the cathode/electrolyte interface lead to overall performance degradation. One key failure mechanism is the dissolution of transition metals from the cathode. This work presents results combining scanning electrochemical microscopy with inductively coupled plasma (ICP) and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopies to examine cathode degradation products. Our effort employs a LiMn2O4 (LMO) thin film as a model cathode to monitor the Mn dissolution process without the potential complications of conductive additive and polymer binders. We characterize the electrochemical behavior of LMO degradation products in various electrolytes, paired with ICP and EPR, to better understand the properties of Mn complexes formed following metal dissolution. We find that the identity of the lithium salt anions in our electrolyte systems [ClO4–, PF6–, and (CF3SO2)2N–] appears to affect the Mn dissolution process significantly as well as the electrochemical behavior of the generated Mn complexes. This implies that the mechanism for Mn dissolution is at least partially dependent on the lithium salt anion.

title: High interfacial storage capability of porous NiMn2O4/C hierarchical tremella-like nanostructures as the lithium ion battery anode.

text: Porous hierarchical NiMn2O4/C tremella-like nanostructures are obtained through a simple solvothermal and calcination method. As the anode of lithium ion batteries (LIBs), porous NiMn2O4/C nanostructures exhibit a superior specific capacity and an excellent long-term cycling performance even at a high current density. The discharge capacity can stabilize at 2130 mA h g(-1) within 350 cycles at a current density of 1000 mA g(-1). After a long-term cycling of 1500 cycles, the capacity is still as high as 1773 mA h g(-1) at a high current density of 4000 mA g(-1), which is almost five times higher than the theoretical capacity of graphite. The porous NiMn2O4/C hierarchical nanostructure provides sufficient contact with the electrolyte and fast three-dimensional Li(+) diffusion channels, and dramatically improves the capacity of NiMn2O4/C via interfacial storage.

text: Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are the device that are widely used to store energy for various applications such as electric vehicles. However, the application of the LIBs still faces limitations such as energy density, durability, charging speed and safety. Nanomaterials, which have at least one dimension under nanoscale, can offer some solutions to these challenges by modifying the properties and performance of the electrode materials. In this research, recent progresses and challenges of using nanomaterials as electrode materials for LIBs are analyzed. The advantages and disadvantages of different types of nanomaterials are being discussed, such as nanoparticles, nanocoating, nanotubes, and nanocomposites, and their effects on the electrochemical behavior of the LIBs. On the other hand, some of the key issues and future directions for the development of nanomaterials-based LIBs are also being highlighted. This research aims to provide a comprehensive overview and perspective on the application of nanomaterials for better performance LIBs.

text: No design rules have yet been established for producing solid electrolytes with a lithium-ion conductivity high enough to replace liquid electrolytes and expand the performance and battery configuration limits of current lithium ion batteries. Taking advantage of the properties of high-entropy materials, we have designed a highly ion-conductive solid electrolyte by increasing the compositional complexity of a known lithium superionic conductor to eliminate ion migration barriers while maintaining the structural framework for superionic conduction. The synthesized phase with a compositional complexity showed an improved ion conductivity. We showed that the highly conductive solid electrolyte enables charge and discharge of a thick lithium-ion battery cathode at room temperature and thus has potential to change conventional battery configurations. Description Editor’s summary Solid electrolytes have been developed to allow solid-state batteries to compete with liquid electrolyte batteries, but there is still a challenge in ensuring good contact with the electrodes, which thus limits the thickness of electrodes that can be used in practice. Li et al. applied the principles of high-entropy materials to improve upon the properties of existing electrolytes through the sensible partial substitution of addition elements. The authors demonstrate the incorporation of their materials into a cathode structure, which provides the high ionic conductivity required for solid-state battery applications. —MSL Adding composition complexity to a known crystal framework enables millimeter-thick battery electrodes.

title: "Fast-Charging" Anode Materials for Lithium-Ion Batteries from Perspective of Ion Diffusion in Crystal Structure.

openAccessPdf.disclaimer: Notice: This abstract is extracted from the open access paper or abstract available at https://api.unpaywall.org/v2/10.1021/acsnano.3c08712?email=<INSERT_YOUR_EMAIL> or https://doi.org/10.1021/acsnano.3c08712, which is subject to the license by the author or copyright owner provided with this content. Please go to the source to verify the license and copyright information for your use.

text: "Fast-charging" lithium-ion batteries have gained a multitude of attention in recent years since they could be applied to energy storage areas like electric vehicles, grids, and subsea operations. Unfortunately, the excellent energy density could fail to sustain optimally while lithium-ion batteries are exposed to fast-charging conditions. In actuality, the crystal structure of electrode materials represents the critical factor for influencing the electrode performance. Accordingly, employing anode materials with low diffusion barrier could improve the "fast-charging" performance of the lithium-ion battery. In this Review, first, the "fast-charging" principle of lithium-ion battery and ion diffusion path in the crystal are briefly outlined. Next, the application prospects of "fast-charging" anode materials with various crystal structures are evaluated to search "fast-charging" anode materials with stable, safe, and long lifespan, solving the remaining challenges associated with high power and high safety. Finally, summarizing recent research advances for typical "fast-charging" anode materials, including preparation methods for advanced morphologies and the latest techniques for ameliorating performance. Furthermore, an outlook is given on the ongoing breakthroughs for "fast-charging" anode materials of lithium-ion batteries. Intercalated materials (niobium-based, carbon-based, titanium-based, vanadium-based) with favorable cycling stability are predominantly limited by undesired electronic conductivity and theoretical specific capacity. Accordingly, addressing the electrical conductivity of these materials constitutes an effective trend for realizing fast-charging. The conversion-type transition metal oxide and phosphorus-based materials with high theoretical specific capacity typically undergoes significant volume variation during charging and discharging. Consequently, alleviating the volume expansion could significantly fulfill the application of these materials in fast-charging batteries.

text: Composite electrodes containing active materials, carbon and binder are widely used in lithium-ion batteries. Since the electrode reaction occurs preferentially in regions with lower resistance, reaction distribution can be happened within composite electrodes. We investigate the relationship between the reaction distribution with depth direction and electronic/ionic conductivity in composite electrodes with changing electrode porosities. Two dimensional X-ray absorption spectroscopy shows that the reaction distribution is happened in lower porosity electrodes. Our developed 6-probe method can measure electronic/ionic conductivity in composite electrodes. The ionic conductivity is decreased for lower porosity electrodes, which governs the reaction distribution of composite electrodes and their performances.

text: Due to its high specific capacity, silicon anode has gained interest on a global scale as the anode of next-generation lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). However, it is challenging for silicon anodes to replace graphite anodes for widespread use due to the inevitable volume expansion and SEI film development generated by silicon during the lithiation/delithiation process. Among these, the advancement of nanotechnology has sped up the development of silicon anodes. This paper reviews nanotechnology applied in the Si anode to improve the battery performance. The volume expansion of Si is effectively decreased by reducing the volume of the silicon anode in order to increase its specific surface area. Additionally, the smaller negative electrode reduces the distance traveled by lithium ions, greatly increasing the silicon negative electrode's efficiency. At present, the main silicon nano-anode materials include nanoparticles, nanowires, nanosheets, nanotubes, nanoporous materials and so on. It is hoped that this review will provide a deep prospect introduction to the nano-silicon anode. Pure silicon nanoparticles and silicon nanowires, and new nanomaterials composed of them with graphite, graphene, metals, etc.

text: Recently, hydrogen boride (HB) with a pseudo-two-dimensional sheet structure was successfully synthesized, and it is theoretically predicted to have high potential as a negative electrode material for alkali metal ion batteries, making it a promising new candidate. This study represents the first experimental examination of the negative electrode properties of HB. HB was synthesized via cation exchange from MgB2. The confirmation of HB synthesis was achieved through various spectroscopic experiments, including synchrotron radiation X-ray diffraction and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, in addition to direct observation using transmission electron microscopy. The HB electrode was prepared by mixing the HB powder sample with conductive additive carbon black and a polymer binder. A test cell was assembled with the HB electrode as the working electrode, and lithium metal as the counter and reference electrodes, and its battery electrode properties were evaluated. Although reversible charge-discharge curves with good reversibility were observed, the reversible capacity was 100 ± 20 mA h g-1 which is significantly smaller than the theoretical predictions. Nitrogen gas adsorption experiments were performed on the HB powder sample to determine the specific surface area indicating that the HB sheets were stacked together. It is plausible to consider that this stacking structure led to a reduced lithium-ion storage capacity compared to the theoretical predictions.

text: Co3O4 is emerging as a promising anode candidate for lithium ion batteries (LIBs) with high theoretical capacity (890 mAh g-1) but suffers from poor electrochemical cycling stability resulting from the inferior intrinsic electronic conductivity and large volume changes during electrochemical cycling. Here, a new electrophoretic deposition Co3O4/graphene (EPD Co3O4/G) hybrid electrode is developed to improve the electrochemical performance. Through EPD, Co3O4 nanocubes can be homogeneously embedded between graphene sheets to form a sandwich-like structure. Owing to the excellent flexibility of graphene and a large number of voids in this sandwich-like structure, the structural integrity and unobstructed conductive network can be maintained during cycling. Moreover, the electrode kinetics has proved to be a fast surface-controlled lithium storage process. As a result, the Co3O4/G hybrid electrode exhibits high specific capacity and excellent electrochemical cycling performance. The Co3O4/G hybrid electrode was also further studied by in situ electrochemical XRD to understand the relationship of its structure and performance: (1) The observed LixCo3O4 indicates an intermediate of possible small volume change in the first discharging. (2) The theoretical capacity achievement of the Co3O4 in hybrid electrode was evidenced. (3) The correlation between the electrochemical performance and the structural evolution of the Co3O4/G hybrid electrode was discussed detailedly.

text: The high theoretical capacity of red phosphorus (RP) makes it a promising anode material for lithium-ion batteries. However, the large volume change of RP during charging/discharging imposes an adverse effect on the cyclability and the rate performance suffers from its low conductivity. Herein, a facile solution-based strategy is exploited to incorporate phosphorus into the pores of zeolitic imidazole framework (ZIF-8) derived carbon hosts under a mild temperature. With this method, the blocky RP is etched into the form of polyphosphides anions (PP, mainly P5 - ) so that it can easily diffuse into the pores of porous carbon hosts. Especially, the indelible crystalline surface phosphorus can be effectively avoided, which usually generates in the conventional vapor-condensation encapsulation method. Moreover, highly-conductive ZIF-8 derived carbon hosts with any pore smaller than 3 nm are efficient for loading PP and these pores can alleviate the volume change well. Finally, the composite of phosphorus encapsulated into ZIF-8 derived porous carbon exhibits a significantly improved electrochemical performance as lithium-ion battery anode with a high capacity of 786 mAh g-1 after 100 cycles at 0.1 A g-1 , a good stability within 700 cycles at 1 A g-1 , and an excellent rate performance.

text: Layered lithium-rich cathode materials have attracted extensive interests owing to their high theoretical specific capacity (320 - 350 mA h g -1 ). However, poor cycling stability and sluggish reaction kinetics inhibit their practical applications. After many years of quiescence, it is expected to revive the development of layered lithium-rich cathode materials to resolve our increasing dependence on high-energy-density lithium-ion batteries. Herein, we reviewed recent research progresses and in-depth understandings of structure characterizations and reaction mechanisms of layered lithium-rich manganese-based cathode materials. In particular, we comprehensively summarized the proposed reaction mechanisms on both the cationic redox reaction of transition-metal ions and the anionic redox reaction of oxygen species. Finally, we discussed opportunities and challenges facing the future development of LLRM cathode materials for next-generation lithium-ion batteries.

text: Extremely fast-charging lithium-ion batteries are highly desirable to shorten the recharging time for electric vehicles, but it is hampered by the poor rate capability of graphite anodes. Here, we present a previously unreported particle size and electrode porosity dual-gradient structure design in the graphite anode for achieving extremely fast-charging lithium ion battery under strict electrode conditions. We develop a polymer binder–free slurry route to construct this previously unreported type particle size-porosity dual-gradient structure in the practical graphite anode showing the extremely fast-charging capability with 60% of recharge in 10 min. On the basis of dual-gradient graphite anode, we demonstrate extremely fast-charging lithium ion battery realizing 60% recharge in 6 min and high volumetric energy density of 701 Wh liter−1 at the high charging rate of 6 C.

text: Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are common in everyday life and the demand for their raw materials is increasing. Additionally, spent LIBs should be recycled to achieve a circular economy and supply resources for new LIBs or other products. Especially the recycling of the active material of the electrodes is the focus of current research. Existing approaches for recycling (e.g., pyro-, hydrometallurgy, or flotation) still have their drawbacks, such as the loss of materials, generation of waste, or lack of selectivity. In this study, we test the behavior of commercially available LiFePO4 and two types of graphite microparticles in a dielectrophoretic high-throughput filter. Dielectrophoresis is a volume-dependent electrokinetic force that is commonly used in microfluidics but recently also for applications that focus on enhanced throughput. In our study, graphite particles show significantly higher trapping than LiFePO4 particles. The results indicate that nearly pure fractions of LiFePO4 can be obtained with this technique from a mixture with graphite.

text: All-solid-state batteries (ASSBs) show great potential for providing high power and energy densities with enhanced battery safety. While new solid electrolytes (SEs) have been developed with high enough ionic conductivities, SSBs with long operational life are still rarely reported. Therefore, on the way to high-performance and long-life ASSBs, a better understanding of the complex degradation mechanisms, occurring at the electrode/electrolyte interfaces is pivotal. While the lithium metal/solid electrolyte interface is receiving considerable attention due to the quest for high energy density, the interface between the active material and solid electrolyte particles within the composite cathode is arguably the most difficult to solve and study. In this work, multiple characterization methods are combined to better understand the processes that occur at the LiCoO2 cathode and the Li10GeP2S12 solid electrolyte interface. Indium and Li4Ti5O12 are used as anode materials to avoid the instability problems associated with Li-metal anodes. Capacity fading and increased impedances are observed during long-term cycling. Postmortem analysis with scanning transmission electron microscopy, electron energy loss spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy show that electrochemically driven mechanical failure and degradation at the cathode/solid electrolyte interface contribute to the increase in internal resistance and the resulting capacity fading. These results suggest that the development of electrochemically more stable SEs and the engineering of cathode/SE interfaces are crucial for achieving reliable SSB performance.

text: Hierarchical copper silicate hydrate hollow spheres-reduced graphene oxide (RGO) composite is successfully fabricated by a facile hydrothermal method using silica as in situ sacrificing template. The electrochemical performance of the composite as lithium-ion battery anode was studied for the first time. Benefiting from the synergistic effect of the hierarchical hollow structure and conductive RGO matrix, the composite exhibits excellent long-life performance and rate capability. A capacity of 890 mAh/g is achieved after 200 cycles at 200 mA/g and a capacity of 429 mAh/g is retained after 800 cycles at 1000 mA/g. title: 17O NMR Spectroscopy in Lithium-Ion Battery Cathode Materials: Challenges and Interpretation

openAccessPdf.disclaimer: Notice: This abstract is extracted from the open access paper or abstract available at https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC9585580, which is subject to the license by the author or copyright owner provided with this content. text: Modern studies of lithium-ion battery (LIB) cathode materials employ a large range of experimental and theoretical techniques to understand the changes in bulk and local chemical and electronic structures during electrochemical cycling (charge and discharge). Despite its being rich in useful chemical information, few studies to date have used 17O NMR spectroscopy. Many LIB cathode materials contain paramagnetic ions, and their NMR spectra are dominated by hyperfine and quadrupolar interactions, giving rise to broad resonances with extensive spinning sideband manifolds. In principle, careful analysis of these spectra can reveal information about local structural distortions, magnetic exchange interactions, structural inhomogeneities (Li+ concentration gradients), and even the presence of redox-active O anions. In this Perspective, we examine the primary interactions governing 17O NMR spectroscopy of LIB cathodes and outline how 17O NMR may be used to elucidate the structure of pristine cathodes and their structural evolution on cycling, providing insight into the challenges in obtaining and interpreting the spectra. We also discuss the use of 17O NMR in the context of anionic redox and the role this technique may play in understanding the charge compensation mechanisms in high-capacity cathodes, and we provide suggestions for employing 17O NMR in future avenues of research.

text: This article demonstrates the atomic layer deposition (ALD) of tungsten nitride using tungsten hexacarbonyl [W(CO)6] and ammonia [NH3] and its use as a lithium-ion battery anode. In situ quartz crystal microbalance (QCM), ellipsometry and X-ray reflectivity (XRR) measurements are carried out to confirm the self-limiting behaviour of the deposition. A saturated growth rate of ca. 0.35 Å per ALD cycle is found within a narrow temperature window of 180-195 °C. In situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) vibrational spectroscopy is used to determine the reaction pathways of the surface bound species after each ALD half cycle. The elemental presence and chemical composition is determined by XPS. The as-deposited material is found to be amorphous and crystallized to h-W2N upon annealing at an elevated temperature under an ammonia atmosphere. The as-deposited materials are found to be n-type, conducting with an average carrier concentration of ca. 10(20) at room temperature. Electrochemical studies of the as-deposited films open up the possibility of this material to be used as an anode material in Li-ion batteries. The incorporation of MWCNTs as a scaffold layer further enhances the electrochemical storage capacity of the ALD grown tungsten nitride (WNx). Ex situ XRD analysis confirms the conversion based reaction mechanism of the as-grown material with Li under operation.

text: The dissolution of transition metal (TM) cations into liquid electrolyte from cathode material, such as Mn ions dissolution from LiMn2O4 (LMO), is detrimental to the cycling performance of Li-ion batteries (LIBs). Though much attention has been paid to this issue, the behavior of Mn dissolution has not been clearly revealed. In this work, by using a refined in-situ UV-visible absorption spectroscopy (UV-vis) technique, we monitored the concentration changes of dissolved Mn ions in liquid electrolyte from LMO at different state of charge (SOC), confirming the maximum dissolution concentration and rate at 4.3 V charged state and Mn2+ as the main specie in the electrolyte. Through ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations, we revealed that Mn dissolution process is highly related to surface structure evolution, solvent decomposition and lithium salt. These results will contribute to understanding TM dissolution mechanisms in working conditions as well as the design of stable cathode.

text: The global energy crisis, consumption of fossil fuels, and the associated environmental issues have stimulated extensive interest in searching for sustainable energy storage and conversion systems. Rechargeable lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are widely used in mobile devices, hybrid, and electric vehicles. Electrode-electrolyte interface has a strong impact on battery capacity decrease and long-term cycling stability. In order to improve fundamental understanding of the involved phenomena to accelerate the rational design of cathode materials and stable interface, Li(Ni,Co,Mn)O2 (NCM) is a cathode material for rechargeable LIB and also a promising electrocatalyst for oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Their battery performance and catalytic activity are highly correlated to their structures. Multiple processes occurring at the cathode/electrolyte interface led to overall performance degradation. One failure mechanism is the dissolution of transition metals from the cathode. Our efforts employ thin film as a model cathode to monitor the Mn dissolution. Using LiMn2O4 and NCM as cathode materials, we will focus on electrochemical characterization, cation mixing, oxygen evolution, and thin film deposition with controlled crystal structures and composition. We will further introduce our work employing the scanning electrochemical microscope to study LIBs degradation and cathode-electrolyte interface in situ and in real-time.

text: In this paper, we report an advanced long-life lithium ion battery, employing a Pyr14 TFSI-LiTFSI non-flammable ionic liquid (IL) electrolyte, a nanostructured tin carbon (Sn-C) nanocomposite anode, and a layered LiNi1/3 Co1/3 Mn1/3 O2 (NMC) cathode. The IL-based electrolyte is characterized in terms of conductivity and viscosity at various temperatures, revealing a Vogel-Tammann-Fulcher (VTF) trend. Lithium half-cells employing the Sn-C anode and NMC cathode in the Pyr14 TFSI-LiTFSI electrolyte are investigated by galvanostatic cycling at various temperatures, demonstrating the full compatibility of the electrolyte with the selected electrode materials. The NMC and Sn-C electrodes are combined into a cathode-limited full cell, which is subjected to prolonged cycling at 40 °C, revealing a very stable capacity of about 140 mAh g(-1) and retention above 99 % over 400 cycles. The electrode/electrolyte interface is further characterized through a combination of electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) investigations upon cell cycling. The remarkable performances reported here definitively indicate that IL-based lithium ion cells are suitable batteries for application in electric vehicles.

text: Performance of lithium-ion batteries at sub-ambient temperatures are extremely restricted by the resistive interphases originated from electrolyte decomposition, especially on the anode surface. This work reports a novel strategy that anode interphase of low impedance is constructed by applying an electrolyte additive dimethyl sulfite (DMS). Electrochemical measurements indicate that the as-constructed interphase provides graphite/LiNi0.5Co0.2Mn0.3O2 pouch cells with excellent lower temperature performance, outperforming the interphase constructed by 1,3,2-Dioxathiolane 2,2-dioxide (DTD), a common commercially used electrolyte additive. Spectral characterizations in combination with theoretical calculations demonstrate that the improved performance is attributed to the unique molecular structure of DMS, which presents appropriate reduction activity and constructs the more stable and ionically conductive anode interphase, due to the weaker combination of its reduction product with lithium ions than DTD. This rational design of interphases via additive structure has been proven to be a low cost but rather effective approach to tailor the performances of lithium-ion batteries.

text: A core-shell structured Si nanoparticles@TiO2-x/C mesoporous microfiber composite has been synthesized by an electrospinning method. The core-shell composite exhibits high reversible capacity, excellent rate capability, and improved cycle performance as an anode material for Li-ion batteries. Furthermore, it shows remarkable suppression of exothermic behavior, which can prevent possible thermal runaway and safety problems of the cells. The improved electrochemical and thermal properties are ascribed to the mechanically, electrically, and thermally robust shell structure of the TiO2-x/C nanocomposite encapsulating the Si nanoparticles, which is suggested as a promising material architecture for a safe and reliable Si-based Li-ion battery of high energy density.

title: Solid‐State Reaction Heterogeneity During Calcination of Lithium‐Ion Battery Cathode

openAccessPdf.disclaimer: Notice: This abstract is extracted from the open access paper or abstract available at https://api.unpaywall.org/v2/10.1002/adma.202207076?email=<INSERT_YOUR_EMAIL> or https://doi.org/10.1002/adma.202207076, which is subject to the license by the author or copyright owner provided with this content. text: During solid‐state calcination, with increasing temperature, materials undergo complex phase transitions with heterogeneous solid‐state reactions and mass transport. Precise control of the calcination chemistry is therefore crucial for synthesizing state‐of‐the‐art Ni‐rich layered oxides (LiNi1‐x‐yCoxMnyO2, NRNCM) as cathode materials for lithium‐ion batteries. Although the battery performance depends on the chemical heterogeneity during NRNCM calcination, it has not yet been elucidated. Herein, through synchrotron‐based X‐ray, mass spectrometry microscopy, and structural analyses, it is revealed that the temperature‐dependent reaction kinetics, the diffusivity of solid‐state lithium sources, and the ambient oxygen control the local chemical compositions of the reaction intermediates within a calcined particle. Additionally, it is found that the variations in the reducing power of the transition metals (i.e., Ni, Co, and Mn) determine the local structures at the nanoscale. The investigation of the reaction mechanism via imaging analysis provides valuable information for tuning the calcination chemistry and developing high‐energy/power density lithium‐ion batteries.

text: The lithium-ion battery (LIB) has enabled portable energy storage, yet increasing societal demands have motivated a new generation of more advanced LIBs. Although the discovery and optimization of battery active materials has been the subject of extensive study since the 1980s, the most disruptive advancements of commercial LIBs in the past decade stem instead from overall cell design and engineering. In pursuit of higher energy density and fast-charging capability, strategies focused on tuning the properties of composite electrode architectures (e.g., porosity, conductivity, tortuosity, spatial heterogeneity) by restructuring the inactive component matrix of LIB electrode films have recently garnered attention. This perspective explores recent advances in electrode design through an applied lens, emphasizing synthetic platforms and future research directions that are scalable, commercially feasible, and applicable to a wide range of active materials. We introduce and critically assess recently proposed strategies for structuring electrode architectures, including spatial gradients of local composition and microstructure; metal-foil current collector alternatives; and electrode templating techniques, evaluating both achievements in battery performance and commercial applicability. Coupled with improved active materials, new electrode architectures hold promise to unlock next generation LIBs.

text: Organic anion-hosting cathodes are remarkably attractive platform candidates for lithium-ion-based dual-ion batteries (LDIBs) due to their various advantages such as variety, designable, and adjustable. Here, a new organic anion-hosting mixed-valence metal-organic framework cathode (CoⅡ2CoⅢ(DFc)2(OH)3·H2O, abbreviated as Co(DFc)x), is firstly employed in LDIBs. With the redox reactions happening in the couples of Fe2+/Fe3+ and Co2+/Co3+, PF6- anions can be incorporated into the cathode and reversibly released into the LiPF6-based electrolyte. Meanwhile, benefiting from its unique structure and insolubility, Co(DFc)x shows a high energy density of 632 Wh kg-1 (vs. lithium anode), a high operating potential of 3.63 V (vs. Li+/Li), a high reversible (discharge) capacity of 170 mAh g-1 at 50 mA g-1 (the 3rd cycle), an excellent rate performance (up to 2000 mA g-1, 5 minutes for one cycle), and extraordinary cycling stability (an average capacity of 74.9 mAh g-1 for 8000 cycles at 2000 mA g-1).

text: Graphene is composed of a single atomic layer of carbon which has excellent mechanical, electrical and optical properties. It has the potential to be widely used in the fields of physics, chemistry, information, energy and device manufacturing. In this paper, we briefly review the concept, structure, properties, preparation methods of graphene and its application in lithium ion batteries. A continuous 3D conductive network formed by graphene can effectively improve the electron and ion transportation of the electrode materials, so the addition of graphene can greatly enhance lithium ion battery’s properties and provide better chemical stability, higher electrical conductivity and higher capacity. In this review, some recent advances in the graphene-containing materials used in lithium ion batteries are summarized and future prospects are highlighted.

text: Volume expansion is a major challenge associated with tin oxide (SnO x), which causes poor cyclability in lithium-ion battery anode. Bare tin dioxide (SnO2), tin dioxide with graphene sheets (SnO2@GS), and bouquet-like nanocomposite structure (Mn2SnO4@GS) are prepared via hydrothermal method followed by annealing. The obtained composite material presents a bouquet structure containing manganese and tin oxide nanoparticle network with graphene sheets. Benefiting from this porous nanostructure, in which graphene sheets provide high electronic pathways to enhance the electronic conductivity, uniformly distributed particles offer accelerated kinetic reaction with lithium ion and reduced volume deviation in the tin dioxide (SnO2) particle during charge-discharge testing. As a consequence, ternary composite Mn2SnO4@GS showed a high rate performance and outstanding cyclability of anode material for lithium-ion batteries. The electrode achieved a specific capacity of about 1070 mA h g-1 at a current density of 400 mA g-1 after 200 cycles; meanwhile, the electrode still delivered a specific capacity of about 455 mA h g-1 at a high current density of 2500 mA g-1. Ternary Mn2SnO4@GS material could facilitate fabrication of unique structure and conductive network as advanced lithium-ion battery.

text: Sodium ion batteries offer benefits for large-scale energy storage, including low cost and improved safety. However, traditional anode materials like graphite are inadequate due to the large radius of Na+ ions, which complicates their insertion and removal during charging and discharging. A recently synthesized two-dimensional carbon allotrope, known as a biphenylene network (BPN), shows promise as a sodium storage material. Our study explores BPN's potential as an anode for sodium batteries. Theoretical analyses demonstrate that BPN has significant advantages, featuring a maximum specific capacity of 413 mA h g-1, which surpasses the graphite-Li system's capacity of 372 mA h g-1. Additionally, BPN exhibits a low Na+ diffusion barrier (<0.6 eV) and minimal volume expansion during charging (approximately 26%), making it superior to the graphite-Na system. Our findings offer new insights into Na storage with BPN and propose directions for its application as an anode in sodium ion batteries.

Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) holds promise as an anode material for future sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to its high theoretical capacity. Nonetheless, its practical use is challenged by low conductivity, significant volume changes, and unfavorable phase transformation. This research presents the synthesis of a hierarchically structured core-shell heterostructure made of nitrogen-doped MoS2/C and silicon oxycarbide (SiOC) (N-MoS2/C@SiOC) via the straightforward pyrolysis of an N-MoS2/polyfurfural precursor suspended in silicone oil. The incorporation of nitrogen within the two-dimensional MoS2 structure along with carbon results in increased interlayer spacing and improved electronic conductivity and mechanical stability, facilitating the easy and highly reversible insertion and extraction of sodium ions during cycling. Additionally, the nanoscale SiOC shell with surface capacitive reactivity offers a conductive route, mitigates undesirable side reactions at the electrode/electrolyte interface, and serves as a structural buffer against substantial volume expansion issues. Consequently, the N-MoS2/C@SiOC composite demonstrates a high reversible capacity of 540.7 mAh g-1, excellent capacity retention (over 100% after 200 cycles), and superior rate capability up to 10 A g-1. The straightforward hierarchical core-shell design approach introduced in this research paves the way for creating high-performance metal sulfide anodes as well as other high-capacity anode materials for energy storage purposes.

SnS2 materials have garnered significant interest in the realm of electrochemical energy storage due to their layered structure allowing for high specific capacity. Nonetheless, their tendency to easily re-stack during charge/discharge cycles can cause instability in electrode structure and lead to a reduction in capacity. This study introduces a straightforward one-step hydrothermal method to synthesize a SnS2/graphene/SnS2 (SnS2/rGO/SnS2) composite, where ultrathin SnS2 nanosheets are covalently attached to both sides of reduced graphene oxide sheets through C‒S bonds. With graphene situated between two SnS2 sheets, the composite features an increased interlayer spacing of approximately 8.03 Å for SnS2. This expansion enhances the insertion/extraction process of Li+/Na+ ions by enabling rapid transport kinetics and preventing the re-stacking of SnS2 nanosheets during charging/discharging cycles. Density functional theory calculations confirm the most stable state with a moderate interlayer spacing in this sandwich-like composite. Furthermore, both molecular simulations and experimental observations of the diffusion coefficients for Li/Na ions affirm this state as ideal for fast ion transport. Additionally, numerous ultra-small SnS2 nanoparticles anchored on the graphene sheets significantly contribute pseudocapacitive effects to the composite, especially under high current densities, ensuring remarkable high-rate performance. It achieves 844 and 765 mAh g⁻¹ for Li/Na-ion batteries even at 10 A g⁻¹. Moreover, after 200 cycles, the morphology remains largely unchanged, and the SnS2 nanoparticles revert to their original phase without significant agglomeration, indicating that this composite, with its high rate capabilities and excellent cycling stability, is a promising candidate for lithium/sodium storage applications.

We describe the creation of 3D flower-like MoS2 nanosheet arrays on carbon cloth, used as a binder-free anode in sodium ion batteries. The MoS2 surface is enhanced with ultrathin TiO2 layers applied through atomic layer deposition. Electrochemical performance tests show that the ALD TiO2 layer enhances the cycling stability and rate capability of MoS2. The MoS2 nanosheets with a 0.5-nm TiO2 coating exhibit the highest initial discharge capacity of 1392 mAh g-1 at 200 mA g-1, marking a 53% improvement over uncoated MoS2. After 150 cycles, the TiO2-coated MoS2 maintains 75.8% of its second cycle capacity at 200 mA g-1, compared to 59% retention for bare MoS2. The underlying mechanism, explored through ex situ scanning electron microscope (SEM), X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analyses, confirms that the ultrathin TiO2 modification prevents structural degradation and the development of the SEI film on the MoS2 electrode.

Authors: Qu, Baihua; Ma, Chuze; Ji, Ge; Xu, Chaohe; Xu, Jing; Meng, Ying Shirley; Wang, Taihong; Lee, Jim Yang | Abstract: A SnS2-reduced graphene oxide (SnS2-RGO) composite with a layered structure is synthesized via a straightforward hydrothermal process and analyzed for its potential as an anode material in sodium-ion batteries (NIBs). The composite exhibits impressive electrochemical properties, achieving a high charge specific capacity of 630 mAh g^-1 at 0.2 A g^-1, alongside strong rate capability with 544 mAh g^-1 at 2 A g^-1, and demonstrating enduring cycle-life with 500 mAh g^-1 at 1 A g^-1 over 400 cycles. © 2014 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.

Pyrite (FeS2) has emerged as a promising anode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to its affordability, eco-friendliness, and high theoretical capacity. Nonetheless, its practical application is limited by significant volume changes during charging and discharging and its poor conductivity. In this study, we introduce a simple and scalable method to create a nanostructured FeS2 embedded within an N-doped carbon nanosheet composite (FeS2/CNS). This is achieved through a combination of a template method and a solid-state sulfuration process. The N-doped carbon nanosheets are expected to mitigate volume changes and improve the electrode's conductivity. Moreover, the nanoscale particle size, averaging 50-80 nm in diameter, can reduce ion-diffusion paths during the sodiation and desodiation phases. Consequently, the FeS2/CNS electrode demonstrates a high specific capacity of 812 mA h g-1 at 0.1 A g-1, a long cycling life with 77.2% capacity retention after 350 cycles at 1 A g-1, and exceptional rate capability of 400 mA h g-1 at 5 A g-1 when assessed as an anode material for SIBs. These findings highlight the potential of FeS2/CNS for use in SIBs, offering a low-cost solution with high power density and extensive cycling life.

Cellulose, known for its abundance, renewability, and affordability, is an appealing natural bio-macromolecule. We present a novel technique to create pre-sodiated carbonaceous anodes for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) using cellulose nanofibers (CNFs) exposed to microwave irradiation, aimed at potential ultrafast and large-scale production. Although CNFs typically exhibit weak microwave absorption, hindering direct carbonization, our study finds that a minimal amount of reduced graphene oxide (rGO) effectively serves as an initiator. Microwaving rGO releases substantial energy, leading to a local ultrahigh temperature and rapid heating, which facilitates the swift carbonization of CNFs and the formation of pre-sodiated carbonaceous materials in seconds. The sodium present in these carbonaceous materials, derived from carbonizing CNFs with sodium-ion carboxyl, provides optimal sites for sodiation/desodiation, thus enhancing the electrochemical properties of the carbonaceous anode. Utilizing the microwaved rGO-CNF (MrGO-CNF) as an anode in SIBs results in an initial capacity of 558 mAh g-1, sustaining 340 mAh g-1 after 200 cycles. The remarkable reversible capacity and cycling stability highlight MrGO-CNF as a promising anode candidate for sodium-ion batteries.

Achieving structural stability is a significant challenge in high-capacity conversion electrodes that undergo considerable volume changes, yet it is crucial for the advancement of high-energy-density and long-lasting batteries. In this study, we present a stable phosphorus anode for sodium ion batteries by leveraging the synergistic effects of a chemically bonded phosphorus-carbon nanotube (P-CNT) hybrid and a cross-linked polymer binder. The P-CNT hybrid is produced by ball-milling red phosphorus with carboxylic group functionalized carbon nanotubes. During this process, P-O-C bonds are formed, maintaining the connection between phosphorus and CNTs, resulting in a robust hybrid. Furthermore, a cross-linked carboxymethyl cellulose-citric acid binder is employed to create a sturdy electrode. Consequently, this anode exhibits a stable cycling capacity of 1586.2 mAh/g after 100 cycles, coupled with a high initial Coulombic efficiency of 84.7% and an ongoing cycling efficiency of approximately 99%. The innovative electrode framework utilizing a chemical bonding strategy described here may serve as inspiration for other electrode materials experiencing significant volume changes.

Hard carbon (HC) is a promising anode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to its low cost and ability to achieve high energy density. However, its low initial coulombic efficiency (ICE) poses a challenge for real-world battery applications. To address this issue, we developed an uncomplicated method to counteract the irreversible capacity loss of HC anodes by engaging in a chemical presodiation reaction using a sodiation agent, sodium biphenyl (Na-Bp). The potent sodiation capability of Na-Bp allows for rapid presodiation of HC, resulting in presodiated HC (NaxHC) with a perfect ICE of 100%. When paired with a Na3V2(PO4)3 cathode to form a complete SIB cell, the NaxHC||Na3V2(PO4)3 configuration achieves a high ICE of approximately 95.0% and a substantially increased energy density of 218 Wh kg-1, significantly outperforming a control cell that uses the original HC anode, which has a 50% ICE and 120 Wh kg-1. This highlights the substantial benefits of the chemical presodiation process. Crucially, this presodiation reaction is gentle, highly effective, and can be broadly applied to a range of Na-storage materials, providing a novel direction for the development of high-performance Na-storage materials for practical battery applications.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) stand out as a promising alternative to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) for large-scale renewable energy storage, mainly due to their cost-effectiveness and the plentiful availability of sodium resources in the earth's crust. Despite this potential, most research on SIB anode materials has focused on carbon-based options, with limited exploration into high-capacity, alloy-based materials. This research introduces an antimony (Sb)/carbon (C) electrode composed of approximately 30 nm Sb nanoparticles (NPs) uniformly embedded within 400 nm interlinked one-dimensional (1D) carbon fibers, referred to as SbNP@C. The electrode was produced using an accessible and scalable electrospinning technique, requiring no binders or current collectors. The SbNP@C electrode demonstrated significant capacity and stable long-term cycling at various current densities. Initially, it exhibited a total capacity of 422 mAh/gelectrode, maintaining 350 mAh/gelectrode after 300 deep charge-discharge cycles at 100 mA/gSb. This performance is attributed to the efficient 1D sodium-ion transport routes and the robust conductive network offered by SbNP@C, allowing the electrode to maintain high capacities at elevated currents, thus suitable for high-power applications.

The development of viable, scalable, and eco-friendly electrode materials with consistent cycling performance is essential for the advancement of beyond lithium rechargeable batteries and supercapacitors. In the context of sodium-ion battery (SIB) anodes made from transition metal dichalcogenides like molybdenum disulfide (MoS2), the challenges of poor cycle stability and rapid capacity degradation—attributable to low electronic conductivity and dissolution of chemical species in the electrolyte—limit the use of these promising layered materials as SIB anodes. This study presents the chemical functionalization of MoS2 nanosheets using polymer-derived silicon oxycarbide (SiOC) to prevent MoS2 from dissolving in the SIB organic electrolyte while maintaining its function in sodiation and desodiation processes. Our findings indicate that a MoS2–SiOC composite electrode significantly enhances cycle stability in sodium-ion cycling compared to pure MoS2, even after 100 cycles.

Hard carbon is widely regarded as the top anode choice for room temperature sodium-ion batteries due to its relatively high capacity, affordability, and scalability. In this study, switchgrass was utilized as a biomass model and subjected to carbonization at an ultrahigh temperature of 2050 °C using Joule heating to fabricate hard carbon anodes for sodium-ion batteries. The carbon materials derived from switchgrass naturally retain its three-dimensional porous structural design, featuring an average interlayer spacing of 0.376 nm. This larger interlayer spacing compared to graphite facilitates remarkable Na ion storage capability. Compared to samples carbonized at 1000 °C, the switchgrass-derived carbon processed at 2050 °C exhibits an enhanced initial Coulombic efficiency. Furthermore, due to the distinctive high-temperature treatment, the switchgrass-derived carbon demonstrates excellent rate capability and exceptional cycling performance.

To advance sodium ion battery technology, understanding the mechanisms of reversibility is essential for innovating electrode designs. In this study, we employed a hydrogel-embedding technique to control the formation of few-layer SnS2 nanosheets positioned between nitrogen- and sulfur-doped carbon nanotubes (NS-CNT) and amorphous carbon. The resulting carbon-sandwiched SnS2 nanosheets exhibit exceptional sodium storage capabilities. In operando small angle X-ray scattering, along with ex situ X-ray absorption near edge spectra, indicates that the redox reactions involving SnS2/NS-CNT and sodium ions are significantly reversible. However, the structural evolution is irreversible, where SnS2 nanosheets break down and subsequently reform into SnS2 nanoparticles. This study offers operando insights into the chemical environment changes and structural dynamics of SnS2-based anodes, elucidates their reversible reaction mechanism, and underscores the critical role of engineered carbon support in maintaining electrode structure stability.

We conducted a detailed study on the suitability of single-layer VS2 polytypes as anode materials in sodium-ion batteries using density functional theory calculations. Our findings indicate that sodiation tends to prevent the 1H-to-1T structural phase transition, which is contrary to the lithiation-induced transition seen in monolayer MoS2. This implies that VS2 could maintain better structural stability throughout charging and discharging cycles. Sodium atoms were observed to diffuse rapidly in both polytypes, exhibiting low diffusion barriers of 0.085 eV (1H) and 0.088 eV (1T). To identify stable configurations of Na on VS2, we used ab initio random structure searching. This revealed that both the V top and the hexagonal center sites are preferred for Na adsorption, with the 1H phase demonstrating stronger binding. Interestingly, our search discovered that Na clusters can form as a stacked second layer at full concentration, diverging from previous assumptions of uniform, single-layer Na adsorption. With favorable specific energy capacities (232.91 mAh/g for 1H and 116.45 mAh/g for 1T) and open-circuit voltages (1.30 V for 1H and 1.42 V for 1T), VS2 emerges as a viable alternative for sodium-ion battery anodes with excellent structural integrity. This study also highlights the effectiveness of ab initio random structure searching in evaluating materials for energy storage applications.

Vanadium oxide nanofilm-coated graphene oxide (GO) is formed through the thermally induced explosive disintegration of a microcrystalline ammonium peroxovanadate-GO composite. The GO sheets act to separate the microcrystalline grains while capturing and containing the products of the microexplosion, leading to the nanoscale deposition on the GO. Heating the supported nanofilm results in various nanocrystalline phases of vanadium oxide (V3O7, VO2) depending on the temperature. This marks the first instance of microexplosive disintegration of a crystalline peroxo compound leading to a nanocoating. Given the recent plethora of peroxide-rich crystalline materials, this technique could serve as a valuable general method for creating nanofilms. The V3O7@GO composite product, when tested as an anode for sodium ion batteries, exhibited a high charge capacity during high-rate charge-discharge cycling (150 mAh g-1 at 3000 mA g-1 compared to 300 mAh g-1 at 100 mA g-1) owing to the unique nanomorphology of the vanadium oxide.

Tin disulfide (SnS2) is gaining attention as a viable anode material for sodium ion batteries (NIBs) due to its distinctive layered structure, substantial theoretical capacity, and affordability. Typically, SnS2 nanomaterials are produced through the hydrothermal method, which is not only time-intensive but also challenging to scale for large-scale production. This research introduces a straightforward solid-state reaction method to synthesize carbon-coated SnS2 (SnS2/C) anode materials through the annealing of metallic Sn, sulfur powder, and polyacrylonitrile in a sealed vacuum glass tube. The resulting SnS2/C nanospheres with their unique layered structure exhibit a high reversible capacity of 660 mAh g(-1) at a current density of 50 mA g(-1) and retain a capacity of 570 mAh g(-1) after 100 cycles, with a degradation rate of only 0.14% per cycle. This performance ranks among the best reported for SnS2/C anodes in NIBs thus far. The outstanding cycling stability of the SnS2/C electrode is attributed to the stable nanosphere morphology and maintained structural integrity during charge and discharge cycles, as confirmed by ex situ analysis.

Sodium is both low-cost and plentiful, making sodium-ion batteries a promising alternative to lithium-ion batteries. However, the lower energy density and poor cycling stability of current sodium-ion batteries hinder their practical application in future smart power grids and stationary storage. Tin oxides (SnO2) are potential candidates for high-capacity anode materials in sodium-ion batteries due to their high sodium storage capability, abundance, and low toxicity. Nevertheless, SnO2-based anodes face challenges in practical applications because they undergo significant volume changes during repeated charge and discharge cycles. These volume changes lead to substantial pulverization of the active material and loss of electrical contact between the SnO2 and the carbon conductor, resulting in rapid capacity degradation. We present a novel amorphous carbon-coated SnO2-electrodeposited porous carbon nanofiber (PCNF@SnO2@C) composite that exhibits high sodium storage potential and preserves its structural integrity during multiple cycles. Electrochemical tests demonstrated that this SnO2-infused nanofiber composite anode delivers excellent electrochemical performance, with a high capacity of 374 mAh g(-1), good capacity retention of 82.7%, and a high Coulombic efficiency of 98.9% after the 100th cycle.

Sodium ion batteries (SIBs) are considered a leading option for large-scale energy storage, with the development of high-performance anode materials being a key challenge for advancing these batteries. Sn-MoS2-C@C microspheres have been innovatively structured, featuring Sn nanoparticles evenly distributed within MoS2 nanosheets and a uniform thin carbon film coating the microspheres, fabricated via the hydrothermal method. These Sn-MoS2-C@C microspheres exhibit superior Na-storage capabilities as an SIB anode, offering a high reversible charge capacity of 580.3 mAh g⁻¹ at 0.05 A g⁻¹ and excellent rate capacities of 580.3, 373, 326, 285.2, and 181.9 mAh g⁻¹ at current densities of 0.05, 0.5, 1, 2, and 5 A g⁻¹, respectively. Remarkably, a charge specific capacity of 245 mAh g⁻¹ is maintained after 2750 cycles at 2 A g⁻¹, highlighting superb cycling durability. Due to its high capacity and prolonged stability, the Sn-MoS2-C@C composite emerges as a highly promising anode material for SIBs.

Red phosphorus (P) is gaining significant interest as a potential anode material for high-energy density sodium-ion batteries (NIBs) because of its considerable theoretical capacity for sodium storage (2595 mAh g−1). However, its naturally insulating characteristic and significant volume changes during cycling lead to very low electrochemical activity, negatively impacting electrochemical performance. In this study, the authors present an effective approach to enhance the sodium storage capabilities of red P by encapsulating nanosized amorphous red P within a nitrogen-doped microporous carbon matrix derived from zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8), referred to as P@N-MPC. As an anode material for NIBs, the P@N-MPC composite delivers a high reversible specific capacity of approximately 600 mAh g−1 at 0.15 A g−1 and shows enhanced rate capacity (approximately 450 mAh g−1 at 1 A g−1 after 1000 cycles, with an extremely low capacity fading rate of 0.02% per cycle). The P@N-MPC's remarkable sodium storage performance is primarily due to its innovative structure. The N-doped porous carbon with sub-1 nm micropores enables rapid diffusion of organic electrolyte ions and improves the conductivity of the incorporated red P. Additionally, the porous carbon matrix accommodates the volume changes of red P during repeated sodiation/desodiation processes, maintaining structural integrity over a prolonged cycle life.

The dual-ion battery (DIB) system has garnered significant interest due to its advantages of being cost-effective, possessing high energy density, and being environmentally friendly. Nonetheless, DIBs utilizing sodium-ion electrolytes are rarely explored because of the scarcity of suitable anode materials allowing reversible Na+ insertion and extraction. In this study, we report for the first time on a novel sodium-ion based DIB, termed MoS2/C-G DIB, which utilizes a penne-like MoS2/C nanotube as the anode and expanded graphite as the cathode. The hierarchical structure of the MoS2/C nanotube provides an increased (002) interlayer spacing in 2H-MoS2, which enhances the kinetics of fast Na+ insertion and extraction, thereby improving the performance of the DIB. The MoS2/C-G DIB achieves a reversible capacity of 65 mA h g-1 at 2 C within a voltage range of 1.0-4.0 V. It also demonstrates good cycling stability over 200 cycles with 85% capacity retention, highlighting the potential applicability of sodium-ion based DIBs.

Integrating functional nanostructures within a lightweight nanocarbon matrix holds significant promise for creating advanced, high-performance electrodes suitable for rechargeable batteries. In this study, we embed core-shell (FeSe2/C) nanostructures into a carbon nanotube (CNT) framework through a simple wet-chemistry process combined with thermally induced selenization to achieve practical capacity. The CNT framework provides three-dimensional continuous pathways for electronic and ionic transfer, while its macropores offer ample space to load a high mass of FeSe2/C. Additionally, the carbon shell not only forms a robust electronic connection between CNTs and FeSe2 but also enhances the sodium ion diffusivity into FeSe2. It also serves as a buffer to accommodate volume changes. These distinctive structural features render the CNT/FeSe2/C composite an excellent medium for sodium storage, maintaining a capacity retention of 546 mAh g-1 even after 100 cycles at 100 mA g-1. Furthermore, areal and volumetric capacities of 5.06 mAh cm-2 and 158 mAh cm-3 are achieved at a high mass loading of 16.9 mg cm-2, respectively. The superior performance of this multi-benefit engineered structure suggests its potential as a candidate for secondary ion batteries, and its simple synthesis process allows for expansion to more complex structures with various morphologies (such as nanorods, nanowires, etc.) to meet increased energy requirements.

This paper presents NiSe2 nanooctahedra as a highly promising anode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). The material demonstrates excellent long-term cycling stability, maintaining 313 mAh/g after 4000 cycles at a rate of 5 A/g, and exhibits impressive high-rate capabilities, achieving 175 mAh/g at 20 A/g. Additionally, NiSe2 shows an initial Coulombic efficiency exceeding 90%. These exceptional performances are due to NiSe2's good conductivity, structural stability, and pseudocapacitive properties. Moreover, the mechanism of sodium ion storage in NiSe2 is explored using in situ and ex situ XRD. These attributes position NiSe2 as a strong contender for use in rechargeable SIBs.

Developing electrode materials for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) that are cost-effective, have a long lifespan, and support high-rate charging is crucial. However, rapidly charging and achieving high power density remains challenging for most SIB electrodes due to slow sodiation kinetics. In this study, we synthesize uniform mesoporous NiS2 nanospheres using a simple one-step method assisted by polyvinylpyrrolidone. By adjusting the voltage window, these NiS2 nanospheres achieve exceptional electrochemical performance in SIBs, with a reversible specific capacity of 692 mA h g-1. The NiS2 anode also demonstrates outstanding high-rate capability (253 mA h g-1 at 5 A g-1) and long-term cycling stability (retaining a capacity of 319 mA h g-1 even after 1000 cycles at 0.5 A g-1). A predominant pseudocapacitance contribution is confirmed through kinetics analysis. Additionally, in situ X-ray diffraction is used to explore the amorphization and conversion reactions occurring during the electrochemical processes of the mesoporous NiS2 nanospheres. The remarkable electrochemical characteristics indicate that NiS2 holds significant promise for advancing next-generation, large-scale energy storage solutions.

Nanosecond-pulsed liquid plasma offers a straightforward and effective approach to creating a Co3O4/CNTs nanocomposite architecture from carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and Co3O4 nanoparticle clusters in deionized water. A key characteristic of this composite is the uniform dispersion and anchoring of Co3O4 nanoparticle clusters within the CNT networks, where Co3O4 ensures high electrochemical reactivity with sodium, and CNTs maintain conductivity and stabilize the anode. Our study demonstrates that the Co3O4/CNT nanocomposite achieves a stable and high capacity of 403 mA h g(-1) at 50 mA g(-1) after 100 cycles, confirmed through a reversible conversion reaction via ex situ techniques for sodium uptake/extraction. The nanocomposite exhibits enhanced rate capability, with reversible capacities of 212 mA h g(-1) at 1.6 A g(-1) and 190 mA h g(-1) at 3.2 A g(-1). The simplicity of its synthesis and its high electrochemical performance make Co3O4/CNT nanocomposites promising anode materials for sodium-ion batteries.

Building on the strengths of dual-ion batteries (DIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), we have developed an advanced sodium-based dual-ion battery (Na-DIB) utilizing a PTCDA organic anode and ionic liquid (IL) electrolyte. This system delivers a top specific discharge capacity of 177 mAh g-1 at 0.5C, accompanied by an outstanding capacity retention exceeding 100% at 2C after 200 cycles. Remarkably, at a very high rate of 20C, the battery sustains a significant capacity of 60 mAh g-1 with a nearly perfect coulombic efficiency and 94% capacity retention after 1000 cycles. The battery's self-discharge rate was thoroughly examined, revealing an exceptionally low value of 0.18% h-1. Thus, this study proposes an impressive Na-DIB system that holds promise for large-scale applications.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) show promise as grid-scale energy storage solutions, yet they need to withstand extreme weather conditions. Nevertheless, SIBs capable of operating over a broad temperature range are seldom reported. In this study, we present a wide-temperature SIB featuring a carbon-coated Na4Fe3(PO4)2P2O7 (NFPP@C) cathode, a Bismuth (Bi) anode, and a diglyme-based electrolyte. We reveal that solvated Na+ ions can be directly stored in the Bi anode through an alloying process without requiring a de-solvent step. Additionally, the NFPP@C cathode shows a high Na+ diffusion coefficient at low temperatures. Consequently, the Bi//NFPP@C battery performs excellently even in cold conditions, maintaining 70.19% of its room-temperature capacity at -70 °C. Furthermore, thanks to the electrolyte's high boiling point, this battery also operates effectively at temperatures up to 100 °C. These promising results could pave the way for developing wide-temperature SIBs.

Ultrafine niobium oxide nanocrystals combined with reduced graphene oxide (Nb2O5 NCs/rGO) have proven to be a promising anode material for sodium-ion batteries, offering excellent rate performance and cycle durability. The Nb2O5 NCs/rGO was prepared through a controlled hydrolysis of niobium ethoxide, followed by heating at 450 °C in a flowing forming gas. Transmission electron microscopy revealed that Nb2O5 NCs, averaging 3 nm in size, were evenly distributed on rGO sheets, with voids present among the nanocrystals. The structure of ultrafine Nb2O5 NCs anchored to a highly conductive rGO network enhances charge transfer and mitigates volume changes during the sodiation/desodiation cycle while also providing increased active surface area for sodium ion storage, leading to outstanding rate and cycle performance. Ex situ XPS analysis indicated that the sodium ion storage mechanism in Nb2O5 might involve a Nb(5+)/Nb(4+) redox reaction, with the ultrafine Nb2O5 NCs offering more surface area to facilitate this redox process.

This study reports that MnO2 can function as an electrochemically active conversion anode for Na-ion batteries (NIBs) for the first time. Space-confined ultrafine (UF)-MnO2, with an average crystal size of 4 nm, was synthesized using a porous silicon dioxide templated hydrothermal method and demonstrated a high reversible sodiation capacity of 567 mA h g(-1). This is in stark contrast to the negligible activity observed in larger MnO2 nanocrystallite aggregates of 14 nm. The significantly improved sodiation performance of UF-MnO2 is attributed to its reduced crystal size, which enhances Na ion diffusion, and high surface energy due to extensive heterogeneous interfacial bonding with the surrounding SiO2. The UF-MnO2 anode shows exceptional rate and cycle performance, retaining over 70% of its capacity after 500 cycles. In operando synchrotron X-ray absorption near-edge structural analysis uncovers combined charge-storage mechanisms involving conversion reactions between Mn(III) and Mn(II) oxides, expressed as Mn(III)-O1.5 + Na(+) + e(-) ↔ 1/2Na2O + Mn(II)-O, along with non-Mn-centered redox reactions. This discovery indicates a new strategy to "activate" potentially viable electrochemical electrode materials that seem inactive in their bulk form.

Current lithium-ion batteries encounter obstacles concerning the sustainability, cost, and availability of natural resources for their components. Sodium is emerging as a complementary energy storage material, providing adequate volumetric energy density. In sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), hard carbon is utilized at the anode instead of graphite, which requires the specific microdomain structure needed for sodium ion storage. Coal char offers a low-cost material and is a feasible source of hard carbon, presenting a high-value secondary use for the abundant char in coal.

This study investigates flash pyrolysis as an innovative method for synthesizing coal char for SIB anodes, using local bituminous coal from Utah. Flash pyrolysis heats char in a drop-tube furnace at 1000 °C/s, contrasting with traditional slow pyrolysis, where heating occurs at 20 °C/min. The char produced via flash pyrolysis (FP char) exhibits a markedly different surface structure compared to slow pyrolyzed (SP) char, with larger d-spacing (FP d-spacing = 0.379 nm, SP d-spacing = 0.364 nm) and a smaller closed micropore diameter (FP micropore = 1.52 nm, SP micropore = 1.91 nm), as determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and small angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) analysis.

The performance of SIBs using FP char versus SP char was tested in ether-based and ester-based electrolytes. FP char outperformed SP char as a SIB anode in both electrolytes. Furthermore, both char anodes demonstrated higher reversible capacity and improved initial coulombic efficiencies (ICE) with ether-based compared to ester-based electrolytes. Specifically, FP char combined with an ether-based electrolyte achieved a 10th cycle reversible capacity of 109.4 mAh/g, while SP char with an ester-based electrolyte reached 72.5 mAh/g, when cycled at 50 mA/g (in sodium metal half-cells). The FP ether cells showed an initial coulombic efficiency (ICE) of 64%, compared to the 52% ICE of SP ester cells. The superior electrochemical performance of FP cells is credited to different surface/bulk structure owing to the high heating rate. The improved performance of char anodes in ether-based cells is likely attributable to the formation of a thinner solid-electrolyte interphase and/or enhanced sodiation due to the ether-based electrolyte.

Sodium ion batteries (SIBs) are gaining renewed attention as a cost-effective alternative to lithium ion batteries due to the abundant supply of sodium and their similar storage mechanisms. VS4 is identified as a promising anode material for SIBs because of its low cost and unique linear chain structure that can facilitate sodium storage. In this study, we report the first-ever growth of VS4 on reduced graphene oxide (rGO) for use as an anode in SIBs. The VS4/rGO anode demonstrates impressive performance, delivering a reversible capacity of 362 mAh g(-1) at 100 mA g(-1) and exhibiting strong rate performance. We also examine the sodium storage behavior of the VS4/rGO composite. Unlike most transition metal sulfides, this composite undergoes a three-step separation mechanism during sodiation, transforming from VS4 to metallic V and Na2S, with an electrochemical process similar to Na-S. The results indicate that the VS4/rGO composite is a promising material for rechargeable SIBs.

The urgent demand for intrinsically safe and long-lasting sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) for large-scale energy storage applications persists. However, many of the SIBs currently developed face challenges with inadequate cycle life and safety risks. In response, we present an all-phosphate sodium-ion battery (AP-SIB) featuring a Na3V2(PO4)3 cathode, NaTi2(PO4)3 anode, and the nonflammable trimethyl phosphate (TMP) electrolyte. This AP-SIB demonstrates high safety, excellent rate performance, and an ultralong cycle life, along with zero-strain properties due to the inverse volume changes of the phosphate-based cathode and anode during charging and discharging cycles. This development offers a safer and cycle-stable Na-ion solution for electric storage needs.

Designing anode materials for sodium ion batteries is a complex task. Alloy anodes offer high gravimetric and volumetric capacities but tend to have a short cycle life due to ongoing pulverization caused by significant volume changes during cycling. In this study, we explore pure Sn, an irreversible conversion reaction with an alloy reaction (SnO), and a reversible conversion reaction with an alloy reaction (Sn4P3) to show that the pulverization and aggregation of alloy anodes can be partially reversed. Additionally, the progressive pulverization and aggregation during charge/discharge cycles can be halted with a reversible conversion reaction combined with an alloy reaction. The order of cycling stability for the three Sn-based anodes is Sn4P3 > SnO > Sn. The improved performance of Sn4P3 is due to the reversible reaction Sn4P3 + 9Na ↔ 4Sn + 3Na3P, which mitigates cracks, damage, and aggregation of Sn particles formed during the alloy process of 4Sn + 15Na ↔ Na15Sn4, thereby stopping pulverization. This repair process resembles natural self-healing, where damage is autonomously repaired, and the anode can thus be called a self-healing anode. Employing self-healing strategies to design electrode architectures is innovative and highly beneficial as it extends cycle life and presents a universal solution for stabilizing electrode materials.

Potassium-ion batteries (PIBs) are considered a promising alternative to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) due to the low cost and abundance of potassium. In this study, we examined the Sn4P3/C composite as a new anode material for PIBs. The Sn4P3/C electrode exhibited a reversible capacity of 384.8 mA h g-1 at a current density of 50 mA g-1 and showed impressive rate capability, maintaining 221.9 mA h g-1 even at 1 A g-1. This electrochemical performance surpasses any anode material previously reported for PIBs. Additionally, the Sn4P3/C electrode demonstrates a discharge potential plateau at 0.1 V in PIBs, slightly higher than the 0.01 V observed in sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), and remains well above the metal plating potential. This reduces dendrite formation during cycling, making Sn4P3 a relatively safe anode material, particularly suited for large-scale energy storage applications where significant quantities of electrode material are used. Moreover, a potential reaction mechanism for the Sn4P3/C composite as a PIB anode is proposed. This research may pave the way for further development of high-capacity, long-lasting alloy-based anodes for PIBs.

Single-layered MoS2 is recognized as a promising anode material for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), and potassium-ion batteries (PIBs) due to its high capacity and uniform ion transport channels. Nonetheless, its application is limited by low intrinsic conductivity and a tendency to agglomerate. A novel strategy is presented here: a charge-driven interlayer expansion, where Co2+ ions substitute Mo4+ in a doping form, granting the MoS2 layers negative charges and causing electrostatic repulsion. This, combined with the introduction of gaseous groups, drives interlayer expansion, disrupting the interlayer van der Waals forces and producing single-layered MoS2, which is uniformly dispersed in a carbon matrix due to the transformation of carbonaceous gaseous groups under high vapor pressure. The doping of Co atoms enhances the intrinsic conductivity of single-layered MoS2, while the carbon matrix prevents its agglomeration. During the conversion reaction, doped Co atoms are fully transformed into ultrasmall Co nanoparticles, imparting strong spin-polarized surface capacitance, which significantly improves ion transport and storage. As a result, the developed material exhibits exceptional Li/Na/K-ion storage performance, outperforming previously reported MoS2-based anodes. This charge-driven interlayer expansion strategy introduces a new approach for preparing single-layered MoS2, showcasing substantial potential for energy storage applications.

TiO2 microsphere electrodes, coated with carbon using a hydrothermal method, were created for use in sodium ion batteries, and their electrochemical characteristics were assessed based on varying carbon content levels. The carbon coating, achieved through sucrose addition, was effective in preventing the growth of TiO2 primary crystallites during the calcination process. The TiO2 electrode with a 20 wt % sucrose-based carbon coating demonstrated outstanding cycle stability, maintaining 100% retention over 50 cycles, and exhibited remarkable rate performance up to a 30 C rate at room temperature. This electrode achieved a high discharge capacity, delivering 155 mAh g(composite)(-1) at 0.1 C, 149 mAh g(composite)(-1) at 1 C, and 82.7 mAh g(composite)(-1) at a 10 C rate.

Using a hydrothermal method, a three-dimensional spider-web architecture composed of Na2Ti3O7 nanotubes is synthesized. This self-similar network architecture demonstrates outstanding performance as an anode for a room temperature sodium-ion battery for the first time, without the need for any additives such as binders or conducting agents.

While lithium-ion battery (LIB) technology has been dominant for several years, the rising demand and cost of lithium resources necessitate the swift development of alternative energy storage solutions. Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), which offer similar electrochemical properties at a lower cost, have attracted research interest. However, significant challenges such as lower reversible capacity and reduced lifespan due to the larger ionic radius of sodium ions persist. Enhancing anode materials has been identified as a promising method to address these issues. This paper reviews recent advancements in anode materials for SIBs and discusses future prospects.
