Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are promising for large-scale energy storage, though their power density is restricted by slow Na+ diffusion in cathode and anode materials. In this study, the authors introduce an ultrahigh power SIB prototype, featuring a high-rate Na3V2(PO4)3 (NVP) cathode, graphite-type mesocarbon microbeads (MCMB) anode, and Na+-diglyme electrolyte. The overpotential of the NVP cathode adheres to the Ohmic rule. Therefore, the developed NVP@C@carbon nanotubes (CNTs) cathode, utilizing highly conductive CNT networks, exhibits excellent electronic conductivity, minimizing overpotential and charge transfer resistances, resulting in an impressive rate capability exceeding 1000C. For the MCMB anode, an initial [Na-diglyme]+ co-intercalation step is driven by pseudocapacitance, followed by rapid ion diffusion through the expanded graphite layers. The quick (de)intercalation kinetics between the cathode and anode are well synchronized. As a result, the MCMB|1 m NaPF6 in diglyme|NVP@C@CNTs full-cell SIB achieves an energy density of 88 Wh kg−1 at a high power density of approximately 10 kW kg−1. Even at an ultrahigh power density of 23 kW kg−1, it maintains an energy density of 58 Wh kg−1. These promising full-cell results will advance the development of high-power SIBs for future large-scale applications.

The performance of sodium-ion batteries and the behavior at the anode/electrolyte interface are influenced by complex interactions among all cell components across a wide range of time and size scales. Studies focusing on a single scale fail to fully capture these intricate behaviors. To thoroughly understand these processes, broad, multiscale research is necessary. This perspectives article introduces various analytical and theoretical techniques and explains how they can be integrated to achieve a complete understanding of sodium-ion battery performance over its lifespan, with an emphasis on the interfaces of hard carbon anodes. These methods address a variety of length and time scales, from micro to nano, and from cell level to atomic structures, including a wide range of physical and (electro)chemical properties. The article explores how mass spectrometric, microscopic, spectroscopic, electrochemical, thermodynamic, and physical methods can be utilized to access different information types essential for understanding battery behavior. It also discusses how to combine these methods to uncover multiscale phenomena at the anode interface, aiming to develop a comprehensive understanding of their impact on the overall function of sodium-ion batteries.

The engineering of 3D graphene/metal composites with extremely small metal sizes and strong metal–graphene interfacial interactions for energy storage remains challenging and scarcely documented. This study introduces a straightforward top-down approach for creating SnSb-in-plane nanoconfined 3D N-doped porous graphene networks intended for anodes in sodium ion batteries. These networks consist of numerous interconnected empty N-graphene boxes, with ultrasmall SnSb nanocrystals firmly embedded in-plane. The comprehensive encapsulation design (plane-to-plane contact) offers an extensive interface between N-graphene and SnSb nanocrystals, significantly improving electron conductivity and structural integrity of the electrode. It also provides additional interfacial sodium storage, resulting in markedly enhanced high-rate sodium storage capacity and stability, as demonstrated by experimental findings and first-principles simulations. Furthermore, this top-down method opens new avenues for the cost-effective and large-scale production of 3D graphene/metal composites for diverse energy-related applications.

We introduce a novel sodium-ion battery comprising a NaFePO₄ cathode paired with a nanocomposite tin-carbon (Sn-C) sodium-alloying anode. The NaFePO₄ cathode is derived from the direct Li-Na conversion of a LiFePO₄ cathode within the full cell, using the Sn-C anode and a sodium-ion electrolyte. Our findings demonstrate that the unique methodology employed here effectively and efficiently transforms LiFePO₄ into NaFePO₄ within a sodium-ion battery operating at 3 V, achieving a maximum reversible capacity of 150 mAh g⁻¹, along with high reversibility and excellent rate capability.

Crystalline Covalent Organic Frameworks (COFs) are characterized by their ordered, accessible nano-channels, which can be utilized as anodes in metal ion batteries, such as lithium-ion (LIB) and sodium-ion batteries (SIB) when functionalized with redox-active groups. While sodium is more abundant than lithium, the larger size of sodium ions makes their intercalation energetically unfavorable for commercial graphite anodes used in Li-ion batteries. Moreover, sodium ions experience slower movement within electrodes, hindering the swift sodiation of SIBs. Chemical manipulation to create an electronic driving force at electrodes may offer a versatile solution to these challenges. In this study, we introduce anodes for SIBs based on three isostructural COFs with nearly identical Highest Occupied Molecular Orbitals (HOMO) levels but different Lowest Unoccupied Molecular Orbitals (LUMO) energy levels. This LUMO variation is purposefully achieved by incorporating electron-deficient centers (phenyl vs. tetrazine vs. bispyridine-tetrazine) into the COF structure. As cell potential decreases, electrons are stored in the anti-bonding LUMO, making these electron-enriched LUMO levels effective for attracting sluggish sodium ions from the electrolyte. The COF's natural porosity aids the lodging and diffusion of Na+ ions. These COFs result in cells with high specific capacity (energy density) and rate performance (efficient charge-discharge rates), which is more challenging for Na+ compared to Li+. The bispyridine-tetrazine COF, with the lowest LUMO energy level, demonstrates a specific capacity of 340 mA h g-1 at 1 A g-1 and 128 mA h g-1 at a high current density of 15 A g-1. It shows only a 24% capacity decrease when the current density is raised from 0.1 to 1 A g-1, the smallest reduction among leading COF-based Na-ion battery anodes.

Symmetric sodium ion batteries present advantageous characteristics, such as low cost, straightforward manufacturing, and easy post-process recycling, making them ideal for large-scale stationary energy storage applications. In this study, we introduced a symmetric sodium ion battery utilizing dual-electron reactions with Na3MnTi(PO4)3, a material featuring a NASICON structure. The Na3MnTi(PO4)3 electrode delivers a stable capacity of up to 160 mAh g-1 with a Coulombic efficiency of 97% at 0.1 C, capitalizing on the redox reactions of Ti3+/4+, Mn2+/3+, and Mn3+/4+. This research is the first to explore a symmetric sodium-ion full cell using Na3MnTi(PO4)3 as both the cathode and anode in an organic electrolyte, showcasing excellent reversibility and cycling performance with voltage plateaus at approximately 1.4 V and 1.9 V. The full cell offers a reversible capacity of 75 mAh g-1 at 0.1 C and an energy density of 52 Wh kg-1. Furthermore, ex-situ XRD analysis and first-principle calculations are conducted to study the sodiation mechanism and structural evolution. This study suggests a practical approach for enhancing energy density in symmetric sodium-ion batteries.

In the development of a high-performance sodium-ion battery (SIB) anode, binary zinc phosphides (ZnP2 and Zn3P2) were synthesized through a simple solid-state heat treatment process, and their sodium storage properties were assessed. ZnP2 displayed superior sodium reactivity compared to Zn3P2. Consequently, a C-modified ZnP2 composite (ZnP2-C) was produced to enhance electrochemical performance. To understand the electrochemical reaction mechanism of ZnP2-C during sodiation and desodiation, various ex-situ analytical techniques were utilized. During the sodiation process, ZnP2 in the composite transformed into NaZn13 and Na3P phases through a one-step conversion reaction. During desodiation, the Zn and P in NaZn13 and Na3P, respectively, reverted fully to the original ZnP2 phase. Due to this one-step conversion/recombination during cycling, the ZnP2-C composite demonstrated excellent electrochemical performance, achieving a highly reversible capacity of 883 mAh g-1 after 130 cycles with no capacity degradation and an impressive C-rate capability of 500 mAh g-1 at 1C and 350 mAh g-1 at 3C.

Aromatic organic compounds hold potential as electrode materials in rechargeable batteries and are anticipated to enhance the development of anode and cathode materials for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). Nonetheless, many aromatic organic compounds considered for SIB anodes so far experience significant degradation during fast charging/discharging and have poor long-term cycling performance. This paper introduces a molecular design concept intended to enhance the stability of organic compounds used in battery electrodes. The designed compound, [2.2.2.2]paracyclophane‐1,9,17,25‐tetraene (PCT), employs local aromaticity to stabilize its neutral state and global aromaticity to stabilize its doubly reduced state. This results in an anode material with exceptionally stable cycling performance and excellent fast-charge/discharge capabilities, offering a promising new direction for the development of electrode materials for SIBs and other battery types.

Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2), known for its two-dimensional layered structure, is a promising candidate for sodium-ion battery (SIB) anodes due to its favorable theoretical capacity and affordability. However, MoS2 faces significant challenges, including poor rate capability due to slow Na+ intercalation kinetics and inadequate cycling stability caused by stacking of MoS2 layers. In this study, we developed a novel bundled defect-rich MoS2 (BD-MoS2) architecture, featuring MoS2 with large vacancies bundled by ultrathin MoO3, created through an easy quenching process. As an SIB anode, the BD-MoS2 electrode demonstrates extremely fast charge and discharge capabilities, attributed to a pseudocapacitive-controlled Na+ storage mechanism. Experimental data and theoretical analysis reveal that Na+ can traverse the MoS2 layers via vacancies, enabling three-dimensional Na+ diffusion and enhancing kinetics beyond mere lateral diffusion. Additionally, the bundling structure minimizes sheet stacking, resulting in an enhanced cycle life with highly reversible capacities of 350 and 272 mAh g-1 at current densities of 2 and 5 A g-1 respectively, sustained over 1000 cycles.

Hard carbon (HC) stands out as the leading candidate for anode materials in sodium-ion batteries. Certain material properties such as the intensity ratio of the Raman spectrum, the lateral crystallite size (La) of HC, and the interlayer distance (d002) are considered influential on anode performance. However, these do not directly represent the bulk properties related to the Na+ intercalation reaction, as Raman analysis is highly surface-sensitive, and La and d002 only provide one-dimensional crystalline insights. In this study, the crystallite interlayer area (Ai), which is defined by La, d002, and stacking height (Lc), is proposed as the determinant of Na+ intercalation behavior in various HCs. It was found that different wood-derived HCs showed a similar total capacity of about 250 mAh g−1, while the Na+ intercalation capacity (Ci) correlated proportionally with Ai, boasting a correlation coefficient of R^2 = 0.94. Moreover, the Ai evaluation factor was applicable to previous studies and showed a strong correlation with their Ci, suggesting that Ai serves as a more broadly applicable metric than traditional evaluation methods.

Researchers have identified a beneficial influence of the polyacrylic acid (PAA)-carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) binder in improving the performance of oxide-based anodes in batteries. They successfully obtained a range of oxide powders with exceptionally high capacity and cycling stability, a feat rarely achieved, especially as most of these powders did not involve any specific carbon modification or morphology control.

Sodium's abundant availability makes sodium-ion rechargeable batteries more appealing than lithium-ion batteries for large-scale energy storage, provided a suitable Na host cathode is identified that offers adequate capacity, voltage, and cycle life at specified charge/discharge rates. Hexacyanometallates, due to their low cost, straightforward synthesis, and rigid open framework enabling rapid Na(+) insertion and extraction, show promise as cathodes. This study reveals an interesting effect of interstitial H2O on the structure and electrochemical properties of sodium manganese(II) hexacyanoferrates(II) with the nominal composition Na2MnFe(CN)6·zH2O (Na2-δMnHFC). The newly identified dehydrated Na2-δMnHFC phase demonstrates exceptional electrochemical performance, surpassing other known Na-ion cathode materials. It achieves a reversible capacity of 150 mAh g(-1) at 3.5 V in a sodium half-cell and 140 mAh g(-1) in a full cell paired with a hard-carbon anode. At a 20 C charge/discharge rate, the half-cell capacity reaches 120 mAh g(-1), and at 0.7 C, the cell maintains 75% of its capacity after 500 cycles.

Graphene-based nanomaterials have emerged as promising anode materials for sodium-ion batteries, owed to graphene's fascinating properties and the synergistic interactions between graphene and active materials. Nonetheless, the two-dimensional structure of graphene allows for quick sodium ion diffusion only in the parallel direction, while diffusion in the vertical direction is challenging, therefore restricting the rate capability of graphene-based electrodes. To address this issue, pore-forming engineering has been utilized to perforate graphene while simultaneously facilitating the in situ growth of Co3Se4 nanoparticles. The introduction of in-plane nanoholes overcomes the physical impediments of the graphene nanosheets, permitting rapid electrolyte ion transport in the longitudinal direction. Moreover, this configuration prevents aggregation of Co3Se4 nanoparticles due to their strong affinity for graphene. As a result of the high conductivity and enhanced ion transport provided by this innovative architecture, the Co3Se4/holey graphene displays an impressive rate performance of 519.5 mAh g−1 at 5.0 A g−1, alongside desirable cycle stability. This study concludes that the internal transport of sodium within graphene-based composites is essential for improving rate performance, and demonstrates that this method is effective in refining graphene-based nanomaterials for potential use as anode materials.

The strategic creation of anode electrodes for sodium-ion batteries poses challenges due to issues such as slow Na+ diffusion kinetics and substantial volume expansion. Considerable efforts, including the development of carbon composites and innovative nanostructures, have been directed towards advancing anode materials. In this study, an ultra-small few-layer MoS2 nanostructure confined within a hierarchical porous carbon fiber composite was synthesized via a nanocasting process using a newly designed hierarchical porous carbon fiber as a template. As an anode material, this composite demonstrates excellent electrochemical performance for sodium-ion batteries. Notably, it achieves high reversible capacities (491 mA h g-1 after 50 cycles at 0.1 A g-1), superior rate performance (387 mA h g-1 at 2 A g-1), and exceptional long-term cycling stability (234 mA h g-1 at 1 A g-1 after 3000 cycles). It is important to highlight that this material exhibits some of the best long-term cycling properties recorded so far for MoS2-based anode materials in sodium-ion batteries. This approach might provide new perspectives for crafting high-performance anode materials for sodium-ion batteries.

Sodium ion batteries (SIBs) have garnered significant interest for their potential in large-scale electrical grid management and the affordability of sodium. Among potential anode materials, iron oxides (FeOx) stand out due to their high theoretical capacity and low cost. However, FeOx anodes face challenges such as slow reaction kinetics and considerable lattice changes, leading to poor rate performance and rapid capacity loss during sodiation and desodiation. This study introduces Mn ions into interstitial sites within the Fe3O4 lattice to produce Mn-incorporated Fe3O4/graphene (M-Fe3O4/G) composites via a simple hydrothermal method. XRD Rietveld refinement and first-principles calculations confirm that Mn incorporation enhances electron density around the Fermi level, resulting in increased electrical conductivity and improved electrochemical performance. The M0.1Fe2.9O4/G composite achieves a notable reversible capacity of 439.8 mAh g-1 at 100 mA g-1 over 200 cycles. At a high current density of 1 A g-1, the M-Fe3O4/G composites maintain stability for over 1200 cycles, providing a capacity of 210 mAh g-1. When paired with a Na3V2(PO4)3-type cathode, the Mn-incorporated Fe3O4/G composites show excellent compatibility in full SIBs, offering a capacity of 161.2 mAh g-1 at 1 A g-1 after 100 cycles. The Mn ion regulation within the Fe3O4 lattice offers valuable insights into optimizing metal oxide anode materials for SIB applications.

Sodium ion (Na-ion) batteries, known for their low cost and scalability, present a promising alternative to current lithium-ion batteries. To address their energy density limitations, a viable approach involves creating a high-voltage anode-free configuration, which utilizes a lightweight aluminum current collector at the anode and a high-voltage sodiumized cathode. This setup demands stringent requirements for Na reversibility and high-voltage stability from the electrolyte. In response, a 3A zeolite molecular sieve film is strategically designed, and a highly aggregated solvation structure is formed through size effects. This effectively suppresses minor but persistent oxidative decomposition, extending oxidative stability to 4.5 V while maintaining the anode's Na reversibility at 99.91%. As a result, we develop anode-free cells with high energy densities of 369 and 372 W h kg⁻¹ for 4.0 and 4.25 V class cells, respectively. Additionally, this approach facilitates a prolonged lifespan of 250 cycles for 4.0 V-class anode-free cells and significantly lowers costs in a sustainable manner.

Antimony-based materials are recognized as promising anodes for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to their high theoretical capacities and suitable sodium insertion potentials. However, the energy density and cycling stability achieved with these Sb-based anodes for SIBs thus far remain considerably restricted and require substantial enhancement. In this study, we present a new Sb/C hybrid design where Sb nanorods are encapsulated within highly conductive nitrogen and sulfur co-doped carbon frameworks (Sb@(N, S-C)). This hybrid anode for SIBs maintains high reversible capacities—621.1 mAh g⁻¹ at 100 mA g⁻¹ after 150 cycles, and 390.8 mAh g⁻¹ at 1 A g⁻¹ after 1000 cycles. Furthermore, at increased current densities of 2, 5, and 10 A g⁻¹, the Sb@(N, S-C) hybrid continues to exhibit high reversible capacities of 534.4, 430.8, and 374.7 mAh g⁻¹, respectively. The impressive sodium storage performance can be primarily attributed to the distinctive cross-linked carbon networks, which provide highly conductive frameworks that facilitate rapid ion and electron transfer, mitigate volume expansion, and prevent the agglomeration of Sb nanorods during cycling.

The study explores the introduction of oxygen vacancies in anatase TiO2 as a method to enhance electron and Na+ ion transport, crucial for optimizing the electrochemical properties of anatase TiO2. Achieving a controlled introduction of these vacancies for sodium-ion anodes remains challenging. This paper presents an innovative approach using plasma treatment to incorporate oxygen vacancies into an urchin-like N-doped carbon-coated anatase TiO2 (NC-DTO). The synergy of oxygen vacancies and the conductive N-doped carbon coating significantly elevates the sodium storage capabilities of NC-DTO. As a sodium-ion battery anode, the NC-DTO electrode exhibits outstanding electrochemical performance, including a capacity of 272 mA h g-1 at 0.25 C, a capacity retention of 98.8% after 5000 cycles at 10 C, and an ultrahigh capacity of 150 mA h g-1 at 15 C. Through density functional theory calculations and experimental evidence, it is shown that the improved sodium storage performance derives from the enhanced electronic conductivity of the N-doped carbon layer, alongside a reduced band gap and decreased sodiation energy barrier due to oxygen vacancies. This study emphasizes that using plasma to introduce oxygen vacancies into TiO2 can significantly advance its electrochemical properties and is applicable to various metal oxides in energy storage applications.

Black phosphorus (BP) has garnered significant attention as a promising anode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIB) due to its high theoretical capacity of 2596 mAh g-1 and excellent electrical conductivity of approximately 300 S m-1. Nonetheless, its practical application is hampered by substantial volume changes during electrochemical cycling. In this study, we substantially enhance BP's reversible performance in SIBs by covalently bonding functionalized BP to graphene. This enhanced interaction improves BP's stability throughout extensive cycling by reinforcing its connection to graphene. The linkage decreases surface energy and increases BP's thickness, broadening the channel between the BP nanosheets and graphene. This expanded channel accommodates more sodium ions, hence improving the cycling performance. Notably, experimental analysis identifies for the first time two types of phosphorus-carbon bonds. Leveraging this strategy, the BP-based SIB anode achieves a specific capacity of 1472 mAh g-1 at 0.1 A g-1 by the 50th cycle and 650 mAh g-1 at 1 A g-1 after 200 cycles.

Symmetric sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) offer potential for large-scale energy storage due to their straightforward production process and the extensive availability of sodium. Nonetheless, many of these batteries face challenges with low energy density. In this study, we synthesize a high-performance Na4V2(PO4)3 anode using electrochemical preintercalation, and for the first time, we construct a high energy density symmetric SIB with Na3V2(PO4)3 as the cathode and Na4V2(PO4)3 as the anode, leveraging the enhanced redox pair of V4+/V2+. When assessed in a half-cell configuration, both electrodes demonstrate stable electrochemical performance over more than 3000 cycles. The symmetric SIBs deliver an output voltage of 3.0 V and achieve a cell-level energy density of 138 W h kg^-1. Additionally, the mechanism of sodium storage is investigated through in situ X-ray diffraction across an extended voltage range of 0.01-3.9 V.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are a promising substitute for lithium-ion batteries in large-scale energy storage because of the plentiful availability of sodium resources. Metal sulfides are considered potential anode materials for SIBs due to their cost-effectiveness and environmental friendliness. In this study, we have successfully synthesized a series of copper sulfides (Cu2S, Cu7S4, and Cu7KS4) through an easy electrochemical method using KCl-NaCl-Na2S molten salts, marking a first in the field. The Cu2S produced features a micron-sized flake structure and was evaluated as an SIB anode, delivering a capacity of 430 mAh g-1 with a high initial Coulombic efficiency of 84.9% at a current density of 100 mA g-1. Furthermore, the Cu2S anode showcases excellent capacity (337 mAh g-1 at 20 A g-1, equivalent to 50 C) and exceptional cycle stability (retaining 88.2% of its capacity after 5000 cycles at 5 A g-1, with a fade rate of just 0.0024% per cycle). Additionally, pseudocapacitance and a robust porous structure formed in situ during cycling enhance the rate capability and cyclic performance of the Cu2S anodes, as shown through kinetics analysis and ex situ characterization.

Sodium-ion batteries are an appealing choice for grid-level energy storage, thanks to sodium's abundant availability and the low cost of sodium-based materials. Phosphorus (P) stands out as a promising anode material for these batteries, possessing a theoretical capacity of 2596 mAh/g. While red phosphorus (RP) exhibits inferior electronic conductivity and initial Coulombic efficiency compared to black phosphorus (BP), the advancement of BP anodes has been hindered by high material costs and limited production capabilities. To overcome these obstacles, we have devised a straightforward and scalable technique to synthesize a layered black phosphorus/graphene composite (BP/rGO) through room temperature pressurization. Anodes of BP/rGO crafted using this method, without carbon black and binder, demonstrated specific charge capacities of 1460.1, 1401.2, 1377.6, 1339.7, 1277.8, 1123.78, and 720.8 mAh/g in rate capability tests with charge and discharge current densities of 0.1, 0.5, 1, 5, 10, 20, and 40 A/g, respectively. In cycling performance tests after 500 deep cycles, BP/rGO anodes maintained capacities of 1250 and 640 mAh/g at 1 and 40 A/g, respectively, indicating marked enhancement in performance for sodium-ion battery anodes.

A symmetric sodium-ion battery employing an aqueous electrolyte is introduced, featuring NASICON-structured Na3MnTi(PO4)3 as both the anode and cathode. This material includes two electrochemically active transition metals, with the Ti(4+)/Ti(3+) redox couple functioning on the anode side and the Mn(3+)/Mn(2+) redox couple on the cathode side. This symmetric cell, based on the bipolar electrode material, demonstrates a distinct voltage plateau near 1.4 V in an aqueous electrolyte, along with stable cycling performance and excellent rate capability. The emergence of this aqueous symmetric sodium-ion battery offers a promising solution for large-scale stationary energy storage due to its high safety and low cost.

To enhance the energy density and rate capability of sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), electrodes with improved Na + storage capability and cycling stability are essential. In this study, we introduce a coral-like FeP composite where FeP nanoparticles are anchored and distributed within a nitrogen-doped 3D carbon framework (FeP@NC). Thanks to the continuous N-doped carbon structure and a spring-buffering graphitized carbon layer enveloping the FeP nanoparticles, the sodium-ion battery utilizing the FeP@NC composite showcases remarkable cycling stability at 10 A g⁻¹, maintaining 82.0% of its capacity over 10,000 cycles. Crucially, a particle refinement mechanism that increases capacity during cycling is rigorously verified. Specifically, the FeP nanoparticles undergo a refinement-recombination process during the initial cycle, followed by a comprehensive refinement pattern after numerous cycles. This leads to a gradual increase in graphitization and interface magnetization, creating additional active sites for Na + storage and thus contributing to increased capacity with continued cycling. This capacity enhancement is also applicable to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). This research provides new insights into the mechanisms of capacity improvement during cycling and offers a potential strategy for designing high-performance anode materials for SIBs and LIBs.

Developing hard carbon with a high initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) and excellent cycling stability is crucial for the practical application of sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). However, the presence of defects and oxygen-containing groups along the edges or layers of carbon in hard carbon is unavoidable, leading to a high density of irreversible Na+ sites. This reduces efficiency and can cause battery failure. Therefore, eliminating these defect structures is vital for improving battery performance. In this study, we propose a method of applying a soft-carbon coating to free-standing hard-carbon electrodes, effectively preventing the formation of defects and oxygen-containing groups in hard carbon. Electrochemical results reveal that these soft-carbon-coated, free-standing hard-carbon electrodes can achieve an exceptionally high ICE of 94.1% and exhibit long cycling performance, with 99% capacity retention after 100 cycles at a current density of 20 mA g-1, demonstrating their significant potential in practical sodium storage applications. Furthermore, we investigated the sodium storage mechanism using operando Raman spectroscopy. Our findings extend the "adsorption-intercalation-pore filling-deposition" model. We propose that pore filling in the plateau region can be divided into two stages: (1) sodium fills pores near the carbon layer's inner wall; (2) once nearly saturated, additional sodium can deposit onto the existing sodium in the inner wall pores.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are considered promising for large-scale energy storage systems due to the plentiful supply and widespread availability of sodium. Various strategies have been effectively implemented to address issues related to the large ion size at medium to low current densities. However, there is a substantial demand for enhancing the fast-charging capabilities of SIBs to meet escalating energy demands at large and grid levels. In this study, we introduce a core-shell Co2VO4/carbon composite anode specifically designed to address the fast-charging challenge of SIBs. The combination of the stable spinel Co2VO4 structure, the nanosphere dimensions, and the carbon shell facilitates improved Na+ ion diffusion and electron transfer rates, resulting in exceptional electrochemical performance. At an ultrahigh current density of 5 A g-1, the Co2VO4@C anode demonstrated a capacity of 135.1 mAh g-1 and retained over 98% of its capacity after 2000 cycles via a pseudocapacitive dominant mechanism. This research offers valuable insights into the design of fast-charging materials for SIBs, as well as other battery technologies, including lithium-ion batteries.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are anticipated to become a viable commercial substitute for lithium-ion batteries in grid electricity storage due to their potentially lower costs in the future. Currently, the development of an effective anode material poses a significant challenge for SIBs, especially at room temperature. Graphite is noticeably limited in accommodating the larger radius of sodium ions (Na+) compared to lithium ions (Li+), while hard carbon, with a larger interlayer distance, offers a relatively high storage capacity and durable cycling life. However, its application is constrained by drawbacks such as low initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) caused by a large surface area and high synthetic cost. In this context, we propose a novel coupled carbonization method to produce cost-effective hard carbon by pyrolyzing and carbonizing a mixture of readily available sucrose and phenolic resin. Thanks to the specialized pyrolysis process and optimized parameters, the resulting hard carbon exhibits an exceptionally low surface area of 1.54 m² g⁻¹ and a high initial Coulombic efficiency of 87%, which are rarely reported and enhance Na+ consumption efficiency at the cathode. Additionally, this hard carbon, with a large interlayer gap of 3.95 Å, achieves a higher capacity of 319 mAh g⁻¹ and maintains a robust capacity retention of 90% over 150 cycles. Further, a full cell featuring a hard carbon anode paired with an air-stable O3-Na0.9[Cu0.22Fe0.30Mn0.48]O2 cathode demonstrates a high ICE of 80% and an energy density of 256 Wh kganode⁻¹ (vs hard carbon), alongside trustworthy cycling performance. These findings confirm the feasibility and adaptability of our synthesis strategy, while suggesting that such tunable carbon-based materials may have broader applications beyond their appealing features for Na-ion batteries.

Sodium-ion batteries (NIBs) and potassium-ion batteries (KIBs) are gaining attention as valuable complements to lithium-ion battery (LIB) technology, contributing to the diversification of the battery market. Hard carbon emerges as a viable anode option for LIBs, NIBs, and KIBs due to its significant capacity, sustainability, abundance, and stable physicochemical characteristics. In this work, we synthesize a series of hard carbons through hydrothermal carbonization followed by pyrolysis at various temperatures to precisely modify their structural properties. As anodes, these hard carbons show varying ion-storage behaviors with Li, Na, and K, with NIBs delivering the highest reversible capacity. Comprehensive materials and electrochemical analyses are conducted to elucidate the relationship between structural attributes and electrochemical performance, shedding light on the specific alkali-ion storage mechanisms within hard carbons. Furthermore, the top-performing hard carbon is paired with a sodium cathode Na3V2(PO4)3 in a Na-ion pouch cell, achieving a high power density of 2172 W kg−1 and an energy density of 181.5 Wh kg−1 (calculated from the total weight of active materials in both anode and cathode). This Na-ion pouch cell also exhibits remarkable stability over ultra-long cycle life (9000 hours or 5142 cycles), showcasing the credible potential of these materials as sustainable, scalable anodes for post-Li battery technologies.

Sodium ion batteries (NIB, NAB, SIB) are garnering interest as a more cost-effective alternative to lithium ion batteries (LIB) due to the widespread and equitable distribution of sodium resources. Tin is a notably promising anode material for SIBs, capable of alloying with up to 3.75 sodium atoms, resulting in a charge storage capacity of 847 mAh g(-1). In this paper, we present the latest insights into the phase transformations induced by sodiation and the related performance across various Sn-based systems, including metallic Sn and its alloys, tin oxide (SnO2), tin sulfide (SnS2/SnS), and tin phosphide (Sn4P3). We initially describe the known facts about the sodiation sequence in metallic Sn, emphasizing the latest findings on the reactions leading up to the final equilibrium Na15Sn4 intermetallic. Researchers contend that the expected equilibrium (phase diagram) series of phase transitions does not occur in this system. Instead, sodiation and desodiation progress through a series of metastable crystalline and amorphous structures. We also summarize recent modeling insights on how these phase transitions significantly alter the alloy's mechanical properties, evolving the bonding and neighboring configurations from "Sn-like" to "Na-like". Next, we explore the sodiation reactions in SnO2, noting that substantial experimental research exists focusing on synthesizing and testing tin oxide-based nanocomposites, but the precise sodiation sequence is only beginning to be understood. Unlike Sn and its alloys, where theoretical capacities are nearly achieved initially in cycles, SnO2 fails to reach the potential 1398 mAh g(-1) achievable with fully reversible conversion and alloying reactions. Recent studies show that contrary to general beliefs, it is the incomplete Sn to Na15Sn4 alloying reaction that limits the electrode's capacity. We detail how the oxide conversion reaction passes through an intermediate SnO phase, and its reversibility in a half-cell greatly depends on the final anodic voltage. We then discuss the sodiation of tin sulfide and tin phosphide phases, presenting emerging microstructural evidence that may clarify why both materials do not reach their promising theoretical capacities under standard electrode testing. Lastly, we offer a comprehensive comparison of the capacity (cycling and rate) performance for various Sn-based anode materials, suggesting that there may be an ideal microstructural architecture.

To address the issue of significant volume changes and low electronic conductivity in earth-abundant ilmenite for rechargeable Na-ion batteries (SIBs), an anode design featuring FeTiO3 nanoparticles embedded in carbon nanotubes (FTO⊂CNTs) has been developed. This is achieved by creating a TiO2 shell around metal-organic framework (Fe-MOF) nanorods through sol-gel deposition, followed by solid-state annealing of the core-shell Fe-MOF@TiO2 structures. These precisely structured FTO⊂CNTs offer several advantages, including a hollow interior, compact electroactive units, a flexible conductive carbon framework, and a stable solid electrolyte interface (SEI) throughout cycles. The FTO⊂CNT electrodes exhibit excellent cycle stability (358.8 mA h g^-1 after 200 cycles at 100 mA g^-1) and impressive rate capability (201.8 mA h g^-1 at 5000 mA g^-1), with a high Coulombic efficiency of approximately 99%. Furthermore, when paired with a Na3V2(PO4)3 cathode to form full SIBs, the FTO⊂CNT//Na3V2(PO4)3 assemblies demonstrate exceptional rate capability and extended cycle life.

A high-performance graphite-Si composite anode for Li-ion batteries was developed, with Si nanoparticles (NPs) attached to graphite microparticles, using a polymer blend of poly(diallyl dimethyl-ammonium chloride) and poly(sodium 4-styrenesulfonate). This polymer blend ensured uniform distribution of Si NPs during synthesis and acted as a robust artificial solid-electrolyte interphase, significantly improving the cycle stability and rate performance of the composite electrode. The electrode demonstrated a specific capacity of 450 mA h g(-1), with 96% capacity retention at a 10 C-rate and 95% retention after 200 cycles, while maintaining the same electrode expansion behavior as a pristine graphite electrode.

Sodium-ion batteries hold great promise for large-scale energy storage applications due to the plentiful supply and affordability of sodium. Nonetheless, the progress and commercialization of sodium-ion batteries are contingent on employing high-capacity electrode materials. SnO2, among various metal oxides, boasts a high theoretical specific capacity for sodium-ion batteries. However, its practical application is hampered by significant volume expansion and poor electrical conductivity, which prevent it from achieving the theoretical capacity. While various nanostructured designs like SnO2 nanocomposites have been explored, the impact of other cell components such as electrolyte and binder on the specific capacity and cycling stability remains unexplored. This study examines the combined effects of electrolyte and binder on enhancing the performance of SnO2 supported by an intertwined network of reduced graphene oxide and partially open multiwalled carbon nanotube hybrid as an anode in a sodium-ion battery. Our findings reveal that using sodium carboxyl methyl cellulose with ethylene carbonate/diethyl carbonate as the electrolyte yields a high specific capacity of 688 mAh g–1 and excellent cycling stability over 500 cycles. This represents a 56% improvement in specific capacity compared to using poly(vinylidene fluoride) binder and propylene carbonate as the electrolyte. This study contributes to a deeper understanding of the synergistic interaction between electrolyte and binder, facilitating the development of metal-oxide-based electrode materials for advancing sodium-ion battery commercialization.

A straightforward one-step thermal pyrolysis process has been devised to create a carbon membrane derived from a natural leaf. This carbonized leaf membrane features anisotropic surfaces and an internal hierarchical porosity, achieving a notable specific capacity of 360 mAh/g and an initial Coulombic efficiency of 74.8% when used as a binder-free, current-collector-free anode in rechargeable sodium ion batteries. Additionally, by merely stacking and carbonizing leaves, large-area carbon membranes can be produced with low contact resistance, offering a promising approach for the large-scale advancement of sodium-ion batteries.

Bismuth (Bi) as a two-dimensional (2D) material has a significant interlayer spacing along the c-axis (0.395 nm), offering ample active sites for sodium ions and ensuring high sodium ion storage efficiency. Nonetheless, its limited electrical conductivity and poor cycling durability hinder its practical usage. In this study, a nitrogen-doped carbon-coated bismuth microsphere (Bi@NC) was synthesized. Thanks to the distinct Bi crystals and the nitrogen-doped carbon coating, the Bi@NC anode demonstrated excellent cycling stability and enhanced rate capability. Furthermore, when the Bi@NC anode was paired with a Na₃V₂(PO₄)₃@C cathode to form a complete battery, it achieved an impressive sodium storage performance (57 mA h g⁻¹ after 2000 cycles at 1.0 A g⁻¹).

Sodium-ion batteries are currently viewed as a cost-effective alternative to lithium-ion technologies for large-scale energy storage, though safety remains a significant concern for their practical use. This study introduces a safer sodium-ion battery by utilizing a nonflammable phosphate electrolyte, specifically trimethyl phosphate (TMP), in combination with a NaNi0.35Mn0.35Fe0.3O2 cathode and a Sb-based alloy anode. The TMP electrolyte's physical and electrochemical properties are assessed through tests involving ignition, ionic conductivity, cyclic voltammetry, and charge-discharge assessments. The findings indicate that the TMP electrolyte with an FEC additive is entirely nonflammable and possesses a broad electrochemical window (0–4.5 V vs. Na/Na+), allowing the Sb-based anode and NaNi0.35Mn0.35Fe0.3O2 cathode to maintain high reversible capacity and cycling stability, akin to those in carbonate electrolytes. Based on these observations, a nonflammable sodium-ion battery is developed using the Sb anode, NaNi0.35Mn0.35Fe0.3O2 cathode, and TMP with 10 vol% FEC electrolyte. This configuration performs effectively with significant capacity and cyclability, indicating promising potential for creating safer sodium-ion batteries suited for large-scale energy storage applications.

Structural phase transitions offer a means to modify material characteristics without introducing additional elements, making them highly valuable for technological applications. This study found that the hexagonal SnS2 phase can convert into an orthorhombic SnS phase following annealing in an argon atmosphere. This transformed SnS displays superior sodium-ion storage capabilities compared to SnS2, due to its advantageous structure. We present the initial report on a SnS@graphene architecture designed for use as a sodium-ion battery anode, constructed from two-dimensional SnS and graphene nanosheets as complementary components. The developed SnS@graphene hybrid nanostructured composite delivers a specific capacity of 940 mAh g(-1) and an impressive rate capability of 492 and 308 mAh g(-1) after 250 cycles at current densities of 810 and 7290 mA g(-1), respectively. This performance surpasses that of most known anode materials for Na-ion batteries. Through combined analysis using ex situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and ex situ X-ray diffraction, we explore the formation mechanism of SnS@graphene and the synergistic Na-storage reactions in the anode. During sodiation, SnS undergoes a two-structural-phase transformation (orthorhombic-SnS to cubic-Sn, then to orthorhombic-Na3.75Sn), whereas SnS2 undergoes a three-phase transformation (hexagonal-SnS2 to tetragonal-Sn, then to orthorhombic-Na3.75Sn). The reduced structural changes in SnS during conversion are likely to contribute to its structural integrity and cycling stability in sodium-ion battery operations. These findings highlight the unique features of the SnS@graphene architecture, making it suitable for high-performance energy storage applications.

Sodium-ion batteries are considered highly promising for large-scale energy storage applications, beyond the capabilities of lithium-ion batteries. However, their success depends on discovering new anode materials, as existing anodes like graphite and silicon used in lithium-ion batteries do not perform well for sodium-ion systems. We have developed novel SnS/C nanocomposites using a top-down method to serve as anode materials for sodium-ion batteries. These nanocomposites exhibit significantly enhanced electrochemical performance compared to bare SnS, particularly in terms of cycling stability and rate capabilities. The SnS/C nanocomposites demonstrate excellent capacity retention across different current rates and deliver capacities up to 400 mA h g−1 even at a high current density of 800 mA g−1 (2C). To investigate the reaction mechanism of these SnS/C nanocomposites, we conducted ex situ transmission electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, and operando X-ray absorption near-edge structure studies.

As sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are increasingly utilized, the development of cost-effective anode materials, such as metal oxides for Na-ion storage, is becoming a highly appealing research area. The larger ionic radius of Na compared to Li results in most metal oxide electrode materials underperforming in SIBs relative to Li-ion batteries. In this study, iron oxide was used to illustrate the concept that designing an amorphous structure can significantly enhance the Na-ion storage capability of a metal oxide. Amorphous Fe2O3/graphene composite nanosheets (Fe2O3@GNS) were prepared via an uncomplicated method as potential SIB anodes. It was found that amorphous Fe2O3 nanoparticles, averaging 5 nm in diameter, were uniformly distributed on the surface of graphene nanosheets through strong C-O-Fe oxygen-bridge bonds. Compared to crystalline Fe2O3, the amorphous Fe2O3@GNS demonstrated superior sodium storage characteristics, including greater electrochemical activity, a high initial Coulombic efficiency of 81.2%, and excellent rate performance. At a current density of 100 mA/g, the amorphous Fe2O3@GNS composites achieved a specific capacity of 440 mAh/g, significantly surpassing the capacity of 284 mAh/g observed in crystalline Fe2O3. Even at a high current density of 2 A/g, the amorphous Fe2O3@GNS composites maintained a specific capacity of 219 mAh/g. The outstanding electrochemical performance is attributed to the amorphous Fe2O3 structures and the strong interfacial interaction with GNS, which enhance the number of electrochemical active sites, provide more pathways for sodium ion transport, facilitate electron transfer, and effectively mitigate volume changes during sodiation and desodiation processes. This approach to designing amorphous iron oxide anodes for SIBs could also aid in the development of various other amorphous metal oxide nanostructures, enhancing their Na-ion storage performance.

The solid-electrolyte interface (SEI) film in sodium-ion batteries plays a crucial role in capacity degradation and cycling stability, yet research on its formation remains limited and not well understood. This study explores the reduction mechanisms of ethylene carbonate (EC), propylene carbonate (PC), vinylene carbonate (VC), ethylene sulfite (ES), 1,3-propylene sulfite (PS), and fluorinated ethylene carbonate (FEC) using density functional theory (DFT). The study calculates reaction activation energies, Gibbs free energies, enthalpies, and transition state structures. Findings show that additives like VC, ES, and PS in the electrolyte are more prone to forming organic components in the anode SEI film through one-electron reduction. The hierarchy of one-electron reduction to form organic SEI components is VC>PC>EC; for two-electron reduction resulting in the inorganic Na2 CO3 component, the sequence is EC>PC>VC. The two-electron reduction of sulfites ES and PS to form inorganic Na2 SO3 is more challenging than the reduction of carbonate esters. Furthermore, it is suggested that both one- and two-electron reductive pathways for FEC are more likely to generate inorganic NaF components.

To advance lithium and sodium ion battery technologies, it is essential to comprehend how the chemical structures influence the properties of the various components. Operando structural studies are among the most insightful methods for understanding battery functionality; however, isolating the contributions of the individual components of a battery stack (such as electrodes, current collectors, electrolytes, and binders) and focusing on specific materials remains challenging. We have employed operando X-ray diffraction computed tomography (XRD-CT) to investigate specific components within a largely unaltered operating cell, enabling us to extract detailed, spatially resolved structural information for both crystalline and amorphous phases during cycling, using Rietveld and pair distribution function (PDF) methods. We demonstrate this technique by providing the first comprehensive structural analysis of sodium cycling within a phosphorus anode, uncovering surprisingly distinct mechanisms for sodiation and desodiation in this promising, high-capacity anode system.

All-solid-state sodium-ion batteries (AS3iBs) are in high demand for stationary energy storage systems because of their enhanced safety and stability across a broad temperature spectrum. Hard carbon (HC), which is cost-effective, displays low redox potential and high capacity, and is crucial for the development of practical large-scale sodium-ion batteries. Nevertheless, the energy density of batteries using this anode material is constrained by its low initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE). This paper explores two methods: i) additional pyrolysis, and ii) presodiation through the thermal decomposition of NaBH4, to enhance the ICE of pristine HC. Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and electrochemical analysis reveal that thermal treatment increases the Csp2 content in the HC structure, while presodiation introduces sodium to occupy inherent irreversible sites. As a result, presodiated HC achieves an exceptional ICE (>99%) compared to thermally treated (90%) or pristine HC (83%) in half-cell configurations. Notably, an AS3iB using presodiated HC as the anode and NaCrO2 as the cathode demonstrates a high ICE of 92% and an initial discharge energy density of 294 Wh kgcathode−1.

Devices with high gravimetric and volumetric energy densities are increasingly sought after due to the swift advancement of electric vehicles and portable and wearable electronics. Electrospinning emerges as a potential method to create freestanding electrodes that boast elevated energy densities in both gravimetric and volumetric terms. Yet, the energy density of conventional electrospun electrodes is often limited by the minimal mass loading of active materials, typically around 20%-30 wt%. In this study, a biomimetic approach inspired by the adhesive properties of spider webs is introduced to develop a high-performance anode that simultaneously enhances both energy densities. By employing electrospinning followed by thermal treatment, freestanding carbon nanofiber (CNF) membranes with more than 50 wt% bismuth content were created. These membranes feature a CNF network that closely integrates with active bismuth clusters, offering robust mechanical protection and efficient charge transport pathways, which are challenging to achieve together. As an anode for lithium-ion batteries, the composite membrane provides a significant reversible capacity of 483 mA h g-1 at 100 mA g-1 after 200 cycles, along with an impressive rate performance of 242 mA h g-1 at 1 A g-1. Similarly, when applied to sodium-ion batteries, it delivers a high reversible specific capacity of 346 mA h g-1 and excellent cycling performance of 186 mA h g-1 at 50 mA g-1 after 100 cycles. This study presents a straightforward, cost-effective, and environmentally benign method for creating freestanding, binder-free composite electrodes with high active material loading applicable in both LIBs and SIBs.

Hard carbon (HC) presents a promising opportunity as a viable commercial anode material for both lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). Nevertheless, the existing battery performance evaluation techniques, which are typically based on...

Two-dimensional (2D) molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) has garnered significant attention for various uses, including catalysts, energy storage, and electronics. However, achieving large-scale exfoliation of 2D materials remains a technical obstacle to practical applications. We introduce a simple liquid-phase exfoliation technique that enhances the exfoliation efficiency of single-layer MoS2 sheets in 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP) with the aid of sodium hydroxide (NaOH). The concentration of exfoliated MoS2 nanosheets was significantly increased compared to conventional liquid-phase exfoliation methods using NMP solvent. We demonstrate the stable operation of sodium-ion batteries utilizing the exfoliated MoS2 and MoS2-rGO composites as anode materials.

The incorporation of oxygen vacancies (OVs) in sodium ion batteries (SIBs) is anticipated to improve their performance, although it has been infrequently documented. Using MoO(3-x) nanosheet anodes as an example, we illustrate for the first time the positive impact of OVs on SIB performance. Additionally, performance under deep-discharge conditions is further enhanced by the application of an ultrathin Al2O3 coating. Various measurements reveal that OVs contribute to increased electrical conductivity and enhanced Na-ion diffusion coefficient, while the ultrathin coating effectively minimizes cycling-induced solid-electrolyte interphase. The coated nanosheets displayed high reversible capacity and excellent rate capability, with capacities of 283.9 mAh g(-1) at 50 mA g(-1) and 179.3 mAh g(-1) at 1 A g(-1) after 100 cycles. This study not only encourages future research on the role of OVs in sodium energy storage but also suggests new avenues for devising strategies to utilize defects in other energy storage systems.

Heterostructure engineering is a highly promising approach for enhancing the slow kinetics of sodium ion battery (SIB) anodes. In this study, we conduct a comprehensive analysis of how different heterostructure interfaces of discharge products (Na2O, Na2S, Na2Se) affect rate performance. First-principles calculations demonstrate that the Na2S/Na2Se interface has the lowest diffusion energy barrier for Na (0.39 eV) among the three interface structures (Na2O/Na2S, Na2O/Na2Se, and Na2S/Na2Se). This is due to its minimal interface deformation and similar electronegativity and lattice constant. Experimentally, it is confirmed that a metal sulfide/metal selenide (SnS/SnSe2) hierarchical anode delivers excellent rate performance, achieving a normalized capacity of 45.6% at 10 A g-1 compared to 0.1 A g-1. This design strategy is beneficial for developing high-rate performance anodes for advanced battery systems.

Antimony/carbon (Sb@C) microspheres are synthesized initially using a straightforward self-catalyzing solvothermal technique to explore their potential as anode materials in sodium-ion batteries. Structural and morphological analyses indicate that the Sb@C microspheres consist of Sb nanoparticles, approximately 20 nm in size, uniformly encapsulated within a carbon matrix. The self-catalyzing solvothermal process is confirmed through comparative experiments employing various raw materials. These synthesized Sb@C microspheres display excellent sodium storage capabilities, achieving a reversible capacity of 640 mAh g(-1), superior rate performance, and a long-term cycling stability with a 92.3% capacity retention over 300 cycles. This performance highlights their promise as anode materials for sodium-ion batteries.

O3-type Na-based layered transition metal oxides are promising candidates for use as cathodes in sodium-ion batteries. However, their application is limited by rapid capacity degradation and poor rate performance, often due to significant structural changes and interfacial decay. This research presents a NaPO3 surface-modified O3-type layered NaNi1/3Fe1/3Mn1/3O2 cathode, which offers enhanced high-voltage stability. This improvement is achieved by employing a protecting layer that defends against acid corrosion, formed through a solid-gas reaction between cathode particles and gaseous P2O5. The NaPO3 nanolayer stabilizes the crystal structure by curbing parasitic surface reactions and elevates the average voltage. The surface-modified cathode exhibits superior cyclic stability, retaining 80.1% of its capacity compared to 63.6% after 150 cycles at 1 C within a broad voltage range of 2.0 V-4.2 V (vs Na+/Na). Additionally, the intrinsic ionic conduction of NaPO3 contributes to the enhanced rate capability of the surface-modified cathode, delivering 103 mAh g-1 against 60 mAh g-1 at 10 C. The findings point to a viable approach for developing sodium-ion battery technology with high rate capabilities and robust longevity.

The incorporation of heteroatoms can successfully prevent phase transitions in layered sodium-ion battery cathodes; however, the behavior of these heteroatoms under operating conditions remains incompletely understood at the atomic level. In this study, density functional theory calculations are coupled with experiments to investigate how Mg dopants mitigate such transitions and their underlying mechanisms during operation in P2-Na0.67Ni0.33Mn0.67O2. Following Na extraction, voids may induce some Mg dopants to migrate from transition metal (TM) layers into the Na layers. When the Mg concentration in the TM layer is relatively high, multiple Mg ions are likely to diffuse collectively, eventually forming Mg-rich areas, termed Mg segregation, separate from Ni vacancies. This Mg segregation, prompted by the void-pump effect, effectively curbs the P2-O2 phase transition due to the stronger Mg-O electrostatic attraction. This attraction strengthens the cohesion between adjacent oxygen layers, thereby reducing crack propagation by minimizing lattice volume changes during high-voltage cycling. Our research provides fundamental insights into heteroatom mitigation behavior in layered cathodes at an atomic scale, contributing to advancements in next-generation energy storage technologies.

Sodium (Na) ion batteries (SIBs) offer a cost-effective solution for energy storage, yet they are limited by inadequate energy density. Incorporating oxygen (O) redox into the Na-storage cathode design is currently viewed as an effective strategy for increasing capacity and addressing the energy density challenge. The main challenges lie in overcoming the irreversible electrochemical behavior associated with O release. Additionally, the O redox chemistry and its subsequent structural changes are still not fully understood. This paper examines the O redox mechanism within Na-storage transition metal oxides. We review the challenges of reaction irreversibility and structural degradation using advanced characterization methods. Furthermore, we propose strategies to potentially improve the electrochemical performance of O redox and discuss future research directions for developing viable O redox cathode materials.

The P2-type layered oxide Na2/3Ni1/3Mn2/3O2 is considered a strong contender for use in sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). However, it faces challenges from a pronounced P2–O2 phase transition during high voltage charging, which leads to significant volume changes and poor cycling stability. In this study, a Quasi-zero strain P2-Na0.75Li0.15Mg0.05Ni0.1Mn0.7O2 cathode is developed, characterized by an absence of the P2–O2 transition and a mere 0.49% volume change, resulting in excellent cycling performance (83.9% capacity retention over 500 cycles at 5 C). The minimal volume strain is attributed to two factors: (1) Mg2+ ions in the Na layer function as "pillars" that stabilize the crystal structure during sodium removal, minimizing structural alterations at high voltages. (2) Li+ ions integrate into the transition metal (TM) layer, reducing electron localization in a highly desodiated state and effectively stabilizing coordination of oxygen atoms, which hinders the P2–O2 transition. This research offers new insights into the role of Li and Mg in stabilizing P2-type cathode structures and presents an efficient strategy for creating SIB cathode materials with extremely low bulk strain.

Prussian blue is gaining attention as a potential candidate for sodium-ion battery cathodes because of its open frameworks and high working potential. However, its crystal structure contains interstitial water and it has poor electronic conductivity, which impair its performance in practical sodium-ion batteries. This study utilized acid-assisted ball milling synthesis as a versatile approach to produce surface-modified Prussian blue. Using (CH3COO)2Fe as the starting material, the ball milling synthesis resulted in Prussian blue modified with carboxyl groups on its surface, leading to reduced interstitial water content and improved electrochemical cycling performance. Additionally, this synthesis method increased the surface area of Prussian blue, thereby enhancing its electrochemical rate performance. When employed as a cathode in sodium-ion batteries, the synthesized Prussian blue demonstrated a specific capacity of 145.3 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C and 113.7 mAh g−1 at 1 C, retaining 54.5% of its initial capacity after 1000 cycles at 1 C (1 C = 170 mA g−1). Furthermore, a solid-state sodium-ion battery was assembled using the synthesized Prussian blue as the cathode and Na metal as the anode, achieving a specific capacity of 128.7 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C. This study presents an effective strategy to address the limitations of Prussian blue for commercial applications.

Layered P2-type oxides incorporating Fe and Mn are highly regarded as cathode materials for sodium ion batteries (SIBs) due to their cost-effective metal components and high specific capacity. Despite their potential, they typically experience rapid capacity degradation and undergo complex phase changes. This research focuses on adjusting the crystal structure and boosting the electrochemical properties of Na0.67Mn0.5Fe0.5O2 through Al doping into Mn or Fe positions, shedding light on Al's contributions to improving rate capability and cycling performance. (1) Replacing Mn or Fe with Al reduces the lattice parameters a and c, but increases d spacing and extends Na-O bonds, ultimately enhancing Na+ diffusion and rate capability, particularly noted in Na0.67Mn0.5Fe0.47Al0.03O2. (2) Al doping diminishes the TMO2 layer thickness and reinforces TM-O/O-O bonding, which boosts the stability of the layered structure and maintains capacity. (3) Al helps minimize Mn3+ related Jahn-Teller distortion, thus reducing irreversible phase transitions. (4) Incorporating Al also lessens lattice volume changes and structural strain, further stabilizing the layered structure and enhancing cycling performance, notably when Al replaces Fe. These detailed findings on Al substitution may also assist in designing high-performance cathode materials for SIBs via strategic lattice doping.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have promising potential for large-scale energy storage applications. Among them, P2-type manganese-based layered oxides are particularly noteworthy due to their high theoretical capacity, cost-effectiveness, and environmental friendliness. Nonetheless, their susceptibility to water and limited cycling stability pose significant challenges, with the mechanisms behind these issues still not fully understood. In this study, copper is used as a substitute to mitigate the Jahn-Teller effect of Mn3+ and to modify the lattice structure. The study thoroughly examines water sensitivity and the charge compensation mechanism. Findings reveal that the electrode's water sensitivity is linked to the Na+/vacancy ordering in the Na interlayers, as water molecules tend to infiltrate the charged state electrodes more readily, though water absorption does not escalate with Na+ extraction. Additionally, Mn2+ develops on the electrode surface during the initial discharge process, while Mn3+ and Mn4+ primarily undergo redox reactions within the bulk. The substitution of Cu in the transition metal layer influences the Na+/vacancy arrangement and reduces Mn2+ formation on the Na0.7Mn0.9Cu0.1O2 electrode, thereby enhancing air stability and improving storage properties.

The phase transition and lattice parameter changes characteristic of the O3 structure frequently occur in O3-type sodium ion battery (SIB) cathodes, potentially increasing voltage hysteresis and reducing energy efficiency. Considering the impact of cost on the large-scale adoption of SIBs for energy storage, this study examines the Co/Ni-free compound NaxCu0.18Fe0.3Mn0.52O2 (with x values of 0.8, 0.85, and 0.9) and introduces an effective method to minimize voltage hysteresis. It was discovered that with a Na content of 0.8, the compound achieved a peak energy efficiency of 95.4% post-activation (measured between 2.5-4.0 V at 50 mA g-1 by the 50th cycle), alongside commendable capacity retention (approximately 0.056% decay per cycle). Further analyses indicate that Na0.8Cu0.18Fe0.3Mn0.52O2 undergoes a smooth O3-P3 phase transition without experiencing changes in the O3 phase lattice parameters. The essential factor is the formation of an O3/P3 composite within the material. This study presents a straightforward approach for designing O3-type cathodes with high energy efficiency and could inspire efforts to discover layered oxides with a higher critical Na content in O3/P3 phases through compositional modifications.

Layered O3-type sodium oxides (NaMO2, where M is a transition metal) typically undergo an O3-P3 phase transition at a redox voltage around 3 V (vs. Na+/Na) during sodium extraction and insertion. As a result, nearly 50% of their total capacity occurs at this low voltage, leading to insufficient energy density for sodium-ion battery (NIB) cathodes. Developing high-voltage O3-type cathodes is challenging because enhancing the phase-transition voltage through structural modulation is difficult. A novel O3-type sodium insertion material, Na0.7 Ni0.35 Sn0.65 O2, has been designed for NIBs. This material shows the highest redox potential of 3.7 V (vs. Na+/Na) among reported O3-type materials utilizing the Ni2+/Ni3+ couple. This is achieved through increased Ni-O bond ionicity by reduced orbital overlap between transition metals and oxygen in the MO2 slabs. The study provides an orbital-level insight into the operating potentials of nominal redox couples for O3-NaMO2 cathodes, offering a strategy to enhance electrode performance.

Sodium-ion batteries (SiB) are increasingly seen as a viable alternative to the existing Lithium-ion batteries (LiBs). Nonetheless, SiBs represent an emerging technology that is still in the early phases of development, accompanied by a vast range of...

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) hold potential for developing economical and safe solutions to meet significant energy storage needs. In this study, we have created manganese oxide (α-MnO2) nanorods for SIB applications. We conduct a detailed analysis of the crystal structure of the metal oxide cathode, vital for effective energy storage. Sodium intercalation into the α-MnO2 matrix is examined through theoretical density functional theory (DFT) studies, which reveal that Na ions exhibit easy diffusion kinetics through the MnO2 lattice, with a promisingly low diffusion barrier of 0.21 eV. When used as a cathode material in SIBs, MnO2 demonstrated a moderate capacity of 109 mAh·g–1 at a C/20 current rate and excellent cycle life retention of 58.6% after 800 cycles in NaPF6/EC+DMC (5% FEC) electrolyte. It achieved a much higher capacity of 181 mAh·g–1 at a C/20 current rate in NaClO4/PC (5% FEC) electrolyte, although it experienced rapid capacity decline, with 11.5% loss after 800 cycles. Our results suggest that the high crystallinity and hierarchical nanorod structure of MnO2 contribute to enhanced cycling performance, coupled with rapid and consistent charge-discharge characteristics.

Layered manganese-based cathode materials are highly valued for their elevated specific capacities in sodium ion batteries. Nonetheless, the Jahn-Teller effect and unavoidable phase transitions adversely affect their cycling stability and rate capability. In this study, we present a P2-type manganese oxide nanoplate cathode material enhanced by Mo-substitution, featuring an oriented stacking structure and exposed {010} active facets. This manganese oxide nanoplate cathode demonstrates impressive capacity retention of 87.8% after 1200 cycles at 10C (2000 mA g-1). Its specific power density reaches up to 530 W Kg-1, showing a specific discharge capacity of 143.9 mA h g-1 at 1C and 89.6% capacity retention over 100 cycles. These outstanding electrochemical performances are attributed to effective chemical modification and the distinct structural characteristics of the manganese oxide nanoplate. Mo-modification enlarges the lattice space and average oxidation state of the manganese oxide cathode, facilitating Na+ diffusion, which mitigates the Jahn-Teller effect and enhances structural stability for an extended cycling life. The multilayer oriented stacking nanoplate structure with exposed {010} active facets provides additional surface active sites and shortens the Na+ diffusion path, improving rate capability.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are among the most promising alternatives anticipated to complement lithium-ion batteries and broaden the battery market. Nonetheless, developing cathode materials with robust high-rate performance and lengthy cycle stability for SIBs remains a significant challenge. An effective method to improve rate and cycling performance is demonstrated by incorporating an ordered bicontinuous porous structure into the cathode materials of SIBs. Prussian blue analogues (PBAs) are chosen due to their potential as leading SIB cathode materials. The existence of three-dimensional continuous channels facilitates rapid Na+ ion diffusion, and the inherent mechanical stability of the bicontinuous architecture results in PBAs with superior rate capability (80 mAh g−1 at 2.5 A g−1) and an exceptionally long cycling life (over 3000 cycles at 0.5 A g−1), achieving peak performance among PBA-based cathode materials. This research paves a new path for enhancing ion diffusion kinetics in electrode materials for rechargeable batteries and offers a novel approach to addressing the issue of electrode failure caused by high-stress concentration during ion storage.

In layered oxide cathodes of lithium-ion batteries, cation migration frequently occurs due to the similar ionic radii of lithium and transition metals (TMs). Despite the significant difference in ionic radii between sodium and TMs, TMs in layered cathodes of sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) can still migrate to the sodium layer, causing considerable electrochemical degradation. To investigate the cause of TM migration in layered SIB cathodes, we selected NaCrO2, a typical layered cathode prone to severe TM migration, as our model material. We discovered that TM migration originates from random desodiation and the subsequent formation of a sodium-free layer at high charge potential. To tackle this problem, we developed a Ru/Ti co-doping strategy. In this approach, the actively doped Ru is oxidized initially to induce selective desodiation, while the doped inactive Ti acts as a pillar to prevent complete desodiation in the Ru-containing TM layers. This strategy suppresses the formation of sodium-free layers and consequently enhances electrochemical performance.

As a potential cathode material for sodium-ion batteries, P2-type Na2/3Ni1/3Mn2/3O2 (NNMO) offers a theoretically high capacity and operating voltage, which supports high energy storage density. However, it faces challenges with poor cycling stability, primarily due to the undesirable P2-O2 phase transition. To address this, Fe3+ ions are electrochemically introduced into the NNMO lattice, creating Na2/3Ni1/3Mn2/3-xFexO2 (x = 0, 1/24, 1/12, 1/8, 1/6) to effectively stabilize the P2-type crystal structure. In these Fe-doped materials, both Ni2+/Ni4+ and Fe3+/Fe4+ redox pairs actively participate in reactions, and the P2-O2 phase transition is successfully restrained during cycling, as confirmed by ex situ X-ray diffraction. Consequently, the optimized Na2/3Ni1/3Mn7/12Fe1/12O2 (1/12-NNMF) exhibits excellent cycling stability with a capacity fading rate of 0.05% per cycle over 300 cycles at 5 C. In addition, the 1/12-NNMF shows outstanding rate capabilities (65 mA h g-1 at 25 C) and remarkable low-temperature performance (retaining 94% capacity at -25 °C after 80 cycles) due to improved Na diffusion resulting from Fe doping, as indicated by electrode kinetics studies. Furthermore, the 1/12-NNMF demonstrates impressive sodium-ion full-cell performance when paired with an LS-Sb@G anode, suggesting potential for practical application.

As the demand for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) grows, recycling used LIBs becomes a necessity from environmental, economic, and health perspectives. This study explores the leaching behavior of Ni, Mn, Co, Al, and Cu from treated cathode active materials extracted from commercial LIBs used in hybrid electric vehicles, using ammoniacal leaching agents like ammonia, ammonium carbonate, and ammonium sulfite. Ammonium sulfite is employed as a reductant to improve leaching kinetics, especially for Ni and Co in ammoniacal conditions. Ammonium carbonate serves as a pH buffer to stabilize the leaching solution's pH. Complete leaching of Co and Cu is achieved, whereas Mn and Al remain largely unleached, and Ni demonstrates moderate leaching efficiency. Analysis confirms that the cathode active materials comprise LiMn2O4, LiCoxMnyNizO2, Al2O3, and carbon, while the leach residue contains LiNixMnyCozO2, LiMn2O4, Al2O3, MnCO3, and Mn oxides. Ammoniacal leaching for Co recovery is potentially more advantageous than traditional acid leaching by reducing the costs associated with sodium hydroxide for pH adjustment and eliminating the need for Mn and Al separation steps.

The winners of the 2019 Nobel Prize in Chemistry made significant contributions to the development of the modern lithium-ion battery. Professor Arumugam Manthiram reflects on the progress of cathode chemistry, focusing on the three primary types of oxide cathode materials, with an emphasis on the essential solid-state chemistry underlying these advancements. Lithium-ion batteries have powered the evolution of portable electronics for about thirty years and are now paving the way for vehicle electrification and entering the utility sector. The rise and predominance of lithium-ion batteries are attributed to their superior energy density relative to other rechargeable battery systems, achieved through the innovation and creation of high-energy density electrode materials. Fundamental scientific research, especially in solid-state chemistry and physics, played a pivotal role in this pursuit, particularly in the 1970s and 1980s. The Nobel Prize in Chemistry awarded in 2019 for the development of lithium-ion batteries serves as a timely opportunity to revisit the advances in cathode chemistry that made contemporary lithium-ion technology possible. This review article reflects on how foundational research has supported the discovery, optimization, and methodical design of the three principal categories of oxide cathodes for lithium-ion batteries and provides a personal view on the future of this critical field.

Oxygen vacancies (OV), inherent defects in transition metal (TM) oxides, significantly influence the physicochemical characteristics of these materials. TM oxides are prevalent in lithium-ion battery (LIB) cathodes; however, the impact of OVs within this context remains poorly understood. In this study, we examine the behavior of OVs in a single-crystal LIB cathode amid non-equilibrium charging and discharging states. Our research reveals that microcracks in the single crystal form due to OV condensation along specific crystallographic directions, driven by the persistent migration of OVs and TM ions. Furthermore, appreciating the effects of OVs' presence and movement in metal oxides aids in clarifying prevalent mechanisms of capacity degradation in LIBs, offering fresh perspectives for novel electrochemical applications.

We present a novel Ge-based electrode design featuring three-dimensional (3-D) spherical microflowers composed of crystalline nanorod networks on robust one-dimensional (1-D) nanostems, which are directly grown on a metallic current collector via simple thermal evaporation. The Ge nanorod networks self-replicated their tetrahedron structures, forming a diamond cubic lattice-like internal network. Following etching and carbon coating, the modified Ge nanostructures exhibit excellent electrical conductivity and resistance to gradual degradation, resulting in outstanding electrochemical performance as anode materials for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). They achieve a charge capacity retention of 96% after 100 cycles and a high specific capacity of 1360 mA h g^−1 at 1 C, along with high-rate capabilities with reversible capacities of 1080 and 850 mA h g^−1 at 5 and 10 C rates, respectively. This enhanced electrochemical performance is largely due to the rapid electron transport and effective strain accommodation provided by the carbon-infused Ge microflower-on-nanostem hybrid electrode.

A new method for extracting transition metals, recovering lithium, and regenerating cathode materials using co-extraction and co-precipitation techniques has been proposed. Manganese is extracted at 100%, cobalt at 99%, and nickel at 85%, isolated from lithium using D2EHPA in kerosene. Lithium is then retrieved from the raffinate as Li2CO3 with 99.2% purity through precipitation. The organic load phase is stripped with 0.5M H2SO4, enabling the direct regeneration of the cathode material LiNi1/3Co1/3Mn1/3O2 from the stripping solution by co-precipitation without separating the metals individually. The regenerated LiNi1/3Co1/3Mn1/3O2 has a microspherical shape, free from impurities, complies with China's production standards, and demonstrates excellent electrochemical performance. Additionally, a waste battery management model is presented to ensure material supply for recycling used batteries.

The diffusion times of lithium ions within the cathode of a lithium-ion battery have been examined at a spatial resolution of less than 100 nanometers. This ion movement into and out of electrodes is crucial for the functioning of lithium-ion batteries. Although this process has been extensively studied on a device level, there is a lack of detailed understanding at the nanoscale level within grain clusters, single grains, and defects. In this study, we explore the spatial variation of lithium-ion diffusion times in the battery-cathode material LiCoO_2 with a resolution of around 100 nm. This is achieved by utilizing an atomic force microscope to both redistribute lithium ions and measure the subsequent cathode deformation. The study identifies a correlation between diffusion and individual grains and grain boundaries, finding that the diffusion coefficient is higher for specific grain orientations and along single-grain boundaries. This insight contributes to a better understanding of the nanoscale mechanisms that underlie the operation of lithium-ion batteries.

Finding electrode materials with high volumetric capacity that can reversibly accommodate the large K+ ions remains a formidable task.
