These impressive results are attributed to the material's excellent conductivity, structural stability, and pseudocapacitive behavior. Moreover, the mechanism of sodium ion storage in NiSe2 is explored for the first time using in situ XRD and ex situ XRD techniques. These advantages position NiSe2 as a strong contender for use in rechargeable SIBs.

Developing electrode materials for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) that are cost-effective, durable, and capable of high rates is crucial. Nonetheless, fast charging and achieving high power density remain significant challenges for most SIB electrodes due to slow sodiation kinetics. In this study, uniform mesoporous NiS2 nanospheres are produced using a straightforward one-step method assisted by polyvinylpyrrolidone. By adjusting the voltage window, these mesoporous NiS2 nanospheres demonstrate outstanding electrochemical performance in SIBs, achieving a high reversible specific capacity of 692 mA h g⁻¹. The NiS2 anode also shows excellent high-rate capability (253 mA h g⁻¹ at 5 A g⁻¹) and sustainable cycling performance (maintaining a capacity of 319 mA h g⁻¹ even after 1000 cycles at 0.5 A g⁻¹). A predominant pseudocapacitance contribution is confirmed through kinetics analysis. Additionally, the amorphization and conversion reactions occurring during the electrochemical process of the mesoporous NiS2 nanospheres are examined using in situ X-ray diffraction. This remarkable electrochemical performance suggests that NiS2 has significant potential for next-generation large-scale energy storage solutions.

Using nanosecond pulses, liquid plasma provides a straightforward and effective approach to create a nanocomposite structure of Co3O4/CNTs from carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and Co3O4 nanoparticle clusters in deionized water. The key aspect of the composite's architecture is the uniform dispersion and anchoring of Co3O4 nanoparticle clusters within CNT networks, where Co3O4 ensures high electrochemical reactivity with sodium, while CNTs offer conductivity and structural stability to the anode. Our research demonstrates that the Co3O4/CNT nanocomposite consistently delivers a stable and high capacity of 403 mA h g(-1) at 50 mA g(-1) after 100 cycles, with sodium uptake/extraction validated through a reversible conversion reaction using ex situ techniques. The composite's rate capability is markedly enhanced, showing a reversible capacity of 212 mA h g(-1) at 1.6 A g(-1) and 190 mA h g(-1) at 3.2 A g(-1). Thanks to its simple synthesis method with excellent electrochemical performance, Co3O4/CNT nanocomposites show significant potential for use as anode materials in sodium-ion batteries.

We have developed an advanced sodium-based dual-ion battery (Na-DIB) by merging the benefits of dual-ion batteries (DIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). This system utilizes a PTCDA organic anode and an ionic liquid (IL) electrolyte. It demonstrates a top specific discharge capacity of 177 mAh g-1 at 0.5C and shows remarkable capacity retention, maintaining over 100% at 2C after 200 cycles. Impressively, even at a very high rate of 20C, the battery sustains a significant capacity of 60 mAh g-1 with a coulombic efficiency (CE) nearing 100%, and 94% capacity retention after 1000 cycles. Furthermore, the system's self-discharge rate is found to be exceptionally low at 0.18% h-1. Thus, this Na-DIB configuration stands out as a promising option for large-scale deployment.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have the potential to be utilized in grid-scale energy storage systems, particularly for managing extreme weather conditions. Nevertheless, SIBs capable of operating across a broad temperature range are scarcely documented. In this study, we introduce a wide-temperature SIB configuration featuring a carbon-coated Na4Fe3(PO4)2P2O7 (NFPP@C) cathode, a Bismuth (Bi) anode, and a diglyme-based electrolyte. We show that the Bi anode can directly store solvated Na+ ions via an alloying reaction without the need for a de-solvent phase. Additionally, the NFPP@C cathode demonstrates an elevated Na+ diffusion coefficient at reduced temperatures. Consequently, the Bi//NFPP@C battery displays excellent performance in low-temperature environments, maintaining 70.19% of its room-temperature capacity even at -70 °C. Thanks to the high boiling point of the electrolyte, the battery also functions effectively at elevated temperatures up to 100 °C. These promising outcomes may contribute to advancing the development of wide-temperature SIBs.

Ultrafine niobium oxide nanocrystals combined with reduced graphene oxide (Nb2O5 NCs/rGO) have been shown to be a promising anode material for sodium ion batteries, offering excellent rate performance and cycle durability. The material was prepared through controlled hydrolysis of niobium ethoxide, followed by a heat treatment at 450 °C under flowing forming gas. Transmission electron microscopy revealed that Nb2O5 nanocrystals, averaging 3 nm in size, were uniformly distributed on rGO sheets with void spaces among the Nb2O5 nanocrystals. This structure, featuring ultrafine Nb2O5 NCs anchored to a conductive rGO network, enhances charge transfer and buffers volume changes during the sodiation/desodiation process, while also increasing the active surface area for sodium ion storage, leading to superior performance in rate and cycle durability. Ex situ XPS analysis indicated that the sodium ion storage in Nb2O5 involves a Nb(5+)/Nb(4+) redox reaction, with the ultrafine Nb2O5 NCs providing additional surface area for this reaction to occur.

This research presents the first demonstration of MnO2's electrochemical activity as a conversion anode in sodium-ion batteries (NIBs). Ultrafine MnO2, with a mean crystal size of 4 nm, was produced via a porous silicon dioxide templated hydrothermal method, showing a high reversible sodiation capacity of 567 mA h g(-1). This contrasts with the minimal activity of larger 14 nm MnO2 nanocrystallite aggregates. The significantly improved sodiation activity of the ultrafine MnO2 is attributed to its smaller crystal size, which enhances Na ion diffusion, and its high surface energy due to extensive heterogeneous interfacial bonding with the surrounding SiO2. This ultrafine MnO2 anode delivers outstanding rate performance and cycle life, maintaining over 70% capacity retention after 500 cycles. In operando synchrotron X-ray absorption near-edge structural analysis reveals a mix of charge-storage mechanisms, including a conversion reaction between Mn(III) and Mn(II) oxides, Mn(III)-O1.5 + Na(+) + e(-) ↔ 1/2Na2O + Mn(II)-O, alongside non-Mn-centered redox reactions. This discovery indicates a novel approach to "activate" potential electrochemical electrode materials that seem inactive in bulk form.

Current lithium-ion batteries encounter issues related to the sustainability, cost, and availability of natural resources in their components. Sodium has emerged as a complementary energy storage material capable of offering effective volumetric energy density. In designing sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), hard carbon is used at the anode instead of graphite, owing to the required microdomain structure for storing sodium ions. Coal char serves as a cost-effective source of hard carbon, providing a valuable secondary use for the plentiful char component in coal. 

This study investigates flash pyrolysis as an innovative method for coal char synthesis intended for SIB anodes, utilizing local bituminous coal from Utah. During flash pyrolysis, char is heated rapidly in a drop-tube furnace at a rate of 1000 °C/s, contrasting with the conventional slow pyrolysis that heats char at 20 °C/min. Flash-pyrolyzed (FP) char shows a markedly different surface structure compared to slow-pyrolyzed (SP) char, with a larger d-spacing (FP d-spacing = 0.379 nm, SP d-spacing = 0.364 nm) and smaller closed micropore diameter (FP micropore = 1.52 nm, SP micropore = 1.91 nm), as determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS), respectively.

The SIB performance of FP and SP char is evaluated in both ether-based and ester-based electrolytes. FP char outperforms SP char as a SIB anode in both electrolyte types. Moreover, both char anodes demonstrate greater reversible capacity and superior initial coulombic efficiencies (ICE) in ether-based electrolytes as opposed to ester-based ones. With FP char combined with an ether-based electrolyte, a 10th cycle reversible capacity of 109.4 mAh/g is attained, in contrast to a SP char with an ester-based electrolyte showing a 10th cycle reversible capacity of 72.5 mAh/g, when both are cycled at 50 mA/g in sodium metal half-cells. FP ether cells also display an initial coulombic efficiency (ICE) of 64%, whereas SP ester cells show an ICE of only 52%. The superior electrochemical performance of the FP cells is attributed to differences in surface and bulk structure due to the rapid heating rate. The improved performance of char anodes in ether-based cells is likely due to the formation of a thinner solid-electrolyte interphase and/or enhanced sodiation resulting from the ether-based electrolyte.

Sodium ion batteries (SIBs) have gained renewed interest as an alternative to rechargeable lithium ion batteries, due to the low cost, plentiful sodium supply, and a storage mechanism akin to that of lithium ions. Among potential anode materials, VS4 stands out for SIBs because of its low cost and distinctive linear chain structure that provides viable sites for sodium storage. This study introduces the novel growth of VS4 on reduced graphene oxide (rGO) as an anode for SIBs. The VS4/rGO anode demonstrates impressive performance, delivering a reversible capacity of 362 mAh g(-1) at 100 mA g(-1) with a commendable rate performance. Furthermore, we examine the sodium storage behavior of VS4/rGO. Unlike most transition metal sulfides, the composite undergoes a three-step separation mechanism during sodiation (transitioning from VS4 to metallic V and Na2S, with an electrochemical process similar to Na-S batteries). The findings highlight the VS4/rGO composite as a promising candidate for rechargeable SIBs.

The urgent demand for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) that are intrinsically safe and have a long lifespan is crucial for large-scale energy storage solutions. Currently available SIBs often face challenges such as limited cycle life and safety concerns. In this study, we developed an all-phosphate sodium-ion battery (AP-SIB) featuring a Na3V2(PO4)3 cathode, NaTi2(PO4)3 anode, and a trimethyl phosphate (TMP) electrolyte that is nonflammable. This AP-SIB shows impressive attributes including high safety, excellent rate performance, and extremely long cycle life. Additionally, it possesses zero-strain properties due to the opposing volume changes of the phosphate cathode and anode during charge and discharge cycles, thus providing a safer and cycle-durable Na-ion technology suitable for electric storage applications.

Designing effective anode materials is challenging in the development of sodium ion batteries. Alloy anodes offer high gravimetric and volumetric capacities but typically experience short cycle life due to continuous and cumulative pulverization caused by significant volume changes during cycling. In this study, by using pure Sn and examining irreversible conversion combined with alloy reactions (SnO) and reversible conversion combined with alloy reactions (Sn4P3), we demonstrate that pulverization and aggregation in alloy anodes can be partially mitigated. A reversible conversion reaction combined with an alloy reaction can halt the accumulation of pulverization and aggregation during charge/discharge cycles. Among the three Sn-based anodes tested, the cycling stability follows the order of Sn4P3 > SnO > Sn. The superior performance of Sn4P3 arises from a reversible reaction, Sn4P3 + 9Na ↔ 4Sn + 3Na3P, which repairs cracks, damage, and aggregation in Sn particles, thereby halting pulverization. This repair mechanism mimics natural self-healing, allowing damage to heal automatically. We thus propose naming this mechanism self-healing, with the resultant anode termed as the self-healing anode. Employing self-healing strategies to construct electrode architectures is an innovative and appealing approach to enhance cycle life and achieve stable electrode materials.

Potassium-ion batteries (PIBs) present a compelling alternative to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) due to the plentiful supply and low cost of potassium. In this study, we explored Sn4P3/C composite as an innovative anode material for PIBs. This electrode achieved a reversible capacity of 384.8 mA h g-1 at 50 mA g-1 and exhibited an impressive rate capability of 221.9 mA h g-1, even at 1 A g-1. Its electrochemical performance surpasses all previously reported anode materials for PIBs. The Sn4P3/C electrode also demonstrated a discharge potential plateau of 0.1 V in PIBs, which is slightly higher than the 0.01 V observed in sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), and significantly above the metal plating potential. This reduces dendrite formation during cycling, making Sn4P3 a safe choice for anode material, especially in large-scale energy storage applications involving substantial amounts of electrode materials. Additionally, a potential reaction mechanism for the Sn4P3/C composite as a PIB anode is suggested. This research may pave the way for the advancement of alloy-based anodes with high capacity and long cycle life in PIBs.

Single-layered MoS2 represents a promising anode material for lithium-ion (LIBs), sodium-ion (SIBs), and potassium-ion batteries (PIBs) because of its high capacity and isotropic ion transport paths. However, its practical applications are constrained by its low intrinsic conductivity and its propensity to agglomerate. This study introduces a charge-driven interlayer expansion technique where Co2+ substitutes for Mo4+ as a dopant, endowing the MoS2 layers with negative charges. This creates electrostatic repulsion and, combined with the insertion of gaseous groups, induces interlayer expansion that disrupts the interlayer van der Waals force, resulting in single-layered MoS2 uniformly dispersed in a carbon matrix. This dispersion derives from the transformation of carbonaceous gaseous groups under high vapor pressure. Co atom doping enhances the intrinsic conductivity of single-layered MoS2, and the carbon matrix effectively prevents agglomeration. During the conversion reaction, the doped Co atoms are transformed into ultrasmall Co nanoparticles, which enhance spin-polarized surface capacitance, thereby significantly improving ion transport and storage. As a result, the developed material exhibits exceptional Li/Na/K-ion storage performance, ranking among the top for MoS2-based anodes. This charge-driven interlayer expansion strategy offers a new approach for creating single-layered MoS2 with substantial potential for energy storage applications.

Carbon-coated TiO2 microsphere electrodes with high power and long lifespan were created using a hydrothermal process for sodium-ion batteries, examining their electrochemical performance relative to carbon content. The carbon layer, formed from adding sucrose, inhibited the enlargement of TiO2 primary crystallites during calcination. The electrode with a 20 wt % sucrose carbon coat displayed outstanding cycle retention over 50 cycles (100%) and exceptional rate capability up to 30 C at room temperature. This cell provided a significant discharge capacity of 155 mAh g(composite)(-1) at 0.1 C, 149 mAh g(composite)(-1) at 1 C, and 82.7 mAh g(composite)(-1) at 10 C.

A three-dimensional spider-web structure composed of Na2Ti3O7 nanotubes is created utilizing a hydrothermal synthesis method. This self-similar network architecture demonstrates outstanding performance as an anode for room temperature sodium ion batteries for the first time, without the use of any additives such as binders or conducting agents.

Lithium-ion battery (LIB) technology has dominated for many years, but the rising pressure and cost associated with lithium sources have accelerated the need for alternative energy storage solutions. Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have emerged as a cost-effective substitute due to their similar electrochemical properties, attracting significant research interest. Despite this, SIBs face major challenges such as lower reversible capacity and short lifespan, resulting from the larger ionic radius of sodium ions. Addressing these issues, enhancing anode materials has proven to be particularly effective. This paper summarizes recent advancements in promising anode materials for SIBs and discusses future prospects in this area.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are promising for large-scale energy storage systems, but their power density is constrained by the slow Na+ diffusion in both cathode and anode materials. In this study, the authors present an ultrahigh power SIB prototype with a high-rate Na3V2(PO4)3 (NVP) cathode, graphite-type mesocarbon microbeads (MCMB) anode, and Na+‐diglyme electrolyte. They observe that the NVP cathode's overpotential follows Ohm's law. The synthesized NVP@C@carbon nanotubes (CNTs) cathode benefits from CNT networks that enhance electronic conductivity, thereby lowering overpotential and charge transfer resistance, resulting in an outstanding rate capability exceeding 1000C. For the MCMB anode, the initial [Na‐diglyme]+ co‐intercalation is dominated by pseudocapacitance, followed by the rapid ion diffusion facilitated by the expanded graphite layers. The cathode and anode's swift (de)intercalation kinetics are well-aligned. Consequently, the MCMB|1 m NaPF6 in diglyme|NVP@C@CNTs full SIB cell achieves an energy density of 88 Wh kg−1 at a high power density of approximately 10 kW kg−1. Even at an ultrahigh power density of 23 kW kg−1, it delivers an energy density of 58 Wh kg−1. These promising results are expected to drive the progress of high-power SIBs for future large-scale applications.

The behavior at the anode/electrolyte interface and the overall performance of sodium-ion batteries are determined by a complex interplay of processes occurring across all components of the electrochemical cell, spanning a wide range of size and timescales. Studies focused on a single scale may fall short in capturing the complete complexity of these processes, necessitating broad, multiscale investigations for thorough understanding. This perspectives article introduces several analytical and theoretical techniques, illustrating how they can be integrated to provide a more comprehensive understanding of sodium-ion battery (SIB) performance throughout its lifecycle, especially focusing on the interfaces of hard carbon anodes. These methods address various length and time scales, from micro to nano level, and from cell level to atomistic structures, encompassing a wide array of physical and (electro)chemical properties. The article specifically examines the use of mass spectrometric, microscopic, spectroscopic, electrochemical, thermodynamic, and physical methods to acquire essential information on battery behavior. Additionally, it discusses the integration of these techniques to clarify the multiscale phenomena at the anode interface, thereby developing a holistic understanding of their impact on overall sodium-ion battery performance.

The engineering of three-dimensional graphene/metal composites featuring ultrasmall metal sizes and strong interfaces between metal and graphene for energy storage remains a challenging and seldom-explored area. This study introduces an easy top-down method to produce SnSb nanocrystals confined within 3D nitrogen-doped porous graphene networks, intended as anodes for sodium-ion batteries. These structures consist of interconnected empty N-graphene boxes with in-plane embedded ultrasmall SnSb nanocrystals. The comprehensive encapsulation (plane-to-plane contact) design significantly boosts electron conductivity and structural integrity of the electrode, while also providing additional interfacial sodium storage. This results in significantly improved high-rate sodium storage capacity and stability, as supported by experimental and first-principles simulation findings. Furthermore, this top-down approach opens new possibilities for the cost-effective and high-yield production of 3D graphene/metal composites for various energy-related applications and beyond.

We present a novel sodium-ion battery that integrates a NaFePO₄ cathode with a nanocomposite tin-carbon (Sn-C) sodium-alloying anode. The NaFePO₄ cathode is produced through Li-Na conversion of a LiFePO₄ cathode directly within the complete cell, utilizing the Sn-C anode and a sodium-ion electrolyte. Our findings demonstrate that this distinctive method successfully and efficiently transforms LiFePO₄ into NaFePO₄ in a sodium-ion battery, functioning at a voltage of 3 V. It achieves a maximum reversible capacity of 150 mAh g⁻¹, exhibits high reversibility, and maintains an excellent rate capability.

Crystalline Covalent Organic Frameworks (COFs) are structured with ordered nano-channels that can be enhanced with redox-active functional groups, enabling them to function effectively as anodes in metal ion batteries, such as lithium-ion (LIB) and sodium-ion batteries (SIB). Although sodium is more abundant, making it a preferable option over lithium, the problematic intercalation of larger sodium ions renders them incompatible with the graphite anodes typically used in lithium-ion batteries. Additionally, the slow movement of these ions within electrodes hinders rapid sodiation in SIBs. Addressing this challenge, introducing an electronic drive at the electrodes through chemical modifications offers a promising solution. In this study, we introduce SIB anodes based on three isostructural COFs that have similar Highest Occupied Molecular Orbitals (HOMO) levels but distinct Lowest Unoccupied Molecular Orbitals (LUMO) energy levels. The variations in LUMO levels have been deliberately engineered by incorporating electron-deficient substitutes (phenyl, tetrazine, and bispyridine-tetrazine) into the COF modules. As cell potential decreases, electrons occupy the anti-bonding LUMO, transforming these electron-rich LUMO levels into effective anodes, enticing the otherwise slow sodium ions to migrate from the electrolyte. Furthermore, the natural porosity of the COF aids in the accommodation and diffusion of Na+ ions. These COFs demonstrate impressive specific capacity and rate capabilities (for fast charging and discharging), which for Na+ is more challenging than for the smaller Li+ ions. The bispyridine-tetrazine COF, featuring the lowest LUMO energy, achieves a specific capacity of 340 mA h g-1 at 1 A g-1 and 128 mA h g-1 at a high current density of 15 A g-1. Upon increasing the current density from 0.1 to 1 A g-1, it experiences only a 24% reduction, the smallest among the best-performing COF-derived Na-ion battery anodes.

Symmetric sodium ion batteries offer desirable attributes such as low cost, simple manufacturing, and easy recyclability, making them ideal for large-scale stationary energy storage applications. In this study, we present a symmetric sodium ion battery leveraging dual-electron reactions in the NASICON-structured Na3MnTi(PO4)3 material. The Na3MnTi(PO4)3 electrode achieves a stable capacity of up to 160 mAh g-1 with a Coulombic efficiency of 97% at 0.1 C, exploiting the redox reactions of Ti3+/4+, Mn2+/3+, and Mn3+/4+. This is the first investigation of a symmetric sodium-ion full cell utilizing Na3MnTi(PO4)3 as both cathode and anode in an organic electrolyte, showing excellent reversibility and cycling performance with voltage plateaus around 1.4 V and 1.9 V. The full cell delivers a reversible capacity of 75 mAh g-1 at 0.1 C and an energy density of 52 Wh kg-1. Moreover, ex-situ XRD analysis and first-principle calculations are used to explore the sodiation mechanism and structural changes. This research proposes a viable strategy to enhance the energy density of symmetric sodium-ion batteries.

In the quest to develop a high-performance anode for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), binary zinc phosphides (ZnP2 and Zn3P2) were synthesized using a straightforward solid-state heat treatment method, and their sodium storage properties were assessed. ZnP2 exhibited superior sodium reactivity compared to Zn3P2. Consequently, a carbon-modified ZnP2-based composite (ZnP2-C) was created to enhance electrochemical performance. To understand the electrochemical reaction mechanism of ZnP2-C during the processes of sodiation and desodiation, a variety of ex-situ analytical techniques were applied. During sodiation, the ZnP2 in the composite converted into NaZn13 and Na3P phases, undergoing a single-step conversion reaction. In contrast, during desodiation, the Zn in NaZn13 and P in Na3P fully recombined back to the original ZnP2 phase. This one-step conversion and recombination process of ZnP2 in the composite provided ZnP2-C with exceptional electrochemical performance, including a highly reversible capacity of 883 mAh g-1 after 130 cycles without any capacity loss, alongside a fast C-rate capability of 500 mAh g-1 at 1C and 350 mAh g-1 at 3C.

Aromatic organic compounds hold promise as electrode materials in rechargeable batteries, with anticipated improvements for both anode and cathode materials in sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). However, many aromatic organic compounds used as anode materials in SIBs have shown substantial degradation during fast-charge/discharge cycles and have not performed well over extended use. This paper introduces a molecular design approach aimed at enhancing the stability of organic compounds used in battery electrodes. The compound under investigation, [2.2.2.2]paracyclophane‐1,9,17,25‐tetraene (PCT), is designed to stabilize its neutral state via local aromaticity and its doubly reduced state through global aromaticity. This design results in an anode material that exhibits remarkably stable cycling performance and excels in fast-charge/discharge scenarios, paving a promising new direction for the development of SIB electrode materials and other battery technologies.

Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2), a two-dimensional layered material, holds promise as an anode for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) because of its appealing theoretical capacity and affordability. However, it faces significant issues like low rate performance due to sluggish Na+ intercalation kinetics and poor cycling durability due to the stacking of MoS2 sheets. In this study, we present a distinct structure of bundled defect-rich MoS2 (BD-MoS2), formed by MoS2 with large vacancies enveloped by ultrathin MoO3, achieved through a simple quenching process. As an anode in a SIB, the BD-MoS2 electrode demonstrates ultrafast charging/discharging attributed to its pseudocapacitive Na+ storage mechanism. Both experimental data and theoretical analyses indicate that Na+ can traverse the MoS2 layer through vacancies rather than just diffuse along the layer, enabling a three-dimensional Na+ diffusion with enhanced kinetics. Additionally, the bundled architecture reduces sheet stacking, leading to excellent cycle durability with highly reversible capacities of 350 and 272 mAh g-1 at 2 and 5 A g-1, respectively, after 1000 cycles.

Hard carbon (HC) is considered the leading candidate for anode materials in sodium-ion batteries. Several properties, including the intensity ratio of the Raman spectrum, the lateral size of HC crystallites (La), and the interlayer distance (d002), have been examined for their impact on anode performance. However, these factors do not directly represent the bulk properties of the Na+ intercalation reaction, given Raman's high surface sensitivity, and La and d002 only provide one-dimensional crystalline information. This study proposes that the crystallite interlayer area (Ai), defined by La, d002, and stacking height (Lc), determines the Na+ intercalation behavior in various HCs. It was found that different wood-derived HCs showed a similar total capacity of approximately 250 mAh g-1, but the Na+ intercalation capacity (Ci) was proportional to Ai, with a correlation coefficient R² = 0.94. The Ai evaluation was also applicable to previous studies and showed a strong correlation with their Ci, suggesting that Ai is more generally applicable than traditional evaluation methods.

An enhancement in the performance of oxide-based anodes using a polyacrylic acid (PAA)-carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) binder has been documented in batteries. Remarkably high capacity and cycling ability were achieved with several oxide powders, without relying on specific carbon modifications or morphology control, representing a significant advancement in the field.

Sodium's abundance makes it a desirable candidate over lithium for large-scale energy storage in sodium-ion rechargeable batteries, as long as a suitable cathode can be found to provide the required capacity, voltage, and cycle life at specified charge/discharge rates. Hexacyanometallates, being low-cost and easy to synthesize with rigid open frameworks, are promising cathode options due to their ability to facilitate rapid Na(+) insertion and extraction. This study presents a notable impact of interstitial H2O on the structural and electrochemical properties of sodium manganese(II) hexacyanoferrates(II), specifically Na2MnFe(CN)6·zH2O (Na2-δMnHFC). The newly identified dehydrated Na2-δMnHFC phase demonstrates superior electrochemical performance compared to other known Na-ion cathode materials, delivering a reversible capacity of 150 mAh g(-1) at 3.5 V in a sodium half cell and 140 mAh g(-1) in a full cell with a hard-carbon anode. At a 20 C charge/discharge rate, the half-cell's capacity is 120 mAh g(-1), while at 0.7 C, the cell retains 75% of its capacity after 500 cycles.

Graphene-based nanomaterials are emerging as promising anode options for sodium-ion batteries due to the notable properties of graphene and the synergistic interactions between graphene and active materials. However, the diffusion of sodium ions is effective only in the parallel direction of the 2D graphene sheet, while vertical diffusion is challenging, thus limiting the rate capability of graphene-based electrodes. To address this issue, pore-forming techniques are used to create perforations in graphene, allowing for the in situ growth of Co3Se4 nanoparticles. These in-plane nanoholes overcome the physical barriers of graphene nanosheets, facilitating rapid electrolyte ion diffusion in the longitudinal direction. Furthermore, this design mitigates the aggregation of Co3Se4 nanoparticles due to their strong affinity for graphene. With the high conductivity and rapid ion transport provided by this sophisticated structure, the Co3Se4/holey graphene demonstrates an impressive rate performance of 519.5 mAh g−1 at 5.0 A g−1 and exhibits excellent cycle stability. The study concludes that enhancing sodium ion transport within graphene-based composites is vital for improving rate performance, and this approach effectively modifies graphene-based nanomaterials into potential anode materials.

Creating anode electrodes for sodium-ion batteries remains challenging due to issues like slow Na+ diffusion and significant volume expansion. Efforts have focused on creating carbon composites and new nanostructures to enhance anode materials. In this study, an ultra-small few-layer MoS2 nanostructure confined within a hierarchical porous carbon fiber composite was synthesized via the nanocasting method using a novel hierarchical porous carbon fiber template. This composite, when used as an anode material, exhibits excellent electrochemical performance for sodium-ion batteries, including high reversible capacities (491 mA h g-1 after 50 cycles at 0.1 A g-1), impressive rate performance (387 mA h g-1 at 2 A g-1), and remarkable long-term cycling stability (234 mA h g-1 at 1 A g-1 after 3000 cycles). It ranks among the best for long-term cycling stability reported for MoS2-based anode materials for sodium-ion batteries. This approach could provide new insights into developing high-performance anode materials for sodium-ion batteries.

Sodium ion batteries (SIBs) are gaining significant attention due to their potential for large-scale energy storage and the affordability of sodium. Iron oxides (FeOx) stand out as promising anode materials because of their high theoretical capacity and low cost. However, FeOx anodes face challenges such as slow reaction kinetics and considerable lattice changes, leading to poor rate performance and rapid capacity loss during the sodiation/desodiation cycles. This study introduces Mn ions into the Fe3O4 lattice through interstitial sites to create Mn-incorporated Fe3O4/graphene (M-Fe3O4/G) composites using a straightforward hydrothermal approach. As verified by XRD Rietveld refinement and first principle calculations, Mn integration into the structure significantly enhances electron density around the Fermi level, thereby boosting the electrical conductivity and electrochemical performance. Consequently, the M0.1Fe2.9O4/G composite achieves a high reversible capacity of 439.8 mAh g-1 at a current density of 100 mA g-1 over 200 cycles. Even at a high current density of 1 A g-1, the M-Fe3O4/G composites exhibit stability for more than 1200 cycles, maintaining a capacity of 210 mAh g-1. When paired with a Na3V2(PO4)3-type cathode, the Mn-incorporated Fe3O4/G composites show excellent performance in full SIBs, delivering 161.2 mAh g-1 at a current density of 1 A g-1 after 100 cycles. The incorporation of Mn ions into the Fe3O4 lattice offers valuable insights into optimizing metal oxide anodes for SIB applications.

Sodium ion (Na-ion) batteries, being both affordable and scalable, are an excellent substitute for current lithium-ion batteries. To address the limitations in energy density, a promising solution involves developing a high-voltage anode-free design, utilizing a lightweight aluminum current collector at the anode and a high-voltage sodium-rich cathode. This approach, however, requires the electrolyte to meet rigorous standards for sodium reversibility and high-voltage stability. To meet these demands, a 3A zeolite molecular sieve film is strategically designed, creating a highly aggregated solvation structure through size effect control. This innovation effectively suppresses slight yet continual oxidative decomposition and enhances oxidative stability up to 4.5 V, without compromising the sodium reversibility of the anode, which remains at 99.91%. As a result, we achieve anode-free cells with high energy densities of 369 and 372 W h kg-1 for cells classified at 4.0 and 4.25 V, respectively. Moreover, this approach supports a long lifespan of 250 cycles for 4.0 V-class anode-free cells and significantly cuts costs in a sustainable manner.

Antimony (Sb)-based materials are considered promising anode materials for sodium ion batteries (SIBs) due to their high theoretical capacities and suitable sodium insertion potentials. However, the energy density and cycling stability of current Sb-based anodes for SIBs remain limited and require notable enhancement. In this study, we introduced an innovative Sb/C hybrid, where Sb nanorods are encapsulated within a highly conductive nitrogen and sulfur codoped carbon (Sb@(N, S-C)) framework. As an anode for SIBs, the Sb@(N, S-C) hybrid achieves high reversible capacities of 621.1 mAh g-1 at 100 mA g-1 after 150 cycles and maintains 390.8 mAh g-1 at 1 A g-1 after 1,000 cycles. Even at higher current densities of 2, 5, and 10 A g-1, the Sb@(N, S-C) hybrid demonstrates reversible capacities of 534.4, 430.8, and 374.7 mAh g-1, respectively. These remarkable sodium storage properties are mainly due to the distinctive cross-linked carbon networks, which provide highly conductive frameworks for the rapid transfer of ions and electrons, thereby mitigating volume expansion and preventing the agglomeration of Sb nanorods during cycling.

Introducing oxygen vacancies into anatase TiO2 is recognized as a potential method to enhance the movement of electrons and Na+ ions, crucial for outstanding electrochemical properties in anatase TiO2. Despite this, intentionally creating oxygen vacancies in anatase TiO2 for sodium-ion anodes in a straightforward and effective manner remains challenging. In this research, we introduce a novel approach using a simple plasma treatment to generate oxygen vacancies in urchin-like N-doped carbon-coated anatase TiO2 (NC-DTO). The combination of oxygen vacancies and conductive N-doped carbon coating significantly improves sodium storage capabilities in NC-DTO. As an anode for sodium-ion batteries, the NC-DTO electrode displays remarkable electrochemical performance, with a capacity of 272 mA h g-1 at 0.25 C, a capacity retention of 98.8% after 5000 cycles at 10 C, and an extremely high capacity of 150 mA h g-1 at 15 C. Density functional theory calculations paired with experimental data indicate that the enhancement in sodium storage is due to increased electronic conductivity from the N-doped carbon layer, as well as a reduced band gap and sodiation energy barrier brought about by oxygen vacancies. This study demonstrates that plasma-induced oxygen vacancies in TiO2 are an effective strategy for improving its electrochemical properties, applicable to other metal oxides for energy storage applications.

Black phosphorus (BP) has recently gained significant attention from researchers as a potential anode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIB) due to its high theoretical capacity of 2596 mAh g-1 and excellent electrical conductivity of approximately 300 S m-1. Despite these properties, its implementation in practical applications is hindered by substantial volume changes during electrochemical cycling. This study improves the reversible performance of BP in SIBs by covalently bonding functionalized BP to graphene. The enhanced interaction between chemically functionalized BP and graphene contributes to the stability of BP during prolonged cycling of SIBs. This bonding decreases surface energy and increases the thickness of BP, widening the channel between BP nanosheets and graphene. The enlarged channel allows for greater sodium ion storage, thereby enhancing cycle performance. Notably, two types of phosphorus-carbon bonds were identified for the first time during experimental analysis. With this strategy, the BP-based SIB anode achieves a specific capacity of 1472 mAh g-1 at 0.1 A g-1 by the 50th cycle and maintains 650 mAh g-1 at 1 A g-1 after 200 cycles.

Symmetric sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are attractive for large-scale energy storage due to their straightforward manufacturing and the plentiful availability of sodium. Despite this, many symmetric SIBs struggle with reduced energy density. In this study, an advanced Na4V2(PO4)3 anode is developed using electrochemical preintercalation, and a high energy density symmetric SIB is constructed using Na3V2(PO4)3 as the cathode and Na4V2(PO4)3 as the anode, exploiting the V4+/V2+ redox couple for the first time. In half-cell tests, both electrodes demonstrate stable electrochemical performance for over 3000 cycles. The symmetric SIBs achieve an output voltage of 3.0 V and a cell-level energy density of 138 W h kg-1. Additionally, the sodium storage mechanism within the extended voltage range of 0.01-3.9 V is investigated using in situ X-ray diffraction.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are a promising alternative to lithium-ion batteries for large-scale energy storage due to the plentiful availability of sodium. Metal sulfides are seen as favorable anode materials for SIBs because of their cost-effectiveness and environmental benefits. In this work, a series of copper sulfides (Cu2S, Cu7S4, and Cu7KS4) are synthesized for the first time through a simple electrochemical method using KCl-NaCl-Na2S molten salts. The synthesized Cu2S, featuring a micron-sized flake structure, is evaluated as an anode for SIBs, achieving a capacity of 430 mAh g⁻¹ with an initial Coulombic efficiency of 84.9% at a current density of 100 mA g⁻¹. Additionally, the Cu2S anode shows excellent performance (337 mAh g⁻¹ at 20 A g⁻¹, equivalent to 50 C) and extremely long cycle life (88.2% capacity retention after 5000 cycles at 5 A g⁻¹, which translates to a fade rate of 0.0024% per cycle). Furthermore, the pseudocapacitance contribution and the sturdy porous structure formed in situ during cycling grant the Cu2S anodes exceptional rate capability and improved cyclic performance, as demonstrated by kinetics analysis and ex situ characterization.

Sodium-ion batteries are appealing for large-scale energy storage owing to the plentiful availability of sodium and the low cost of sodium-based materials. Phosphorus is a potential anode material for these batteries, boasting a theoretical capacity of 2596 mAh/g. However, red phosphorus suffers from poor electronic conductivity and lower initial Coulombic efficiency compared to black phosphorus. Despite its advantages, the high cost and limited production capacity of black phosphorus have hindered its use in anodes. To overcome these limitations, we have devised a straightforward and scalable approach to create a layered composite of black phosphorus and graphene (BP/rGO) at room temperature through pressurization. This carbon-black-free and binder-free BP/rGO anode demonstrated impressive specific charge capacities of 1460.1, 1401.2, 1377.6, 1339.7, 1277.8, 1123.78, and 720.8 mAh/g under a rate capability test at current densities of 0.1, 0.5, 1, 5, 10, 20, and 40 A/g, respectively. In a cycling performance assessment, the BP/rGO anodes maintained capacities of 1250 and 640 mAh/g at 1 and 40 A/g, respectively, even after 500 deep cycles, representing a significant enhancement in sodium-ion battery anode performance.

A symmetric sodium-ion battery employing an aqueous electrolyte is presented, using Na3MnTi(PO4)3 with a NASICON structure as both the anode and the cathode. This material features two electrochemically active transition metals, with Ti(4+)/Ti(3+) operating on the anode side and Mn(3+)/Mn(2+) on the cathode side. This symmetric cell, based on the dual-function electrode material, demonstrates a distinct voltage plateau around 1.4 V in an aqueous electrolyte, along with stable cycling performance and excellent rate capability. The development of this aqueous symmetric sodium-ion battery, noted for its high safety and low cost, holds potential as a solution for large-scale stationary energy storage.

Electrodes that provide enhanced sodium ion (Na+) storage and exhibit excellent cycling stability are crucial for advancing the energy density and rate capabilities of sodium ion batteries (SIBs). In this study, we introduce a coral-like FeP composite where FeP nanoparticles are anchored on a nitrogen-doped three-dimensional carbon framework, termed FeP@NC. Thanks to the continuous N-doped carbon structure and a cushioning graphitized carbon layer encasing the FeP nanoparticles, the FeP@NC composite enables the sodium ion battery to maintain ultra-stable cycling at 10 A g⁻¹ with a capacity retention of 82.0% over 10,000 cycles. Notably, we confirm a unique mechanism of particle refinement and capacity increase during cycling. Specifically, FeP nanoparticles undergo a refining-recombination phase in the initial cycle, followed by a global refinement trend after several dozen cycles. This leads to an enhanced degree of graphitization and interface magnetization, creating additional active sites for Na+ storage and resulting in increased capacity over time. Interestingly, this capacity increment phenomenon applies to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) as well. This paper introduces a novel insight into the mechanism of capacity enhancement during cycling and suggests a viable approach to designing high-performance anode materials for both SIBs and LIBs.

Developing hard carbon with a high initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) and strong cycling stability is crucial for the effective use of sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). However, the formation of defects and oxygen-containing groups along either the edges or layers of carbon in hard carbon is unavoidable, resulting in a high density of irreversible Na+ sites that reduce efficiency and thus risk battery failure. It is therefore important to eliminate these unwanted defect structures to improve battery performance. In this study, we present a method that involves applying a soft-carbon coating to free-standing hard-carbon electrodes, which significantly reduces the formation of defects and oxygen-containing groups in hard carbon. Electrochemical tests reveal that the soft-carbon-coated, free-standing hard-carbon electrodes achieve an ultrahigh ICE of 94.1% and maintain excellent cycling performance (99% capacity retention after 100 cycles at a current density of 20 mA g-1), highlighting their strong potential for use in practical sodium storage systems. Additionally, the mechanism of sodium storage was examined using operando Raman spectroscopy. Our investigation extends the "adsorption-intercalation-pore filling-deposition" model of sodium storage. We suggest that the pore filling in the plateau region can be split into two phases: (1) sodium initially fills the pores near the inner walls of the carbon layer, and (2) once saturation is near in these inner wall pores, additional sodium can be deposited onto the already existing sodium.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are considered promising for large-scale energy storage due to the plentiful and widespread availability of sodium. Various approaches have effectively addressed the issues related to the large ion size in SIBs at moderate to low current densities. However, there is still a significant need for improved fast-charging capabilities in SIBs to meet the growing energy demands from large-scale to grid-level applications. In this study, a core-shell Co2VO4/carbon composite anode is developed to address the fast-charging challenges of SIBs. The combined effect of the durable spinel structure of Co2VO4, the nano-sized spheres, and the carbon shell leads to improved diffusion rates for Na+ ions and enhanced electron transfer, resulting in excellent electrochemical performance. At an extremely high current density of 5 A g-1, the Co2VO4@C anode reaches a capacity of 135.1 mAh g-1 and maintains over 98% capacity retention after 2000 cycles, largely through a pseudocapacitive dominant mechanism. This research offers valuable insights for the development of fast-charging materials for SIBs and other battery systems like lithium-ion batteries.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are anticipated to provide a commercially viable alternative to lithium-ion batteries for grid electricity storage, primarily due to their potential cost-effectiveness in the near future. However, determining an appropriate anode material remains a significant challenge for SIB deployment, particularly at room temperature. Graphite struggles to accommodate the larger sodium ions (Na+) compared to lithium ions (Li+), whereas hard carbon with an increased interlayer distance offers relatively high storage capacity and a robust cycle life. Despite these advantages, the low initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) of hard carbon, due to its large surface area and costly synthetic methods, limits its practical usage. This study introduces an innovative coupled carbonization method to produce an economical hard carbon material through the pyrolysis and carbonization of a mixture of sucrose and phenolic resin. The optimized pyrolysis reaction process and conditions yield a hard carbon with an exceptionally low surface area of 1.54 m² g⁻¹ and a high ICE of 87%, which are seldom reported and improve the Na+ consumption efficiency in the cathode. Notably, with a high interlayer distance of 3.95 Å, the hard carbon delivers a capacity of 319 mAh g⁻¹ and preserves 90% capacity retention over 150 cycles. Additionally, a full cell configuration using the prepared hard carbon anode against an air-stable O3-Na0.9[Cu0.22Fe0.30Mn0.48]O₂ cathode is demonstrated, achieving a high ICE of 80% and an energy density of 256 Wh kg⁻¹ (anode-side, hard carbon) with dependable cycling performance. These findings validate the feasibility and adaptability of our synthesis approach, indicating that tunable carbon-based materials could find broader applications beyond their appealing properties for Na-ion batteries.

Emerging sodium-ion batteries (NIBs) and potassium-ion batteries (KIBs) offer potential to complement lithium-ion battery (LIB) technology and broaden the battery market. Hard carbon stands out as a suitable anode choice for LIBs, NIBs, and KIBs due to its high capacity, sustainability, broad availability, and stable physicochemical characteristics. In this study, a variety of hard carbons are crafted through hydrothermal carbonization followed by pyrolysis at various temperatures to meticulously adjust their structural attributes. When utilized as anodes, these hard carbons display varied ion-storage behaviors for Li, Na, and K, with NIBs showing the highest reversible capacity. Comprehensive material and electrochemical analyses are conducted to investigate the link between structural aspects and electrochemical performance, elucidating the specific mechanisms of alkali-ion storage in hard carbons. Additionally, the most efficient hard carbon is evaluated with a sodium cathode Na3V2(PO4)3 in a Na-ion pouch cell, achieving a high power density of 2172 W kg−1 at an energy density of 181.5 Wh kg−1 (considering the total mass of active materials in both anode and cathode). The Na-ion pouch cell also maintains stable ultra-long-term cycling (9000 hours or 5142 cycles), underscoring the promising potential of these materials as sustainable, scalable anodes for applications beyond lithium-based batteries.

Sodium ion batteries (NIB, NAB, SIB) are garnering attention as a cost-effective alternative to lithium-ion batteries (LIB), due to the abundant and widely distributed reserves of sodium. Tin is a highly promising anode material for SIBs that can alloy with up to 3.75 sodium atoms, achieving a charge storage capacity of 847 mAh g(-1). In this account, we present the current knowledge on sodiation-induced phase transformations and their effects on performance across various Sn-based systems, including metallic Sn, its alloys, tin oxide (SnO2), tin sulfide (SnS2/SnS), and tin phosphide (Sn4P3). We begin by detailing the sodiation process in metallic Sn, focusing on the latest insights into reactions preceding the final Na15Sn4 intermetallic equilibrium. We explore why researchers assert that an equilibrium series of phase transitions, as described by phase diagrams, does not occur, and instead describe how sodiation/desodiation progresses through a series of metastable crystalline and amorphous structures. Recent modeling insights reveal how these transitions significantly affect the mechanical properties of the alloy, altering the bonding and arrangement of atoms from "Sn-like" to "Na-like." Subsequently, we examine sodiation reactions in SnO2, arguing that despite extensive experiments focusing on the synthesis and testing of tin oxide-based nanocomposites, the precise sodiation sequence is just beginning to be understood. In contrast to Sn and Sn alloys, which can achieve near-theoretical capacities early in cycling, SnO2 never reaches the theoretical 1398 mAh g(-1) capacity due to incomplete Sn to Na15Sn4 alloying reactions. We describe how the oxide conversion reaction progresses through an intermediate SnO phase and its dependence on terminal anodic voltage for reversibility in a half-cell. We then discuss sodiation in tin sulfide and tin phosphide phases, presenting emerging microstructural evidence that may elucidate why these materials fail to achieve their promising theoretical capacities under standard testing conditions. Finally, we compare the capacity (cycling and rate) performances of various Sn-based anode materials, suggesting that an optimal microstructural architecture may exist.

To address the issues of significant volume change and low electronic conductivity in the earth-abundant material ilmenite used for rechargeable sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), a novel anode comprising fine ilmenite FeTiO3 nanoparticles within carbon nanotubes (FTO⊂CNTs) has been developed. This involves the creation of a TiO2 shell on metal-organic framework (Fe-MOF) nanorods through sol-gel deposition, followed by solid-state annealing of the resulting core-shell structures to produce well-defined FTO⊂CNTs. The synthesized FTO⊂CNT electrode offers notable benefits, including a hollow interior in the hybrid nanostructure, fully encapsulated small electroactive units, a flexible conductive carbon matrix, and a durable solid electrolyte interface (SEI) of FTO during cycles. FTO⊂CNT electrodes display impressive cycle stability (achieving 358.8 mAh g-1 after 200 cycles at 100 mA g-1) and exceptional rate capability (201.8 mAh g-1 at 5000 mA g-1) with a high Coulombic efficiency of about 99%. Furthermore, when paired with a Na3V2(PO4)3 cathode to form complete SIBs, the manufactured FTO⊂CNT//Na3V2(PO4)3 batteries exhibit outstanding rate performance and an extended cycle life.

A high-performance graphite-Si composite anode for Li-ion batteries was developed by integrating Si nanoparticles (NPs) onto graphite microparticles, using a polymer blend of poly(diallyl dimethyl-ammonium chloride) and poly(sodium 4-styrenesulfonate). This polymer blend facilitated the even distribution of Si NPs during the synthesis process and acted as a durable artificial solid-electrolyte interphase, significantly improving the composite electrode's cycle stability and rate performance. The electrode demonstrated a specific capacity of 450 mA h g(-1), retained 96% of its capacity at a 10 C-rate, maintained 95% retention after 200 cycles, and exhibited an electrode expansion behavior similar to that of a pristine graphite electrode.

Sodium-ion batteries are seen as potential options for large-scale energy storage due to sodium's plentiful availability and affordability. The successful development and market introduction of these batteries, however, hinge on utilizing electrode materials with high capacity. Among numerous metal oxides, SnO2 is notable for its high theoretical specific capacity in these batteries. Nevertheless, its capacity is compromised by significant volume expansion and low electrical conductivity, preventing it from achieving its theoretical potential. Although various nanostructured electrode designs, such as SnO2 nanocomposites, have been explored, the impact of other battery components like the electrolyte and binder on specific capacity and cycle stability is not well understood. This study examines the combined effect of the electrolyte and binder on performance improvements of SnO2 when supported by an intertwined network of reduced graphene oxide and partially open multiwalled carbon nanotube hybrid as an anode in sodium-ion batteries. Our findings reveal that using sodium carboxyl methyl cellulose and ethylene carbonate/diethyl carbonate as the solvent results in a substantial specific capacity of 688 mAh g–1 and maintains satisfactory cycle stability over 500 cycles. This represents about a 56% improvement in specific capacity compared to using a poly(vinylidene fluoride) binder with propylene carbonate as the solvent. This study enhances our understanding of the combined role of electrolytes and binders, aiding the development of metal-oxide-based electrode materials essential for advancing the commercialization of sodium-ion batteries.

A straightforward one-step thermal pyrolysis method was devised to create a carbon membrane using a natural leaf. The resulting carbonized leaf membrane features anisotropic surfaces and an internal hierarchical porosity. It demonstrates a remarkable specific capacity of 360 mAh/g and an initial Coulombic efficiency of 74.8% when used as a binder-free, current-collector-free anode in rechargeable sodium-ion batteries. Additionally, large-area carbon membranes with minimal contact resistance are produced by merely stacking and carbonizing leaves, presenting an innovative approach for the large-scale development of sodium-ion batteries.

Bismuth (Bi) as a two-dimensional (2D) material features a large interlayer spacing along the c-axis (0.395 nm), offering numerous active sites for sodium ion storage, thereby ensuring high activity for sodium ion storage. Nonetheless, the material's limited electrical conductivity and diminished cycling performance hinder its practical use. In this study, a Bi microsphere coated with nitrogen-doped carbon (Bi@NC) was synthesized. The distinctive Bi crystals and nitrogen-doped carbon layer imparted the Bi@NC anode with improved cycling stability and excellent rate capability. Furthermore, when the Bi@NC anode was combined with a Na3V2(PO4)3@C cathode in a full battery, it demonstrated outstanding sodium storage performance, achieving 57 mA h g⁻¹ after 2000 cycles at a current density of 1.0 A g⁻¹.

Sodium-ion batteries are increasingly seen as a cost-efficient alternative to lithium-ion systems for large-scale energy storage, but their safety remains a significant concern for practical use. This study introduces a safer sodium-ion battery by employing a nonflammable phosphate electrolyte, specifically trimethyl phosphate (TMP), combined with a NaNi0.35Mn0.35Fe0.3O2 cathode and an Sb-based alloy anode. The study explores the physical and electrochemical compatibility of the TMP electrolyte through ignition tests, ionic conductivity, cyclic voltammetry, and charge-discharge evaluations. The findings reveal that the TMP electrolyte, when mixed with an FEC additive, is entirely nonflammable and possesses a broad electrochemical window (0–4.5 V vs. Na/Na+). Within this system, both the Sb-based anode and the NaNi0.35Mn0.35Fe0.3O2 cathode demonstrate high reversible capacity and cycling stability, akin to those observed in carbonate electrolyte systems. Leveraging these outcomes, a nonflammable sodium-ion battery is developed using an Sb anode, a NaNi0.35Mn0.35Fe0.3O2 cathode, and a TMP + 10 vol% FEC electrolyte, which performs effectively with notable capacity and cycle stability. This advancement suggests a promising direction for creating safer sodium-ion batteries suitable for large-scale energy storage applications.

Utilizing structural phase transitions to modify material properties without additional elements is of notable technological significance. This study found that the hexagonal-SnS2 phase can convert to the orthorhombic-SnS phase through annealing in an argon atmosphere, enhancing sodium-ion storage capabilities due to the structural advantages of SnS. This paper reports the first SnS@graphene architecture for use as a sodium-ion battery anode, constructed from two-dimensional SnS and graphene nanosheets as complementary elements. The synthesized SnS@graphene hybrid composite achieves a remarkable specific capacity of 940 mAh g(-1) and outstanding rate capability of 492 and 308 mAh g(-1) following 250 cycles at current densities of 810 and 7290 mA g(-1), respectively, surpassing the performance of most known anode materials for Na-ion batteries. Utilizing combined ex situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and ex situ X-ray diffraction, the paper discusses in detail the formation mechanism of SnS@graphene and the synergistic Na-storage reactions of SnS in the anode. SnS undergoes a two-phase transformation (orthorhombic-SnS to cubic-Sn to orthorhombic-Na3.75Sn), whereas SnS2 undergoes a three-phase transformation (hexagonal-SnS2 to tetragonal-Sn to orthorhombic-Na3.75Sn) during sodiation. The relatively minor structural changes of SnS during conversion are expected to confer good structural and cycling stability in its sodium-ion battery performance. These findings show that the SnS@graphene architecture possesses unique qualities ideal for high-performance energy storage applications.

Sodium-ion batteries are seen as a promising alternative to lithium-ion batteries for large-scale energy storage. However, the advancement of sodium-ion batteries depends on developing new anode materials, as key anode materials used in lithium-ion batteries, like graphite and silicon, do not perform adequately in sodium-ion batteries. We have synthesized novel SnS/C nanocomposites using a top-down method to serve as anode materials for sodium-ion batteries. These materials demonstrate considerably enhanced electrochemical performance compared to bare SnS, particularly in cycling stability and rate capabilities. The SnS/C nanocomposites maintain excellent capacity retention across different current rates and deliver capacities up to 400 mA h g−1 even at a high current density of 800 mA g−1 (2C). To understand the reaction mechanism of the SnS/C nanocomposites, we conducted ex situ transmission electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, and operando X-ray absorption near-edge structure studies.

As sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) become increasingly prevalent, the pursuit of affordable anode materials like metal oxides for Na-ion storage is gaining significant interest. Given that sodium ions have a notably larger radius than lithium ions, many metal oxide electrode materials do not achieve the high performance in SIBs that they do in lithium-ion batteries. In this study, we utilized iron oxide to illustrate that intentionally designing an amorphous structure could improve the Na-ion storage capabilities of metal oxides. Amorphous Fe2O3/graphene composite nanosheets (Fe2O3@GNS) were synthesized through a simple method to serve as anodes for SIBs. It was found that amorphous Fe2O3 nanoparticles, averaging 5 nm in diameter, were uniformly attached to the graphene nanosheet surfaces via strong C-O-Fe oxygen-bridge bonds. In comparison to crystalline Fe2O3, the amorphous Fe2O3@GNS demonstrated superior sodium storage attributes, such as high electrochemical activity, an initial Coulombic efficiency of 81.2%, and good rate performance. At a current density of 100 mA/g, the amorphous Fe2O3@GNS composites exhibited a specific capacity of 440 mAh/g, significantly surpassing the 284 mAh/g capacity of crystalline Fe2O3. Even under a high current density of 2 A/g, the amorphous composites maintained a specific capacity of 219 mAh/g. The outstanding electrochemical performance is largely due to the amorphous Fe2O3 structures and their strong interface with GNS, which collectively provide more electrochemical active sites, enhance sodium ion transport, facilitate electron transfer, and effectively cushion the volume changes during the sodiation/desodiation processes. This strategic approach to designing amorphous iron oxide anodes for SIBs could also advance the development of other metal oxides with amorphous nanostructures, thereby enhancing their Na-ion storage performance.

The solid-electrolyte interface (SEI) film in sodium-ion batteries plays a critical role in the battery's capacity fading and cycling stability. Although the SEI film in sodium-ion batteries is important, it has not been extensively studied, and the formation mechanism remains unclear. This study employs DFT to investigate the reduction mechanisms of ethylene carbonate (EC), propylene carbonate (PC), vinylene carbonate (VC), ethylene sulfite (ES), 1,3-propylene sulfite (PS), and fluorinated ethylene carbonate (FEC). The activation energies, Gibbs free energies, enthalpies, and structures of the transition states are determined. Findings show that VC, ES, and PS additives in the electrolyte more readily form organic components in the anode SEI film through one-electron reduction. The order of preference for one-electron reduction leading to organic SEI compounds is VC>PC>EC, whereas the sequence for two-electron reduction producing inorganic Na2 CO3 is EC>PC>VC. Additionally, compared to the reduction of carbonate esters, two-electron reduction of sulfites ES and PS to form inorganic Na2 SO3 is more challenging. The study also suggests that FEC undergoes one- and two-electron reductive decomposition pathways more efficiently, resulting in inorganic NaF components.

To enhance lithium and sodium ion battery technologies, it is essential to comprehend how the characteristics of various components are influenced by their chemical structures. While operando structural studies provide valuable insights into battery operation, isolating the contributions of individual components within a battery stack—such as electrodes, current collectors, electrolyte, and binders—and analyzing distinct materials remains challenging. We have employed operando X-ray diffraction computed tomography (XRD-CT) to investigate specific elements of a virtually unchanged functioning cell, obtaining precise, spatially-resolved structural details of both crystalline and amorphous phases present during cycling, using Rietveld and pair distribution function (PDF) techniques. This method is demonstrated through the inaugural detailed structural analysis of sodium cycling in a phosphorus anode, uncovering unexpectedly varied mechanisms for sodiation and desodiation in this high-capacity anode system.

All-solid-state sodium-ion batteries (AS3iBs) are in demand for stationary energy storage due to their enhanced safety and stability across a broad temperature range. Hard carbon (HC), recognized for its low cost, low redox potential, and high capacity, is crucial for developing practical large-scale sodium-ion batteries. Nonetheless, the low initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) of this anode material limits the battery's energy density. This study investigates two methods to enhance the ICE of pristine HC: i) supplementary pyrolysis and ii) presodiation through the thermal decomposition of NaBH4. Analyses using Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and electrochemical measurements reveal that thermal treatment increases the Csp2 concentration within the HC structure, while presodiation provides sodium to fill irreversible intrinsic sites. As a result, presodiated HC demonstrates an exceptional ICE of over 99%, in contrast to thermally treated HC at 90% and pristine HC at 83% in half-cell configurations. Notably, an AS3iB using presodiated HC and NaCrO2 as the anode and cathode achieves a high ICE of 92% and an initial discharge energy density of 294 Wh kg_cathode^−1.

The growing demand for electric vehicles and portable and wearable electronics has led to a need for energy storage devices with high gravimetric and volumetric energy densities. Electrospinning emerges as a favorable method to produce freestanding electrodes with these high energy densities. A limitation of conventional electrospun electrodes is their low mass loading of active materials (around 20%-30 wt%). This study introduces a biomimetic approach inspired by sticky spider webs to create a high-performance anode that enhances both gravimetric and volumetric energy densities. By employing electrospinning followed by thermal treatment, freestanding carbon nanofiber (CNF) membranes with over 50 wt% bismuth content were fabricated. These membranes feature a CNF network structure that tightly bonds with active bismuth clusters, offering superior mechanical support and rapid charge transfer pathways—achievements not typically realized together. The composite membrane functions effectively as a lithium-ion battery anode, providing a high reversible capacity of 483 mA h g-1 at 100 mA g-1 after 200 cycles and demonstrating impressive rate performance with 242 mA h g-1 at 1 A g-1. Additionally, when used in sodium-ion batteries, it exhibits a considerable reversible specific capacity of 346 mA h g-1, along with excellent cycling performance, maintaining 186 mA h g-1 at 50 mA g-1 after 100 cycles. This research presents a straightforward, cost-effective, and environmentally friendly approach to produce freestanding, binder-free composite electrodes with high active material loading suitable for use in both LIBs and SIBs.

Hard carbon (HC) appears to be a promising commercial anode material for both lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). Nevertheless, the existing techniques for assessing battery performance that depend on...

Two-dimensional (2D) molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) has garnered significant attention for uses such as catalysis, energy storage, and electronics. Nonetheless, a key challenge remains the absence of effective exfoliation techniques for producing large quantities of 2D materials. We present a simple liquid-phase exfoliation technique that enhances the efficiency of obtaining single-layer MoS2 sheets using 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP) with the help of sodium hydroxide (NaOH). This method significantly increases the concentration of exfoliated MoS2 nanosheets compared to traditional liquid-phase exfoliation using NMP as a solvent. We further demonstrate the stable function of sodium-ion batteries using the exfoliated MoS2 and MoS2-rGO composite as anode materials.

Oxygen vacancies (OVs) are anticipated to improve the performance of sodium ion batteries (SIBs), though they have been sparsely reported. Using a MoO(3-x) nanosheet anode as an example, we demonstrate for the first time the advantageous impact of OVs on SIB performance. Additionally, at deep-discharge conditions, these benefits are enhanced by applying an ultrathin Al2O3 coating. Various measurements indicate that OVs enhance both electrical conductivity and the Na-ion diffusion coefficient, with the ultrathin coating effectively minimizing the cycling-induced solid-electrolyte interphase. The coated nanosheets show a high reversible capacity and excellent rate capability, achieving capacities of 283.9 mAh g(-1) at 50 mA g(-1) and 179.3 mAh g(-1) at 1 A g(-1) after 100 cycles. This study not only aims to draw attention to the role of OVs in sodium energy storage but also opens avenues for developing defect-utilizing strategies in other energy storage systems.

Heterostructure engineering is a highly promising strategy for improving the slow kinetics of anodes in sodium ion batteries (SIBs). In this study, we conduct a comprehensive examination of how various heterostructure interfaces affect the rate performance of discharging products (Na2O, Na2S, Na2Se). First-principle calculations show that among the three interface structures (Na2O/Na2S, Na2O/Na2Se, and Na2S/Na2Se), the Na2S/Na2Se interface exhibits the lowest diffusion energy barrier for Na at 0.39 eV. This is attributed to its minimal interface deformation, as well as similar electronegativity and lattice constants. Experimental results confirm that a metal sulfide/metal selenide (SnS/SnSe2) hierarchical anode provides excellent rate performance, achieving 45.6% of its normalized capacity at 10 A g-1 compared to 0.1 A g-1. The design strategy put forth in this study aids in developing high rate performance anodes for advanced battery systems.

Antimony/carbon (Sb@C) microspheres are synthesized through an easy self-catalyzing solvothermal approach, and their potential as anode materials in sodium-ion batteries is explored. Structural and morphological analysis shows that Sb@C microspheres consist of Sb nanoparticles (approximately 20 nm) uniformly encapsulated within a carbon matrix. The self-catalyzing solvothermal process is confirmed with comparative experiments using various raw materials. The resulting Sb@C microspheres display excellent sodium storage capabilities, achieving a reversible capacity of 640 mAh g(-1), outstanding rate performance, and prolonged cycling stability with 92.3% capacity retention after 300 cycles, highlighting their promise as anode materials for sodium-ion batteries.

Layered transition metal oxides based on sodium with an O3-type structure are promising candidates for cathodes in sodium-ion batteries. However, their application is limited due to rapid capacity fading and poor rate performance, which result from significant structural changes and interfacial degradation. In this research, a NaPO3 surface-modified O3-type layered NaNi1/3 Fe1/3 Mn1/3 O2 cathode has been created, providing improved stability at high voltages. This is achieved by a protective layer that resists acid attack, formed through a solid-gas reaction between the cathode particles and gaseous P2O5. The NaPO3 nanolayer effectively stabilizes the crystal structure by minimizing surface parasitic reactions and enhancing the observed average voltage. The surface-modified cathode shows superior cyclic stability (80.1% compared to 63.6%) after 150 cycles at 1 C within a broad voltage range of 2.0 V-4.2 V (vs Na+/Na). Additionally, the inherent ionic conduction of NaPO3 grants the surface-modified cathode excellent rate capability (103 mAh g-1 vs 60 mAh g-1) at 10 C. The findings of this study present a feasible method for advancing high rate and durable sodium-ion battery technology.

Incorporating heteroatoms can successfully inhibit phase transitions in layered sodium-ion battery cathodes, though their behavior during operation remains incompletely understood at the atomic level. In this study, density functional theory calculations are integrated with experiments to investigate how Mg dopants mitigate transitions and the mechanisms involved in P2-Na0.67Ni0.33Mn0.67O2 under operational conditions. When Na is extracted, some Mg dopants shift from transition metal (TM) layers into Na layers, driven by voids. This diffusion, involving multiple Mg ions, is more prevalent when the Mg content in the TM layer is relatively high, ultimately leading to Mg-enriched regions, or Mg segregation, away from Ni vacancies. This void-pump-effect-induced segregation of Mg effectively inhibits the P2-O2 phase transition due to the stronger Mg-O electrostatic attraction, which enhances connectivity between adjacent oxygen layers and prevents crack growth by reducing lattice volume variations during high-voltage cycling. This work offers fundamental insights into the mitigation behavior of heteroatoms in layered cathodes at an atomic level, advancing next-generation energy storage technologies.

Sodium ion batteries (SIBs) offer a cost-effective solution for energy storage but face limitations due to low energy density. Incorporating oxygen (O) redox in the design of Na-storage cathodes is seen as a promising approach to increase capacity and address energy density constraints. However, challenges such as the irreversible electrochemical behavior linked to O release must be addressed. Additionally, the O redox chemistry and the resulting structural evolution are not yet fully understood. In this work, we explore the O redox mechanism in Na-storage transition metal oxides. We review the issues related to reaction irreversibility and structural collapse, using insights from advanced characterization techniques. Furthermore, we discuss strategies to potentially improve the electrochemical performance of O redox and outline future research directions for discovering viable O redox cathode materials.

The P2-type layered oxide Na2/3Ni1/3Mn2/3O2 is a promising option for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), though it faces significant P2–O2 phase transitions during high-voltage charging, which causes substantial volume changes and weakens cycling performance. This paper introduces a Quasi-zero strain P2-Na0.75Li0.15Mg0.05Ni0.1Mn0.7O2 cathode, which exhibits a minimized P2–O2 transition with only a 0.49% volume change, leading to excellent cycling stability (83.9% capacity retention after 500 cycles at 5 C). The reduced volume strain is due to two factors: (1) Mg2+ ions in the Na layer act as "pillars," stabilizing the crystal structure during sodium removal and limiting structural changes at high voltage, and (2) Li+ insertion into the transition metal layer reduces electron localization in high desodiation states and immobilizes coordinating oxygen atoms, thus preventing P2–O2 transition slippage. This research offers new insights into the dual substitution effect of Li and Mg on P2-type cathode stability and a promising approach for developing SIB cathodes with exceptionally low bulk strain.

Prussian blue is garnering significant interest from researchers as a potential sodium-ion battery cathode due to its open framework and high operational potential. Yet, its practical application in sodium-ion batteries is hampered by interstitial water within its crystal structure and poor electronic conductivity. This study utilized an acid-assisted ball milling synthesis as a flexible method to produce surface-modified Prussian blue. Using (CH3COO)2Fe as a precursor, the ball milling process modified Prussian blue by introducing a carboxyl functional group on its surface, which decreased interstitial water content and enhanced electrochemical cycling performance. Additionally, the ball milling technique endowed the resulting Prussian blue with a considerable surface area, boosting its electrochemical rate performance. As a sodium-ion battery cathode, the synthesized Prussian blue exhibited a specific capacity of 145.3 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C and 113.7 mAh g−1 at 1 C, preserving 54.5% of its initial capacity after 1000 cycles at 1 C (1 C = 170 mA g−1). Moreover, a solid-state sodium-ion battery was assembled using the synthesized Prussian blue as the cathode and Na metal as the anode, achieving a high specific capacity of 128.7 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C. This study proposes an effective strategy to surmount the challenges facing Prussian blue for widespread commercial use.

P2-type layered oxides containing Fe and Mn are gaining attention as cathode materials for sodium ion batteries (SIBs) due to their cost-effectiveness and high specific capacity. However, they experience rapid capacity degradation and complex phase transformations. This study addresses these issues by adjusting the crystal structure and enhancing the electrochemical performance of Na0.67Mn0.5Fe0.5O2 using Al doping to replace Mn or Fe. The study reveals Al's contribution to improving rate capability and cycling performance: (1) Substituting Al for Mn or Fe reduces lattice parameters a and c while increasing d spacing and lengthening Na-O bonds, which boosts Na+ diffusion and rate capability, notably in Na0.67Mn0.5Fe0.47Al0.03O2. (2) Al doping decreases TMO2 layer thickness and fortifies TM-O/O-O bonds, enhancing layered structure stability and capacity retention. (3) Al doping decreases Mn3+ and Jahn-Teller distortion, reducing irreversible phase transitions. (4) Al doping reduces lattice volume variation and structural strain, further enhancing layered structure stability and cycling performance, particularly when Al replaces Fe. These insights into Al substitution roles can aid in designing high-performance cathode materials for SIBs with strategic lattice doping.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are promising for large-scale energy storage applications. Among them, P2-type manganese-based layered oxides are particularly appealing due to their high theoretical capacity, cost-effectiveness, and environmental friendliness. Nonetheless, challenges such as water sensitivity and limited cycling stability pose barriers to their application, with the core mechanisms of these issues not fully understood. This study employs copper substitution to mitigate the Jahn-Teller effect of Mn3+ and modify the related lattice structure.
