Detailed investigations into water sensitivity and charge compensation mechanisms reveal that water sensitivity is linked to the ordering of Na+/vacancy in the Na interlayers, as water molecules more readily penetrate the electrodes in a charged state, while the tendency for water uptake does not increase with Na+ extraction. The surface of the electrodes sees Mn2+ formation during the initial discharge process, while redox reactions primarily occur between Mn3+ and Mn4+ in the bulk. The incorporation of copper into the transition metal layer influences the Na+/vacancy arrangement and reduces Mn2+ formation on the Na0.7Mn0.9Cu0.1O2 electrode, leading to improved air stability and enhanced storage properties.

The O3 structure in SIB cathodes often experiences phase transitions and changes in lattice parameters, which can increase voltage hysteresis and reduce energy efficiency. Considering cost concerns that hinder the widespread use of SIBs for large-scale energy storage, we investigate Co/Ni-free NaxCu0.18Fe0.3Mn0.52O2 (x = 0.8, 0.85, 0.9) and suggest an effective approach to minimize voltage hysteresis. Our findings indicate that at a Na content of 0.8, the energy efficiency peaks at 95.4% after activation (operating within 2.5-4.0 V, 50 mA g-1, across 50 cycles), with commendable capacity retention (approximately 0.056% loss per cycle). Further analysis shows that Na0.8Cu0.18Fe0.3Mn0.52O2 follows a smooth O3-P3 phase transition without experiencing changes in the O3 phase lattice parameters. The crucial factor is the formation of an O3/P3 composite. This study offers a straightforward method for designing high energy efficiency O3-type cathodes and may inspire exploration of layered oxides with elevated O3/P3 critical Na content through element modification.

Layered O3-type sodium oxides (NaMO2, where M is a transition metal) typically undergo an O3-P3 phase transition at a low redox voltage of about 3 V (vs. Na+/Na) during sodium extraction and insertion. Consequently, nearly 50% of their total capacity is concentrated in this low voltage range, resulting in inadequate energy density for sodium-ion battery (NIB) cathodes. Developing high-voltage O3-type cathodes is challenging because increasing the phase-transition voltage through structural adjustments is difficult. We introduce a new type of O3 sodium insertion material for NIBs. The formulated O3-type Na0.7 Ni0.35 Sn0.65 O2 material achieves the highest redox potential of 3.7 V (vs. Na+/Na) among known O3-type materials based on the Ni2+/Ni3+ pair. This is due to the increased Ni-O bond ionicity from reduced orbital overlap between transition metals and oxygen in the MO2 layers. This work offers an orbital-level insight into the operating potentials of nominal redox pairs for O3-NaMO2 cathodes, proposing a strategy to customize electrodes for enhanced performance.

Sodium-ion batteries (SiB) are viewed as a viable alternative to the existing Lithium-ion batteries (LiBs). Despite this potential, SiB technology is still in its infancy, with a broad array of developmental challenges...

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are a promising option for developing cost-effective and safe energy storage solutions to meet significant energy storage needs. In this study, we have developed manganese oxide (α-MnO2) nanorods for use in SIB applications. The crystal structure, which plays an essential role in achieving high-performance energy storage, has been thoroughly examined for the metal oxide cathode. The process of sodium intercalation into the α-MnO2 matrix was investigated using theoretical density functional theory (DFT) studies. These studies suggest that Na ions can diffuse easily through the MnO2 lattice with a favorable low diffusion barrier of 0.21 eV. MnO2, when utilized as a cathode material in SIBs, demonstrated a moderate capacity of 109 mAh·g–1 at a C/20 current rate and impressive cycle life retention of 58.6% after 800 cycles in a NaPF6/EC+DMC (5% FEC) electrolyte. Notably, it exhibited a significantly higher capacity of 181 mAh·g–1 at a C/20 current rate in a NaClO4/PC (5% FEC) electrolyte, although it experienced rapid capacity fading of 11.5% after 800 cycles. Our research indicates that the enhanced cycling performance and efficient charge-discharge behavior are attributable to the high crystallinity and hierarchical nanorod morphology of MnO2.

Layered manganese-based cathode materials are highly valued for their substantial specific capacities in sodium ion batteries. However, their cycling stability and rate capability are often compromised by the Jahn-Teller effect and unavoidable phase transitions. In this study, we present a Mo-substituted P2-type manganese oxide nanoplate cathode with an oriented stacking structure and exposed {010} active facets. This modified cathode demonstrates impressive capacity retention of 87.8% after 1200 cycles at 10C (2000 mA g-1). It also boasts a high specific power density of 530 W Kg-1, a specific discharge capacity of 143.9 mA h g-1 at 1C, and 89.6% capacity retention after 100 cycles. These outstanding electrochemical performances are attributed to the effective chemical modification and the distinctive structural attributes of the manganese oxide nanoplate. Mo-substitution enhances the cathode by increasing lattice space and the average oxidation state, facilitating Na+ diffusion, curbing the Jahn-Teller effect, and bolstering structural stability, which collectively extend the cycling life. Additionally, the multilayer oriented stacking structure with exposed {010} facets enhances surface active site availability and reduces the Na+ diffusion path, thereby improving rate capability.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are emerging as a top contender to complement lithium-ion batteries and broaden the battery market. Nonetheless, developing cathode materials for SIBs that boast high-rate performance and enduring cycle stability remains a significant hurdle. Addressing this issue, we introduce a method to improve rate and cycling performance by incorporating an ordered bicontinuous porous structure in SIB cathode materials. Prussian blue analogues (PBAs) are chosen due to their promising potential as SIB cathode materials. Their 3D continuous channels facilitate swift Na+ ion diffusion, and the inherent mechanical stability of their bicontinuous architecture contributes to their outstanding rate capability (80 mAh g−1 at 2.5 A g−1) and extensive cycling longevity (>3000 cycles at 0.5 A g−1), achieving premier levels among reported PBA-based cathode materials. This research introduces a novel approach to enhancing ion diffusion kinetics in rechargeable battery electrodes and offers a framework for addressing electrode degradation caused by high-stress concentrations during ion storage.

In layered oxide cathodes of lithium-ion batteries, cation migration occurs frequently due to the comparable ionic radii of lithium and transition metals (TMs). Despite a significant difference in ionic radii between sodium and TMs, layered cathodes in sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) also experience TM migration to the sodium layer, causing substantial electrochemical degradation. To investigate the cause of TM migration in layered SIB cathodes, NaCrO2, a representative cathode material with significant TM migration, was selected as a model. It was determined that TM migration originates from random desodiation, followed by the formation of a sodium-free layer at high charge potentials. A co-doping method incorporating Ru and Ti was devised to mitigate this problem. In this approach, Ru is doped and oxidized to promote selective desodiation, while Ti serves as an inactive pillar to prevent full desodiation in Ru-containing TM layers. This technique helps suppress the formation of sodium-free layers and improves electrochemical performance.

P2-type Na2/3Ni1/3Mn2/3O2 (NNMO) is an attractive cathode material for sodium-ion batteries due to its theoretically high capacity and voltage, enabling significant energy storage density. Despite these advantages, its cycling stability is compromised by an unfavorable P2-O2 phase transition. To address this, Fe3+ ions are introduced into the NNMO lattice, creating Na2/3Ni1/3Mn2/3-xFexO2 (x = 0, 1/24, 1/12, 1/8, 1/6). This modification effectively stabilizes the P2 crystalline structure. In these Fe-substituted materials, both Ni2+/Ni4+ and Fe3+/Fe4+ couples are involved in redox reactions, and the P2-O2 phase transition is significantly suppressed during cycling, as demonstrated by ex situ X-ray diffraction. Consequently, the optimized Na2/3Ni1/3Mn7/12Fe1/12O2 (1/12-NNMF) exhibits prolonged cycling stability, with a fading rate of 0.05% per cycle over 300 cycles at 5 C. Additionally, 1/12-NNMF demonstrates strong rate capabilities (65 mA h g-1 at 25 C) and excellent low-temperature performance (94% capacity retention at -25 °C after 80 cycles) due to improved Na diffusion from Fe doping, as indicated by electrode kinetics studies. Importantly, when combined with an LS-Sb@G anode, 1/12-NNMF shows outstanding sodium-ion full-cell performance, suggesting its potential for practical applications.

With the rising production and use of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), recycling used LIBs has become essential for environmental, economic, and health reasons. The leaching behavior of nickel (Ni), manganese (Mn), cobalt (Co), aluminum (Al), and copper (Cu) from processed cathode active materials extracted from commercial LIB packs in hybrid electric vehicles has been studied using ammoniacal leaching agents. These agents include ammonia, ammonium carbonate, and ammonium sulfite. Ammonium sulfite serves as a reductant to improve leaching kinetics, especially for Ni and Co. Additionally, ammonium carbonate functions as a pH buffer, maintaining a stable pH in the leaching solution during the process. Co and Cu are fully leachable, whereas Mn and Al show minimal leaching, and Ni demonstrates moderate efficiency. The cathode active materials are identified as composites of LiMn2O4, LiCoxMnyNizO2, Al2O3, and C, while the leach residue comprises LiNixMnyCozO2, LiMn2O4, Al2O3, MnCO3, and Mn oxides. Ammoniacal leaching of Co is considered advantageous over traditional acid leaching as it reduces the expenses associated with sodium hydroxide used to raise the leaching solution's pH and eliminates the need for separate Mn and Al removal steps.

The 2019 Nobel Prize in Chemistry recognized the groundbreaking work of three individuals in the development of the modern lithium-ion battery. Professor Arumugam Manthiram reviews the progression of cathode chemistry, highlighting the three key categories of oxide cathode materials, with a focus on the crucial solid-state chemistry that has driven these developments. For nearly thirty years, lithium-ion batteries have fueled the growth of portable electronics and are currently advancing vehicle electrification and beginning to penetrate the utility sector. The rise and preeminence of lithium-ion batteries are attributed to their superior energy density over other rechargeable battery systems, achieved through the innovation of high-energy density electrode materials. Central to this progress has been basic scientific research in solid-state chemistry and physics, particularly prominent in the 1970s and 1980s. In light of the Nobel Prize awarded for the evolution of lithium-ion batteries, it is insightful to revisit the advancements in cathode chemistry that have underpinned modern lithium-ion technology. This review article offers an analysis of how fundamental research has contributed to the discovery, refinement, and strategic design of three principal categories of oxide cathodes for lithium-ion batteries, along with a personal outlook on the future of this significant field.

Oxygen vacancies (OVs) are inherent defects within transition metal (TM) oxides, significantly influencing their physicochemical attributes. TM oxides are frequently employed as cathodes in lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), yet the impact of OVs in this area remains inadequately understood. In this study, we explore the activity of OVs within a single-crystal LIB cathode during the non-equilibrium states of charging and discharging. Our findings reveal that microcracks develop in a single crystal due to OV condensation along specific crystallographic orientations, resulting from the ongoing migration of OVs and TM ions. Furthermore, a deeper understanding of OV presence and diffusion in metal oxides helps clarify many conventional mechanisms behind LIB capacity fading and presents new prospects for electrochemical applications.

We present an innovative design for Ge-based electrodes featuring three-dimensional (3-D) spherical microflowers composed of crystalline nanorod networks atop robust one-dimensional (1-D) nanostems, which are directly grown on a metallic current collector using a straightforward thermal evaporation method. The Ge nanorod networks autonomously replicate their tetrahedron shapes, creating a lattice-like inner network similar to a diamond cubic structure. Following etching and the application of a carbon coating, these transformed Ge nanostructures display enhanced electrical conductivity and resistance to progressive degradation, leading to exceptional electrochemical performance when used as anode materials in LIBs. Notably, they maintain a charge capacity retention of 96% after 100 cycles and achieve a high specific capacity of 1360 mA h g^−1 at 1 C. Moreover, they exhibit high-rate capability with reversible capacities of 1080 and 850 mA h g^−1 at 5 and 10 C rates, respectively. The superior electrochemical performance is likely due to the rapid electron transport and effective strain accommodation provided by the carbon-filled Ge microflower-on-nanostem hybrid electrode.

A new method has been devised for extracting transition metals, recovering lithium, and regenerating cathode materials using straightforward co-extraction and co-precipitation processes. The process successfully co-extracts and separates 100% of manganese, 99% of cobalt, and 85% of nickel from lithium using D2EHPA in kerosene. Subsequently, lithium is retrieved from the raffinate as Li2CO3 with a 99.2% purity via a precipitation technique. The organic load phase is then stripped with 0.5M H2SO4, leading to the direct regeneration of the cathode material LiNi1/3Co1/3Mn1/3O2 from the stripping solution through a co-precipitation process without separating the metals individually. This regenerated cathode material has a microspherical morphology free of impurities, meets China's LiNi1/3Co1/3Mn1/3O2 production standards, and demonstrates excellent electrochemical performance. Additionally, a waste battery management model is implemented to ensure a steady supply of materials for recycling spent batteries.

Lithium-ion diffusion times within the cathode of a lithium-ion battery have been examined with a spatial precision below 100 nanometres. The ingress and egress of lithium ions within electrodes are critical to lithium-ion battery functionality. While extensively studied at the device scale, nanoscale understanding within grain clusters, individual grains, and defects remains limited. In this study, we investigate the spatial variations of lithium-ion diffusion times in the LiCoO_2 battery-cathode material at a ∼100 nm resolution. This is achieved using an atomic force microscope to both redistribute lithium ions and assess the consequent cathode deformation. The study reveals a relationship between diffusion and individual grains and grain boundaries, indicating that the diffusion coefficient is higher for specific grain orientations and single-grain boundaries. These insights enhance the understanding of the nanoscale mechanisms that underpin the operation of lithium-ion batteries.

The exploration of high-volumetric-capacity electrode materials capable of reversible insertion and extraction of large K+ ions poses a significant challenge. Tellurium (Te) is a potential electrode for K+ ion storage because of its high volumetric capacity, as seen in lithium and sodium-ion batteries, along with its inherently good electronic conductivity. However, the charge storage capability and mechanism of Te in potassium-ion batteries (KIBs) were previously unclear. In this study, a novel K–Te battery is developed, uncovering that the K+ ion storage mechanism in Te involves a two-electron conversion reaction of 2K + Te ↔ K2Te, leading to a high theoretical volumetric capacity of 2619 mAh cm−3. As a result, tellurium/porous carbon electrodes, when fabricated strategically, demonstrate an ultrahigh reversible volumetric capacity of 2493.13 mAh cm−3 at 0.5 C (considering Te), a high-rate capacity of 783.13 mAh cm−3 at 15 C, and exceptional long-term cycling stability over 1000 cycles at 5 C. This outstanding electrochemical performance confirms the viability of using Te as a high-volumetric-capacity active material for K+ ion storage, thus promoting the practical application of KIBs.

High-tap-density silicon nanomaterials are highly sought after as anode materials for lithium-ion batteries due to their reduced surface area and minimal first-cycle loss. Despite this, creating a suitable polymeric binder for these materials is challenging. Binders must adhere to the limited surface area to cope with significant volume changes during cycling; additionally, the low porosities and small pore sizes inherent to this material hinder lithium-ion transport. This paper presents a novel binder, poly(1-pyrenemethyl methacrylate-co-methacrylic acid) (PPyMAA), which enables a high-tap-density nanosilicon electrode to cycle stably, achieving an initial cycle efficiency of 82%, which increases to 87% when combined with graphite materials. The inclusion of MAA acid groups does not alter the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) characteristics or diminish the adhesion capabilities of the PPy homopolymer. Our single-molecule force microscopy measurements of PPyMAA show adhesion strength comparable to that of traditional polymers like homopolyacrylic acid (PAA), while also being electronically conductive. The synergy of conductivity and adhesion provided by the MAA and pyrene copolymer contributes to the favorable cycling performance of the high-tap-density silicon electrode.

A simple method is presented for creating a layered SiCN-MoS_2 structure through the pyrolysis of polysilazane-functionalized MoS_2 flakes. The layered morphology and transformation from polymer to ceramic on MoS_2 surfaces were confirmed using electron microscopy and spectroscopic techniques. When tested as a thick film electrode in a Li-ion battery half-cell, SiCN-MoS_2 exhibited the typical three-stage reaction with enhanced cycling stability and capacity retention compared to pure MoS_2. The impact of SiCN on the conversion reaction capacity of the Li/MoS_2 system was minimal, but it significantly reduced Li-irreversibility caused by electrolyte decomposition. This is reasoned to contribute to the reduced initial cycle loss and improved capacity retention. As a self-supporting paper electrode at a mass loading of 6 mg·cm^−2, SiCN-MoS_2 demonstrated superior performance, regaining its initial charge capacity of approximately 530 mAh·g^−1 when the current density was lowered to 100 mA·g^−1 after operating at 2400 mA·g^−1 (192 mAh·g^−1). In contrast, electrodes with cycled MoS_2 exhibited mud-cracks and film delamination, whereas SiCN-MoS_2 electrodes remained intact, coated with a uniform solid electrolyte interphase. Overall, our findings indicate that interfacing at the molecular level with precursor-derived SiCN effectively suppresses metal-sulfide/electrolyte degradation reactions at low discharge potentials.

Developing new battery materials poses a major challenge due to the need to understand their fundamental mechanisms and degradation processes. Due to their microscopically inhomogeneous nature, it is essential to have characterization tools that provide operando and localized information from individual grains and particles. We present a method that allows for imaging the nanoscale distribution of ions during the electrochemical charging of a battery in a transmission electron microscope liquid flow cell. Utilizing valence energy-loss spectroscopy, we track both solvated and intercalated ions, identifying electronic structure fingerprints of solvated ions using ab initio nonlinear response theory. This new approach, including an electrochemical cell holder, nanoscale spectroscopy, and theory, enables us to determine the lithiation state of a LiFePO4 electrode and its surrounding aqueous electrolyte in real-time with nanoscale resolution during electrochemical charging and discharging. We monitor lithium transfer between the electrode and electrolyte and image the charging dynamics in the cathode. We also observe that competing delithiation mechanisms, such as core-shell and anisotropic growth, happen simultaneously in different particles under identical conditions. This technique provides a general method for operando nanoscale imaging of electrochemically active ions in both electrodes and electrolytes across diverse electrical energy storage systems.

This article provides a summary of the latest advancements in lithium-ion battery anode materials. It underscores the crucial role anode materials have in influencing the overall efficiency of lithium-ion batteries. The article also explores various anode materials, detailing the unique performance features of each in practical applications. Furthermore, it compiles and evaluates the critical research limitations and obstacles encountered during development. Lastly, it offers guidance for future research paths in anode materials, covering aspects like new material types, structural innovations, and electrode reactions, with a special focus on promising innovative approaches.

Although high entropy oxides (HEOs) have been examined as potential conversion-type negative electrodes in Li-ion batteries, the specific roles of the individual elements remain unclear. This study dissects the behavior of each element during electrochemical cycling and relates it to the nanoscale structure. HEOs, characterized by their chemically disordered multi-cation structures, are receiving significant attention as negative electrode materials for batteries. Their excellent electrochemical performance is believed to be due to high-entropy stabilization and the so-called 'cocktail effect.' However, at room temperature, the configurational entropy of the HEO is thermodynamically only metastable and does not drive structural reversibility during conversion reactions, nor has the 'cocktail effect' been previously elucidated. This research describes the synergistic interaction of multi-cations in the HEO Mg_0.2Co_0.2Ni_0.2Cu_0.2Zn_0.2O at atomic and nanoscale levels during electrochemical reactions and clarifies the 'cocktail effect.' More electronegative elements form an electrochemically inactive 3D metallic nano-network that facilitates electron transport. The electrochemically inactive cation supports an oxide nanophase, semi-coherent with the metallic phase, ready to host Li^+ ions. This self-organized nanostructure allows stable cycling of micron-sized particles, eliminating the need for nanoscale modifications typically required by conventional metal oxides in battery applications. This indicates that elemental diversity is crucial for optimizing multi-cation electrode materials.

Iron pyrite (FeS2) is a potential cathode material for lithium-ion batteries due to its low cost and extremely high energy density (1671 Wh kg-1). Despite this, its reaction mechanisms remain a topic of debate. In our study, we discover that, contrary to the traditional view of forming an intermediate phase Li2FeS2 followed by Fe/Li2S composites at initial discharge, FeS2 either undergoes a one-step reaction (FeS2 → Fe + Li2S) or a two-step reaction (FeS2 → FeS + Li2S → Fe + Li2S), depending on the current rate and temperature. During charging, the process involves a two-step reaction: a phase transition from Fe + Li2S to FeS occurs at approximately 1.74 V, followed by the formation of elemental sulfur (Li2S → S, 2.30 V). FeS forms as a mackinawite phase at the Li2S interface through hetero-epitaxial growth. In subsequent cycles, a combined reaction behavior of FeS and S is observed. The mechanism indicates that FeS2 faces challenges associated with conversion reaction materials like FeS and S, which include significant volume changes, voltage hysteresis, and polysulfide dissolution. These insights may enhance the understanding of the intrinsic capacity fading of FeS2 and offer strategies for improving its electrochemical performance.

Silicon is a highly promising candidate for lithium-ion battery anodes due to its high theoretical capacity, abundance, and established infrastructure. Recently, Si nanostructure-based anodes have seen significant advancements in design and processing. However, developing low-cost, scalable methods for producing these nanostructures remains a challenge, hindering their widespread use. In this study, we demonstrate that Si nanoparticles with controlled sizes can be produced in large quantities from low-quality Si sources via a scalable high-energy mechanical milling process. We conducted a systematic analysis of Si nanoparticles sourced from two primary low-grade Si materials: metallurgical silicon (~99 wt% Si, $1/kg) and ferrosilicon (~83 wt% Si, $0.6/kg). Ferrosilicon-derived nanoparticles contain FeSi2, which acts as a buffer to minimize mechanical fractures from volume expansion, whereas those from metallurgical Si exhibit higher capacity and superior kinetic properties due to their higher purity and enhanced electronic transport. Both ferrosilicon and metallurgical Si nanoparticles, after carbon coating, showcase over 100 stable deep cycles with reversible capacities of 1360 mAh g(-1) and 1205 mAh g(-1), respectively. Consequently, our method offers a novel approach for the cost-effective, energy-efficient, large-scale production of functional Si electrode materials.

The study demonstrates that the model cathode material Li_2Ru_0.5Mn_0.5O_3 exhibits ruthenium segregation and exsolution at the reconstructed oxide surface post-cycling, initiating a progressive degradation process. These findings open up new possibilities for selecting dopants to stabilize the cathode surface. Understanding the degradation mechanism of lithium-rich cathode materials is challenging due to the interplay of chemical and structural changes, despite its significance. Advanced electron microscopy, synchrotron X-ray techniques, and first-principle calculations were employed to investigate the compound Li_2Ru_0.5Mn_0.5O_3, which contains a 4d element. Surprisingly, after cycling, ruthenium forms metallic nanoclusters on the reconstructed surface. Our calculations indicate that this unexpected segregation of ruthenium metal arises due to its thermodynamic insolubility in the oxygen-depleted surface, leading to disruption and porous structure formation. This research highlights the necessity of studying the thermodynamic stability of the reconstructed film on cathode materials and provides theoretical insights for selecting manganese-substituting elements in both lithium-rich and stoichiometric layer-layer compounds to stabilize the cathode surface.

Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries, with a theoretical capacity of 1675 mAh g-1, can offer 5-10 times the capacity of current commercial lithium-ion batteries. However, their rapid capacity degradation due to polysulfide dissolution in typical electrolytes is a significant drawback. This paper suggests using a cathode material composite of amorphous MoS3 and reduced graphene oxide (r-GO) as an alternative to pure sulfur-based cathodes. To improve electrode kinetics and stability, microsized MoS3 sheets are pulverized into nanosheets and coated with an ultrathin nano-SEI layer through in situ electrochemical methods. These nanosheets are then securely attached using the oxygen functional groups of r-GO. This treatment results in the MoS3/r-GO electrode exhibiting performance superior to pure sulfur electrodes, maintaining a capacity of around 900 mAh g-1 at 5C for 2500 cycles without fading. Furthermore, a full-cell battery using the MoS3/r-GO cathode paired with a silicon-carbon composite anode achieves a 3-5 times higher energy density (1725 Wh kg-1/7100 Wh L-1) compared to current LIBs.

Recovering cobalt and lithium from spent lithium-ion batteries is crucial to prevent environmental pollution and address resource shortages. This study proposes a hydrometallurgical technique for recovering lithium fluoride. Initially, lithium and cobalt are selectively leached into a solution using formic acid and hydrogen peroxide. By examining factors such as leaching temperature, duration, stoichiometric ratio, H2O2 concentration, and solid-to-liquid ratio, the leaching efficiencies for Li and Co were found to be 99.90% and 99.96%, respectively. Additionally, an evaluation of leaching kinetics and the calculation of apparent activation energies showed that the leaching process aligns well with chemical control mechanisms. Subsequent fractional precipitation effectively yielded lithium fluoride with a high purity of 99.0%, facilitating the recovery of materials from spent lithium-ion batteries.

Porous silicon nanowires have been extensively examined for a range of applications; however, their use in energy storage is sparsely documented. This study presents both experimental and theoretical investigations into porous doped silicon nanowires produced through direct etching of boron-doped silicon wafers. By using alginate as a binder, these porous silicon nanowires showed excellent electrochemical performance and longevity as an anode material in lithium-ion batteries. Remarkably, after 250 cycles, the capacity remains stable over 2000, 1600, and 1100 mAh/g at current rates of 2, 4, and 18 A/g, respectively, indicating high structural stability attributed to the nanowires' significant porosity and electron conductivity. A mathematical model incorporating lithium ion diffusion and strain from lithium intercalation was applied to analyze the impact of porosity and pore size on structural stability. Simulations revealed that silicon with high porosity and larger pore sizes contributes to stabilizing the structure throughout charge/discharge cycles.

Managing the morphology of nanostructured silicon is essential for enhancing the structural stability and electrochemical performance of lithium-ion batteries. Using removable or sacrificial templates is a straightforward and efficient method to create hollow materials. In this study, we present the synthesis of mesoporous silicon hollow nanocubes (m-Si HCs) derived from a metal-organic framework (MOF) to be used as an anode material with exceptional electrochemical properties. The architecture of m-Si HCs, featuring a mesoporous external shell (~15 nm) and an internal void (~60 nm), effectively accommodates volume changes and reduces diffusion-induced stress/strain during repeated cycling. Furthermore, this cube structure increases the electrolyte contact area through its exposed active sites, enhancing the transport of Li ions. The meticulously designed m-Si HC with carbon coating achieves a high reversible capacity of 1728 mAhg^-1 with an initial Coulombic efficiency of 80.1% after the first cycle and demonstrates an excellent rate capability of over 1050 mAhg^-1 even at a 15 C-rate. Notably, the m-Si HC anode significantly minimizes electrode swelling to approximately 47% after 100 cycles and maintains excellent cycle stability of 850 mAhg^-1 after 800 cycles at a 1 C-rate. Additionally, a full cell (2.9 mAhcm^-2) equipped with an m-Si HC-graphite anode and LiCoO2 cathode shows impressive cycle retention of 72% after 100 cycles at a 0.2 C-rate.

The lithium storage capabilities of silicon (Si) can be improved by alloying with germanium (Ge), owing to Ge's excellent electronic and ionic conductivity. In this study, we synthesized a three-dimensional nanoporous (3D-NP) SiGe alloy as a high-performance anode for lithium-ion batteries (LIB) using a dealloying technique, employing a ternary AlSiGe ribbon as the precursor material. By adjusting the sacrificial aluminum content in the precursor, the morphology and porosity of the resulting SiGe alloy can be precisely controlled. At an aluminum content of 80%, the resulting 3D-NP SiGe exhibits a uniformly coral-like structure characterized by continuous ligaments, as well as hierarchical micropores and mesopores. This structure results in a high reversible capacity of 1158 mA h g-1 after 150 cycles at a current density of 1000 mA g-1, with excellent rate performance. This strategy could provide direction for optimizing nanostructures and facilitate the mass production of materials for energy storage.

Free-standing electrode (FSE) designs have the potential to significantly enhance the gravimetric and volumetric energy density of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) by removing the unnecessary weight and volume of traditional metal foil current collectors. However, existing methods to fabricate FSEs often lack adequate mechanical stability, electrochemical performance, or suitability for industrial application. This study introduces a scalable camphene-assisted fabrication technique that permits the concurrent casting and structuring of FSEs using standard LIB materials, achieving performance that surpasses that of traditional foil-cast electrodes. These electrodes are porous, lightweight, and durable, enhancing rate performance by bettering mass and ion transport within the interconnected conductive carbon pore network while removing current collectors for efficient and stable Li+ storage over more than 1000 cycles in half-cells, with increased gravimetric and areal energy densities. Relative to their foil-cast counterparts, the electrodes created using camphene display approximately 1.5 times higher gravimetric energy density, improved rate capability, and better capacity retention in coin-cell setups. A full cell composed of both free-standing anode and cathode achieved over 250 cycles with over 80% capacity retention at an areal capacity of 0.73 mA h/cm². This fabrication method, indifferent to active material, can be customized to shape flexible, current-collector-free electrodes, enabling optimization of LIBs for either high power or high energy density Li+ storage. Additionally, this approach offers an electrode fabrication method suitable for other electrochemical technologies and advanced manufacturing techniques.

Traditional nickel-rich cathode materials exhibit reaction heterogeneity during electrochemical cycling, especially at elevated temperatures, due to their polycrystalline nature and secondary particle morphology. Although there has been extensive research on the morphological evolution of these polycrystalline nickel-rich materials, real-world investigations at the electrode and cell levels remain limited. In this study, an inherent limitation of polycrystalline nickel-rich cathode materials within high-energy full-cells is identified under conditions typical of industrial electrode fabrication. Due to their unstable chemo-mechanical properties, these nickel-rich materials degrade in the longitudinal direction of high-energy electrodes even after the initial cycle. This uneven degradation at the electrode level is due to the excessive utilization of active materials on the surface, leading to a significantly non-uniform potential distribution during prolonged cycling. This issue further decreases the reversibility of lithium ions. Therefore, considering the degradation issues of polycrystalline nickel-rich materials, the study proposes utilizing a durable single-crystalline LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 as an effective alternative to reduce localized overutilization of active materials. Implementing this change can stabilize the electrochemical performance of high-energy lithium-ion cells, achieving exceptional capacity retention above approximately 80% after 1000 cycles at 45 °C.

The low performance of cathode materials is a significant challenge for the use of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) in advanced portable electronics, hybrid electric vehicles, and electric vehicles. This study introduces a flexible oxygen-deficient LiV3O8 (D-LVO) nanosheet, created using a simple oxygen-deficient hydrothermal method followed by thermal annealing in an argon atmosphere. As a LIB cathode material, the synthesized D-LVO nanosheets exhibit exceptional capacity performance across various current densities, achieving capacities of 335, 317, 278, 246, 209, 167, and 133 mA h g-1 at 50, 100, 200, 500, 1000, 2000, and 4000 mA g-1, respectively. They also demonstrate excellent lithium-ion storage stability, retaining over 88% of the initial reversible capacity after 200 cycles at 1000 mA g-1. The superior electrochemical performance is primarily attributed to the presence of tetravalent V (~15% V4+) and corresponding oxygen vacancies in the LiV3O8 nanosheets. This modification results in an intrinsic electrical conductivity that is more than an order of magnitude higher and a lithium-ion diffusion coefficient nearly two orders of magnitude greater than that of LiV3O8 lacking detectable V4+ (N-LVO), facilitating easy lithium-ion diffusion, swift phase transition, and excellent electrochemical reversibility. Additionally, the D-LVO nanosheets' more uniform nanostructure and larger specific surface area compared to N-LVO may enhance electrolyte penetration and provide additional reaction sites for rapid lithium-ion diffusion during charging and discharging.

Lithium transition-metal oxides such as LiMn2O4 and LiMO2 (where M includes Ni, Mn, Co, etc.) are extensively used as cathode materials in lithium-ion batteries due to their significant capacity and energy density. Despite this, various processes at the cathode/electrolyte interface result in performance degradation. A primary failure mechanism is the dissolution of transition metals from the cathode. This study presents findings by integrating scanning electrochemical microscopy with inductively coupled plasma (ICP) and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopies to analyze cathode degradation products. We utilize a LiMn2O4 (LMO) thin film as a model cathode to observe the Mn dissolution process, avoiding the complexities of conductive additives and polymer binders. Our work characterizes the electrochemical behavior of LMO degradation products in different electrolytes, utilizing ICP and EPR, to gain insights into the properties of Mn complexes formed post-metal dissolution. The results indicate that the type of lithium salt anions in our electrolyte systems [ClO4–, PF6–, and (CF3SO2)2N–] significantly influences the Mn dissolution process and the electrochemical behavior of the resulting Mn complexes. This suggests that Mn dissolution is at least partially dependent on the lithium salt anion.

Porous hierarchical NiMn2O4/C nanostructures with a tremella-like form are synthesized through a straightforward solvothermal process followed by calcination. When used as anodes in lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), these NiMn2O4/C nanostructures deliver outstanding specific capacity and demonstrate excellent long-term cycling stability even at high current densities. They achieve a stabilized discharge capacity of 2130 mA h g(-1) over 350 cycles at a current density of 1000 mA g(-1). Furthermore, after 1500 cycles, the capacity remains significantly high at 1773 mA h g(-1) at a current density of 4000 mA g(-1), which is nearly five times higher than graphite's theoretical capacity. The porous NiMn2O4/C hierarchical design ensures ample electrolyte contact and facilitates rapid three-dimensional Li(+) diffusion, significantly enhancing NiMn2O4/C's capacity through interfacial storage.

Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are extensively utilized for energy storage in various applications, including electric vehicles. Despite their widespread use, LIBs still encounter challenges like limited energy density, durability issues, slow charging speeds, and safety concerns. Nanomaterials, characterized by having at least one nanoscale dimension, offer potential solutions by enhancing the properties and performance of electrode materials. This study examines the recent advancements and challenges associated with using nanomaterials in LIB electrodes. It discusses the pros and cons of various nanomaterials, such as nanoparticles, nanocoatings, nanotubes, and nanocomposites, and how they influence the electrochemical performance of LIBs. Additionally, the study highlights key issues and future directions for the development of LIBs leveraging nanomaterials. The goal of this research is to offer a comprehensive overview and insights into the application of nanomaterials to enhance LIB performance.

To date, no design principles have been established for creating solid electrolytes with lithium-ion conductivity sufficient to replace liquid electrolytes and push the limits of current lithium-ion battery performance and configuration. By utilizing the characteristics of high-entropy materials, we have engineered a highly ion-conductive solid electrolyte by enhancing the compositional complexity of an established lithium superionic conductor. This approach removes ion migration barriers while preserving the superionic conduction structural framework. The newly fabricated phase with increased compositional complexity exhibited enhanced ion conductivity. We demonstrated that this highly conductive solid electrolyte facilitates the charging and discharging of a thick lithium-ion battery cathode at ambient temperature, indicating its potential to reshape traditional battery configurations. Solid electrolytes have been created to enable solid-state batteries to rival liquid electrolyte batteries, but ensuring effective electrode contact remains challenging, which restricts the practical thickness of electrodes. Li et al. leveraged high-entropy material principles to enhance the properties of existing electrolytes through targeted partial substitution of additional elements. They showcase the integration of their materials into a cathode structure, achieving the required high ionic conductivity for solid-state battery use. Adding complexity to a known crystal framework permits the use of millimeter-thick battery electrodes.

In recent years, "fast-charging" lithium-ion batteries have attracted significant attention due to their potential applications in energy storage fields such as electric vehicles, power grids, and subsea systems. However, the high energy density of these batteries may be compromised under fast-charging conditions. The crystal structure of electrode materials plays a pivotal role in determining electrode performance. Utilizing anode materials with low diffusion barriers could enhance the "fast-charging" capabilities of lithium-ion batteries. This Review initially outlines the principles of "fast-charging" in lithium-ion batteries and the ion diffusion pathways within the crystal lattice. It then assesses the potential of various crystal-structured "fast-charging" anode materials, aiming to identify those that offer stability, safety, and longevity and address challenges related to high power and safety. The Review also summarizes recent advancements in "fast-charging" anode materials, including advancements in preparation methods for novel morphologies and techniques for performance enhancement. Additionally, it provides an outlook on ongoing breakthroughs in "fast-charging" anode materials for lithium-ion batteries. Intercalated materials, such as those based on niobium, carbon, titanium, and vanadium, while offering good cycling stability, are often hampered by poor electronic conductivity and theoretical specific capacity. Enhancing the electrical conductivity of these materials is seen as a promising approach to achieving fast charging. Conversely, conversion-type transition metal oxides and phosphorus-based materials, known for their high theoretical specific capacity, often experience considerable volume changes during charge and discharge cycles. Mitigating this volume expansion could significantly advance their application in fast-charging batteries.

Composite electrodes, which incorporate active materials, carbon, and a binder, are extensively utilized in lithium-ion batteries. The electrode reaction tends to occur in regions with lower resistance, leading to a reaction distribution within these composite electrodes. We examine how this reaction distribution relates to depth direction and both electronic and ionic conductivity in composite electrodes with varying porosities. Using two-dimensional X-ray absorption spectroscopy, we observe that reaction distribution occurs more significantly in electrodes with lower porosity. Our newly developed 6-probe method is capable of measuring electronic and ionic conductivity in composite electrodes. It reveals that ionic conductivity decreases in low-porosity electrodes, which influences the reaction distribution and overall performance of these composite electrodes.

Silicon anodes have attracted global attention for next-generation lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) because of their high specific capacity. Nevertheless, silicon anodes face challenges in replacing graphite anodes widely due to issues like inevitable volume expansion and SEI film formation during lithiation and delithiation. Advancements in nanotechnology have significantly accelerated the development of silicon anodes. This paper examines how nanotechnology is utilized in silicon anodes to enhance battery performance. By minimizing the volume of the silicon anode, its specific surface area is increased, effectively mitigating volume expansion. A smaller negative electrode also reduces the travel distance for lithium ions, which substantially boosts the efficiency of the silicon anode. Currently, key silicon nano-anode materials include nanoparticles, nanowires, nanosheets, nanotubes, and nanoporous materials, among others. This review aims to provide a comprehensive introduction to the potential of nano-silicon anodes. It explores pure silicon nanoparticles and nanowires, as well as new nanomaterials formed by combining these with graphite, graphene, metals, and more.

Hydrogen boride (HB) has been successfully synthesized with a pseudo-two-dimensional sheet structure and is theoretically anticipated to be a highly effective negative electrode material for alkali metal ion batteries. This study is the inaugural experimental investigation of HB's properties as a negative electrode. HB was synthesized through a cation exchange process from MgB2. Its synthesis was confirmed using several spectroscopic methods, such as synchrotron radiation X-ray diffraction and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, complemented by direct transmission electron microscopy observations. The HB electrode was created by combining the HB powder with conductive carbon black and a polymer binder. A test cell featuring the HB electrode as the working electrode was assembled, using lithium metal as both the counter and reference electrodes, to assess its battery electrode properties. Although the charge-discharge cycles displayed good reversibility, the observed reversible capacity was 100 ± 20 mA h g-1, which is considerably lower than theoretical expectations. Nitrogen gas adsorption tests conducted on the HB powder revealed the specific surface area, suggesting that the HB sheets were stacked. This stacking likely contributed to the diminished lithium-ion storage capacity relative to theoretical predictions.

Co3O4 is gaining attention as a potential anode material for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) owing to its high theoretical capacity of 890 mAh g-1. However, it faces challenges with poor cycling stability due to inadequate intrinsic electronic conductivity and significant volume changes during cycling. In this study, a new Co3O4/graphene (Co3O4/G) hybrid electrode is developed using electrophoretic deposition (EPD) to enhance electrochemical performance. The EPD process allows Co3O4 nanocubes to be evenly embedded between graphene sheets, creating a sandwich-like structure. This structure benefits from graphene's flexibility and numerous voids, preserving structural integrity and maintaining an effective conductive network throughout cycling. Furthermore, the electrode kinetics indicate a rapid surface-controlled lithium storage process. Consequently, the Co3O4/G hybrid electrode demonstrates high specific capacity and excellent cycling performance. In situ electrochemical XRD studies were conducted to explore the relationship between the hybrid electrode's structure and performance: (1) The presence of LixCo3O4 suggests a minimal volume change during the initial discharge. (2) The theoretical capacity of Co3O4 within the hybrid electrode is confirmed. (3) A detailed discussion is presented on the link between electrochemical performance and structural evolution of the Co3O4/G hybrid electrode.

Red phosphorus (RP) holds potential as an anode material for lithium-ion batteries due to its high theoretical capacity. However, RP experiences significant volume changes during charge/discharge cycles, which negatively affects its cycle life and its low conductivity hampers its rate performance. In this work, a straightforward solution-based method is employed to embed phosphorus into the pores of carbon hosts derived from zeolitic imidazole framework (ZIF-8) at mild temperatures. This approach transforms blocky RP into polyphosphides anions (PP, predominantly P5 -), facilitating its diffusion into the pores of the carbon host. This technique prevents the formation of indelible crystalline surface phosphorus, a common issue with traditional vapor-condensation encapsulation methods. Additionally, the ZIF-8 derived carbon hosts are highly conductive with pore sizes under 3 nm, which are effective in containing PP and mitigating volume changes. Ultimately, the phosphorus encapsulated within the ZIF-8 derived porous carbon demonstrates markedly enhanced electrochemical performance as a lithium-ion battery anode, boasting a high capacity of 786 mAh g-1 after 100 cycles at 0.1 A g-1, solid stability over 700 cycles at 1 A g-1, and an outstanding rate performance.

Layered lithium-rich cathode materials have garnered significant attention due to their high theoretical specific capacity (320 - 350 mA h g -1). However, their practical application is hindered by poor cycling stability and slow reaction kinetics. Despite a period of dormancy, efforts to advance layered lithium-rich cathode materials are anticipated to address the growing demand for high-energy-density lithium-ion batteries. This review examines recent advances and an enhanced understanding of the structural characterizations and reaction mechanisms of layered lithium-rich manganese-based cathode materials. Specifically, we extensively summarize the proposed reaction mechanisms involving both the cationic redox reactions of transition-metal ions and the anionic redox reactions of oxygen species. Lastly, we explore the opportunities and challenges in the future development of LLRM cathode materials for the next generation of lithium-ion batteries.

Rapidly charging lithium-ion batteries is essential for reducing electric vehicle charging times, yet this is challenged by graphite anodes' limited rate capability. In this study, we introduce a novel dual-gradient structure in graphite anodes, characterized by variations in particle size and electrode porosity, aimed at achieving ultra-fast charging under stringent electrode conditions. We employ a polymer binder-free slurry method to create this unique particle size-porosity dual-gradient structure in realistic graphite anodes, enabling a remarkable fast-charging capability that achieves 60% recharge in 10 minutes. Utilizing this dual-gradient graphite anode, we achieve an extremely fast-charging lithium-ion battery that reaches 60% recharge in 6 minutes with a high volumetric energy density of 701 Wh per liter at a charging rate of 6 C.

Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are prevalent in daily use, and the increasing demand for their raw materials necessitates efficient recycling processes. Recycling spent LIBs is crucial for fostering a circular economy and sourcing materials for new LIBs or other applications. Current research primarily targets the recycling of active electrode materials. Traditional recycling methods like pyro-, hydrometallurgy, and flotation have limitations, including material loss, waste production, and poor selectivity. This study investigates the application of a dielectrophoretic high-throughput filter on commercially available LiFePO4 and two types of graphite microparticles. Dielectrophoresis, an electrokinetic force dependent on volume, is typically used in microfluidics but has recently been adapted for high-throughput applications. Our findings demonstrate that graphite particles exhibit substantially higher trapping efficiency than LiFePO4 particles. The study indicates that this method can effectively separate nearly pure LiFePO4 from a graphite mixture.

All-solid-state batteries (ASSBs) hold considerable promise for delivering high power and energy densities while enhancing battery safety. Despite advancements in solid electrolytes (SEs) achieving sufficient ionic conductivities, reports on SSBs with extended operational life remain scarce. Understanding the intricate degradation mechanisms at the electrode/electrolyte interfaces is crucial for progressing towards high-performance and durable ASSBs. The lithium metal/solid electrolyte interface has gained significant attention due to the push for higher energy density, but the interface between active materials and SE particles within composite cathodes presents a particularly challenging area for research. This study employs various characterization techniques to explore the interactions at the interface between the LiCoO2 cathode and the Li10GeP2S12 solid electrolyte. To circumvent the instability issues related to Li-metal anodes, indium and Li4Ti5O12 serve as anode materials. Observations during prolonged cycling reveal capacity fading and increased impedance. Postmortem analysis using scanning transmission electron microscopy, electron energy loss spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy demonstrates that mechanical failure and degradation driven by electrochemistry at the cathode/solid electrolyte interface contribute to heightened internal resistance and capacity reduction. The findings indicate that improving the electrochemical stability of SEs and optimizing cathode/SE interfaces are essential for achieving consistent SSB performance.

A composite of hierarchical copper silicate hydrate hollow spheres and reduced graphene oxide (RGO) has been effectively created through a straightforward hydrothermal process, utilizing silica as an in situ sacrifice template. This composite's electrochemical performance as a lithium-ion battery anode was assessed for the first time. Thanks to the combined effects of its hierarchical hollow structure and conductive RGO matrix, the composite demonstrates impressive long-term performance and rate capability. It achieves a capacity of 890 mAh/g after 200 cycles at 200 mA/g, and maintains a capacity of 429 mAh/g after 800 cycles at 1000 mA/g. These findings suggest that integrating hierarchical hollow structures with conductive RGO could potentially address the volume expansion challenge in high capacity anode materials.

Recent investigations into lithium-ion battery (LIB) cathode materials utilize a wide array of experimental and theoretical methodologies to study alterations in both bulk and local chemical and electronic structures throughout electrochemical cycling (charging and discharging). Though rich in valuable chemical insights, 17O NMR spectroscopy has been underutilized in studies so far. Many LIB cathode materials feature paramagnetic ions, resulting in NMR spectra characterized by hyperfine and quadrupolar interactions, which lead to broad resonances accompanied by extensive spinning sideband manifolds. With precise analysis, these spectra can potentially disclose information concerning local structural distortions, magnetic exchange interactions, structural inhomogeneities (such as Li+ concentration gradients), and even the existence of redox-active O anions. This Perspective examines the fundamental interactions influencing 17O NMR spectroscopy of LIB cathodes and delineates how 17O NMR can be applied to clarify the structure of pristine cathodes as well as their structural transformation during cycling, thus shedding light on the challenges associated with obtaining and interpreting these spectra. The discussion also covers the role of 17O NMR in the context of anionic redox and its potential contribution to understanding charge compensation mechanisms in high-capacity cathodes, along with recommendations for utilizing 17O NMR in future research directions.

This paper presents the atomic layer deposition (ALD) of tungsten nitride using tungsten hexacarbonyl [W(CO)6] and ammonia [NH3] as precursors, exploring its application as a lithium-ion battery anode. Techniques like in situ quartz crystal microbalance (QCM), ellipsometry, and X-ray reflectivity (XRR) validate the self-limiting nature of the deposition process. The growth rate reaches approximately 0.35 Å per ALD cycle within the temperature range of 180-195 °C. In situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) vibrational spectroscopy is employed to elucidate the reaction pathways of surface-bound species following each ALD half cycle. Elemental composition and chemical states are examined via X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Initially, the deposited material is amorphous but crystallizes to h-W2N after being annealed at elevated temperatures in an ammonia environment. The material as initially deposited exhibits n-type conductivity with an average carrier concentration of around 10(20) at room temperature. Electrochemical evaluations of the deposited films suggest their potential as anode materials for Li-ion batteries. Introducing MWCNTs as a scaffold layer enhances the electrochemical storage capacity of the ALD-grown tungsten nitride (WNx). Ex situ X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis confirms a conversion-based reaction mechanism of the original material with lithium during battery operation.

The dissolution of transition metal cations into the liquid electrolyte from cathode materials, such as the dissolution of Mn ions from LiMn2O4 (LMO), negatively impacts the cycling performance of Li-ion batteries (LIBs). Although considerable attention has been given to this issue, the specifics of Mn dissolution remain unclear. In this study, a refined in-situ UV-visible absorption spectroscopy (UV-vis) technique was employed to monitor concentration changes of dissolved Mn ions in liquid electrolyte from LMO at various states of charge (SOC). We confirmed the highest dissolution concentration and rate occur at the 4.3 V charged state, with Mn2+ being the primary species in the electrolyte. Ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations showed that the Mn dissolution process is closely linked to surface structure evolution, solvent decomposition, and lithium salt. These findings will enhance our understanding of transition metal dissolution mechanisms under operational conditions and aid in designing a stable cathode.

The worldwide energy predicament, alongside the use of fossil fuels and consequent environmental challenges, has driven significant interest in developing sustainable energy storage and conversion systems. Rechargeable lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are prevalent in mobile electronics and hybrid and electric vehicles. The electrode-electrolyte interface critically influences battery capacity reduction and long-term cycling stability. Enhancing fundamental insights into these phenomena is essential for the strategic design of cathode materials and a durable interface. Li(Ni,Co,Mn)O2 (NCM) serves both as a cathode material for rechargeable LIBs and an effective electrocatalyst for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). The performance and catalytic properties of these materials are closely linked to their structures. Various processes at the cathode/electrolyte interface contribute to performance degradation. One failure mechanism involves the dissolution of transition metals from the cathode. Our research uses thin films as model cathodes to observe Mn dissolution. Employing LiMn2O4 and NCM as cathode materials, we will concentrate on electrochemical characterization, cation mixing, oxygen evolution, and thin film deposition with precise control over crystal structures and composition. Additionally, we will present our work using the scanning electrochemical microscope to examine LIB degradation and the cathode-electrolyte interface both in situ and in real-time.

This study presents a high-performance, long-lasting lithium-ion battery using a Pyr14 TFSI-LiTFSI non-flammable ionic liquid (IL) electrolyte, a nanostructured tin carbon (Sn-C) nanocomposite anode, and a layered LiNi1/3 Co1/3 Mn1/3 O2 (NMC) cathode. The IL electrolyte is evaluated for its conductivity and viscosity across different temperatures, following a Vogel-Tammann-Fulcher (VTF) model. Lithium half-cells with the Sn-C anode and NMC cathode in the Pyr14 TFSI-LiTFSI electrolyte are analyzed through galvanostatic cycling at various temperatures, confirming the electrolyte's full compatibility with the chosen electrode materials. A cathode-limited full cell is constructed by combining the NMC and Sn-C electrodes, which is then cycled at 40°C, maintaining a stable capacity of approximately 140 mAh g(-1) with over 99% capacity retention over 400 cycles. The electrode/electrolyte interface is studied using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) following cell cycling. The outstanding performance demonstrated confirms that IL-based lithium-ion cells are appropriate for electric vehicle applications.

The performance of lithium-ion batteries at temperatures below ambient levels is greatly limited by resistive interphases formed from electrolyte decomposition, especially on the anode surface. This study introduces an innovative approach where a low-impedance anode interphase is developed using the electrolyte additive dimethyl sulfite (DMS). Electrochemical evaluations reveal that the interphase created with DMS significantly enhances the low-temperature performance of graphite/LiNi0.5Co0.2Mn0.3O2 pouch cells, surpassing the interphase formed by the commonly used commercial electrolyte additive, 1,3,2-Dioxathiolane 2,2-dioxide (DTD). Spectral analyses coupled with theoretical calculations illustrate that the enhanced performance is due to DMS's unique molecular structure, which exhibits appropriate reduction activity and forms a more stable, ionically conductive anode interphase. This is because the reduction product of DMS binds less strongly with lithium ions compared to DTD. This strategic design of interphases via additive structure is a cost-effective yet highly efficient method for optimizing the performance of lithium-ion batteries.

A Si nanoparticles@TiO2-x/C mesoporous microfiber composite with a core-shell structure has been produced using an electrospinning technique. This core-shell configuration demonstrates a high reversible capacity, outstanding rate capability, and enhanced cycling performance when used as an anode material for lithium-ion batteries. Additionally, it significantly mitigates exothermic reactions, potentially preventing thermal runaway and safety issues within the cells. The enhanced electrochemical and thermal characteristics are attributed to the robust mechanical, electrical, and thermal properties of the TiO2-x/C nanocomposite shell that encases the Si nanoparticles. This material structure is proposed as a promising candidate for developing safe and reliable high-energy-density Si-based lithium-ion batteries.

During solid-state calcination, materials undergo complex phase transitions involving heterogeneous solid-state reactions and mass transport, as temperature rises. Thus, precise control over calcination chemistry is essential for creating advanced Ni-rich layered oxides (LiNi1-x-yCoxMnyO2, NRNCM) employed as cathode materials in lithium-ion batteries. Despite being a critical factor in battery performance, the chemical heterogeneity during NRNCM calcination remains unexplained. This study utilizes synchrotron-based X-ray, mass spectrometry microscopy, and structural analyses to demonstrate that temperature-dependent reaction kinetics, the diffusivity of solid-state lithium sources, and ambient oxygen influence the local chemical makeup of reaction intermediates within a calcined particle. Furthermore, it is identified that variations in the reducing power of transition metals (Ni, Co, and Mn) dictate nanoscale local structures. This research into the reaction mechanism through imaging analysis offers key insights for adjusting calcination chemistry, which is essential for developing lithium-ion batteries with high energy and power density.

Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have facilitated portable energy storage, but increasing societal demands are driving the development of a more advanced generation of LIBs. While the discovery and optimization of active materials for batteries have been extensively researched since the 1980s, significant commercial advancements in LIBs over the last ten years have primarily arisen from improvements in overall cell design and engineering. To achieve higher energy density and fast-charging capabilities, recent strategies have aimed at adjusting the properties of composite electrode architectures—including porosity, conductivity, tortuosity, and spatial heterogeneity—by restructuring the matrix of inactive components in LIB electrode films. This perspective reviews recent innovations in electrode design with a focus on practical applications, highlighting synthetic platforms and future research avenues that are scalable, commercially viable, and applicable to a broad array of active materials. We introduce and critically analyze new approaches for structuring electrode architectures, such as spatial gradients in local composition and microstructure, alternatives to metal-foil current collectors, and electrode templating techniques, assessing their impact on battery performance and commercial potential. Combined with enhanced active materials, these novel electrode architectures could enable the next generation of LIBs.

Organic anion-hosting cathodes are highly appealing candidates for lithium-ion-based dual-ion batteries (LDIBs) due to their numerous advantages, including diversity, customizable design, and adjustability. In this study, we introduce a new organic anion-hosting mixed-valence metal-organic framework cathode, identified as CoⅡ2CoⅢ(DFc)2(OH)3·H2O (Co(DFc)x), for use in LDIBs for the first time. The redox processes involving the Fe2+/Fe3+ and Co2+/Co3+ couples enable the incorporation and reversible release of PF6- anions into the LiPF6-based electrolyte. This cathode's unique structure and insolubility contribute to its high energy density of 632 Wh kg-1 (relative to a lithium anode), a high operating potential of 3.63 V (vs. Li+/Li), a high reversible capacity of 170 mAh g-1 at a current density of 50 mA g-1 during the third cycle, excellent rate performance capable of reaching 2000 mA g-1 (allowing a cycle time of 5 minutes), and outstanding cycling stability, maintaining an average capacity of 74.9 mAh g-1 over 8000 cycles at 2000 mA g-1.

Graphene, consisting of a single carbon atomic layer, exhibits outstanding mechanical, electrical, and optical properties, making it a promising material for broad applications in physics, chemistry, information, energy, and device manufacturing sectors. This paper provides a concise overview of graphene's concept, structure, properties, preparation techniques, and its implementation in lithium-ion batteries. By forming a continuous 3D conductive network, graphene significantly enhances electron and ion transport within electrode materials, thereby improving the lithium-ion battery's characteristics, including chemical stability, electrical conductivity, and capacity. This review summarizes recent advancements in graphene-containing materials for lithium-ion batteries and discusses future prospects in this area.

Volume expansion poses a significant challenge for tin oxide (SnO x) when used as an anode in lithium-ion batteries, leading to limited cyclability. This study involves the preparation of bare tin dioxide (SnO2), tin dioxide combined with graphene sheets (SnO2@GS), and a bouquet-like nanocomposite structure (Mn2SnO4@GS) through hydrothermal methods followed by annealing. The resulting composite material forms a bouquet structure featuring a network of manganese and tin oxide nanoparticles interlaced with graphene sheets. This porous nanostructure leverages graphene sheets to provide superior electronic pathways, thereby enhancing electronic conductivity. The uniformly distributed particles also facilitate rapid kinetic reactions with lithium ions and mitigate volume changes in SnO2 particles during charge-discharge cycles. Consequently, the ternary composite Mn2SnO4@GS demonstrated exceptional cyclability and a high rate performance as an anode material in lithium-ion batteries. The electrode reached a specific capacity of approximately 1070 mA h g-1 at a current density of 400 mA g-1 after 200 cycles, and maintained a specific capacity of around 455 mA h g-1 at a high current density of 2500 mA g-1. The ternary Mn2SnO4@GS material contributes to the development of innovative structural and conductive networks in advanced lithium-ion batteries.

Sodium ion batteries offer significant benefits for large-scale energy storage, including cost efficiency and improved safety. Nonetheless, conventional anode materials like graphite fall short due to the difficulty posed by the large Na+ ion radius, which impedes their insertion and extraction during charging and discharging. A newly synthesized material, the biphenylene network (BPN), a two-dimensional (2D) carbon allotrope, shows promise as a solution. This study examines BPN's potential as a Na storage medium. Theoretical analysis highlights BPN’s benefits as an anode for sodium batteries, with a maximum specific capacity of 413 mA h g-1, surpassing the graphite-Li system's 372 mA h g-1. BPN also demonstrates a low Na+ diffusion barrier below 0.6 eV and minimal volume expansion during charging (approximately 26%), making it superior to the graphite-Na system. Our results offer fresh perspectives on Na storage utilizing BPN and provide a framework for employing BPN as an anode in sodium ion batteries.

Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) is seen as a promising anode material for future sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to its high theoretical capacity. However, its practical use is limited by low conductivity, significant volume changes, and undesirable phase transitions. This research involves synthesizing a hierarchically engineered core-shell heterostructure composed of nitrogen-doped MoS2/C and silicon oxycarbide (SiOC) (N-MoS2/C@SiOC) through the straightforward pyrolysis of a suspension comprising an N-MoS2/polyfurfural precursor in silicone oil. Nitrogen doping within the two-dimensional MoS2 structure, along with carbon integration, expands the interlayer spacing and improves electronic conductivity and mechanical durability. This facilitates easy and highly reversible sodium ion insertion and extraction during cycling. Additionally, the nanoscale SiOC shell with surface capacitive activity offers a conductive route, preventing unwanted side reactions at the electrode/electrolyte interface and serving as a buffer to mitigate severe volume expansion issues. Consequently, the N-MoS2/C@SiOC composite demonstrates a high reversible capacity (540.7 mAh g-1), superior capacity retention (>100% after 200 cycles), and excellent rate capability up to 10 A g-1. The straightforward hierarchical core-shell design approach presented in this study enables the development of high-performance metal sulfide anodes and other high-capacity anode materials for energy storage purposes.

Materials composed of SnS2 have garnered significant interest in electrochemical energy storage due to their layered structure, which offers high specific capacity. Nonetheless, these materials tend to restack during charge/discharge cycles, leading to instability in the electrode structure and a reduction in storage capacity. This paper details a straightforward, one-step hydrothermal method to synthesize a SnS2/graphene/SnS2 (SnS2/rGO/SnS2) composite. This composite features ultrathin SnS2 nanosheets covalently attached to both sides of reduced graphene oxide sheets through C‒S bonds. The incorporation of graphene between two SnS2 layers results in an increased interlayer spacing of approximately 8.03 Å within the SnS2, which facilitates the insertion and extraction of Li+/Na+ ions with rapid transport kinetics and prevents the SnS2 nanosheets from restacking during charge/discharge cycles. Density functional theory calculations indicate that this sandwich-like arrangement of interlayer spacing is the most stable. Simulations at the molecular level and experimental data both show that this configuration optimally supports rapid ion transport. Additionally, many ultra-fine SnS2 nanoparticles anchored on the graphene sheets contribute significantly to pseudocapacitance, especially at high current densities, resulting in outstanding high-rate performance, with capacities of 844 and 765 mAh g-1 for Li/Na-ion batteries at 10 A g‒1. The composite also maintains its morphology after 200 cycles, with SnS2 nanoparticles reverting to their original phase with no significant agglomeration. Thus, this composite, with its superior rate capabilities and excellent cycle stability, is a promising candidate for lithium/sodium storage applications.

We present the development of 3D flower-like MoS2 nanosheet arrays on carbon cloth, serving as a binder-free anode for sodium-ion batteries. Through atomic layer deposition, ultrathin, conformal TiO2 layers are applied to modify the MoS2 surface. Electrochemical performance assessments reveal that the ALD TiO2 layer enhances the cycling stability and rate capability of MoS2. The MoS2 nanosheets coated with a 0.5-nm TiO2 layer exhibit an initial discharge capacity of 1392 mA h g-1 at 200 mA g-1, a 53% increase compared to uncoated MoS2. After 150 cycles, the capacity retention of the TiO2-coated MoS2 is 75.8% of its capacity at the second cycle at 200 mA g-1, while pure MoS2 exhibits a retention of 59%. Additionally, the mechanism underlying these results is elucidated through ex situ characterizations using scanning electron microscope (SEM), X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), which confirm that the TiO2 modifications help prevent structural degradation and SEI film formation on the MoS2 electrode.

Authors: Qu, Baihua; Ma, Chuze; Ji, Ge; Xu, Chaohe; Xu, Jing; Meng, Ying Shirley; Wang, Taihong; Lee, Jim Yang | A layered composite material, composed of SnS2 and reduced graphene oxide (SnS2-RGO), was synthesized via a simple hydrothermal process and tested as an anode for sodium-ion batteries (NIBs). The composite displayed impressive electrochemical performance, achieving a high charge specific capacity of 630 mAh g^-1 at a current of 0.2 A g^-1, along with an excellent rate capability of 544 mAh g^-1 at 2 A g^-1. Additionally, it demonstrated a prolonged cycle-life, delivering 500 mAh g^-1 at 1 A g^-1 over 400 cycles. © 2014 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.

Pyrite (FeS2) is considered a promising anode material for sodium ion batteries (SIBs) due to its affordability, environmentally friendly nature, and high theoretical capacity. Nevertheless, its practical application is hindered by significant volume changes during charging and discharging and its poor conductivity. In this study, we present a simple scalable method to create a nanostructured FeS2 embedded within an N-doped carbon nanosheet composite (FeS2/CNS) using a combination of template and solid-state sulfuration techniques. The N-doped carbon nanosheets are expected to mitigate volume changes and improve electrode conductivity, while the nanoscale particles, averaging 50-80 nm in diameter, can reduce ion-diffusion distances during sodiation and desodiation. As a result, the FeS2/CNS electrode delivers high specific capacity (812 mA h g-1 at 0.1 A g-1), long cycle life (77.2% capacity retention after 350 cycles at 1 A g-1), and impressive rate capability (400 mA h g-1 at 5 A g-1) when tested as a SIB anode. These findings highlight the potential of FeS2/CNS for SIB applications, offering a cost-effective solution with high power density and extended cycling life.

Cellulose is a highly appealing natural bio-macromolecule due to its widespread availability, sustainability, and affordability. This study introduces a novel approach to fabricate pre-sodiated carbonaceous anodes for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) using cellulose nanofibers (CNFs) under microwave irradiation, potentially allowing for ultrafast and large-scale production. Although CNFs usually exhibit poor microwave absorption, preventing direct carbonization through microwave treatment, it is discovered that a minimal quantity of reduced graphene oxide (rGO) serves as an efficient initiator. The microwaving of rGO releases tremendous energy, creating a local ultrahigh temperature and an extremely rapid heating rate, which catalyzes the swift carbonization of CNFs and generates pre-sodiated carbonaceous materials in seconds. The sodium content in these carbonaceous materials, originating from the carbonization of CNFs with sodium-ion carboxyl, provides suitable sites for sodiation and desodiation, enhancing the electrochemical performance of the sodium-intercalated carbonaceous anode. When the microwaved rGO-CNF (MrGO-CNF) is utilized as an anode in SIBs, it demonstrates a high initial capacity of 558 mAh g-1, with 340 mAh g-1 remaining after 200 cycles. The notable reversible capacity and cycling stability highlight MrGO-CNF as a promising anode candidate for sodium-ion batteries.

The structural stability of high-capacity conversion electrodes, which experience significant volume changes, presents a major challenge but is crucial for the advancement of high-energy-density, long-lasting batteries. In this study, we introduce a phosphorus anode for sodium-ion batteries that remains stable by leveraging the synergistic effect of a chemically bonded phosphorus-carbon nanotube (P-CNT) hybrid combined with a cross-linked polymer binder. The P-CNT hybrid is created by ball-milling red phosphorus with carbon nanotubes that have been functionalized with carboxylic groups. The P-O-C bonds generated during this process ensure sustained contact between the phosphorus and CNTs, resulting in a robust hybrid. Additionally, a cross-linked binder composed of carboxymethyl cellulose and citric acid is employed to create a strong electrode.
