In the case of sulfites ES and PS, two-electron reduction to form inorganic Na2SO3 is more difficult than carbonate ester reduction. Moreover, the decomposition pathway involving one- and two-electron reductions for FEC is more conducive to generating inorganic NaF components.

To advance lithium and sodium ion battery technologies, comprehending how the properties of their components are influenced by their chemical structures is crucial. Although operando structural studies provide some of the most valuable insights into battery functionality, distinguishing the contributions of individual components within a battery stack (such as electrodes, current collectors, electrolyte, and binders) to analyze specific materials remains challenging. Our research utilizes operando X-ray diffraction computed tomography (XRD-CT) to focus on specific components within a nearly unaltered working cell, obtaining detailed, spatially-resolved structural data of both crystalline and amorphous phases during cycling through Rietveld and pair distribution function (PDF) methods. We demonstrate this approach with an unprecedented structural analysis of sodium cycling in a phosphorus anode, uncovering unexpectedly different mechanisms for sodiation and desodiation in this highly promising, high-capacity anode system.

All-solid-state sodium ion batteries (AS3iBs) are in high demand for stationary energy storage systems due to their inherent safety and stability across a broad temperature range. Hard carbon (HC), which is cost-effective, has a low redox potential, and high capacity, plays a critical role in realizing a practical large-scale sodium-ion battery. Nonetheless, the battery's energy density is limited by the low initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) of this anode material. In this study, two methods are investigated to enhance the ICE of pristine HC: i) additional pyrolysis and ii) presodiation through the thermal decomposition of NaBH4. Through Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, and electrochemical analyses, it is demonstrated that thermal treatment raises the Csp2 content in the HC structure, while presodiation provides sodium to fill the inherent irreversible sites. As a result, presodiated HC achieves an impressive ICE exceeding 99%, compared to 90% for thermally treated HC and 83% for pristine HC in half-cell setups. Importantly, an AS3iB using presodiated HC as the anode and NaCrO2 as the cathode shows a high ICE of 92% and an initial discharge energy density of 294 Wh kg^(-1) for the cathode.

Devices with high gravimetric and volumetric energy densities are increasingly sought after due to the rapid advancement of electric vehicles and portable as well as wearable electronics. Electrospinning emerges as a promising method for creating freestanding electrodes that achieve high gravimetric and volumetric energy densities. However, traditional electrospun electrodes face limitations in energy density because of the low mass loading of active materials, typically between 20% and 30% by weight. This study introduces a biomimetic strategy inspired by the sticky spider web, presenting a high-performance anode that enhances both gravimetric and volumetric energy density. Electrospinning and subsequent thermal treatment were used to prepare freestanding carbon nanofiber (CNF) membranes with more than 50 wt% of bismuth. The resulting CNF network structures were tightly bonded with active bismuth cluster materials, providing robust mechanical protection coupled with a fast charge transport pathway, which are challenging to achieve together. As a lithium-ion battery anode, the composite membrane exhibits high reversible capacity (483 mA h g⁻¹ at 100 mA g⁻¹ after 200 cycles) and impressive rate performance (242 mA h g⁻¹ at 1 A g⁻¹). When used in sodium-ion batteries, it shows a high reversible specific capacity of 346 mA h g⁻¹ and excellent cycling performance (186 mA h g⁻¹ at 50 mA g⁻¹ after 100 cycles). This research presents a straightforward, cost-effective, and environmentally friendly approach to fabricating freestanding and binder-free composite electrodes with high loadings for use in both LIBs and SIBs.

Hard carbon (HC) is a promising candidate for commercial anode material applications in lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs). Nonetheless, the existing approaches for evaluating battery performance, which rely on...

Two-dimensional (2D) molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) has garnered significant interest for its applications in catalysis, energy storage, and electronics. An obstacle to the practical use of 2D MoS2 has been the absence of effective methods for producing it in large quantities. We present a straightforward liquid-phase exfoliation technique that enhances the exfoliation efficiency for single-layer MoS2 sheets using 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP), with assistance from sodium hydroxide (NaOH). This method significantly increases the concentration of exfoliated MoS2 nanosheets compared to traditional liquid-phase exfoliation approaches with NMP solvent. We demonstrate the reliable performance of a sodium-ion battery utilizing exfoliated MoS2 and MoS2-rGO composite as anode materials.

Utilizing oxygen vacancies (OVs) in sodium ion batteries (SIBs) is anticipated to improve their performance, though it has been seldom explored. Using the MoO(3-x) nanosheet anode as a case study, we illustrate for the first time how OVs benefit SIB performance. Furthermore, these advantages under deep-discharge conditions are enhanced by an ultrathin Al2O3 coating. Various measurements reveal that OVs enhance electrical conductivity and the Na-ion diffusion coefficient, while the ultrathin coating effectively reduces cycling-induced solid-electrolyte interphase formation. The coated nanosheets demonstrated a high reversible capacity and excellent rate capability, achieving capacities of 283.9 mAh g(-1) at 50 mA g(-1) and 179.3 mAh g(-1) at 1 A g(-1) after 100 cycles. This study not only highlights the potential of OVs for sodium energy storage but also proposes new strategies for exploiting defects in other energy storage systems.

Engineering heterostructures is a highly promising strategy for enhancing the slow kinetics in sodium ion battery (SIB) anodes. In this study, we conduct a thorough investigation into how different heterostructure interfaces of discharge products (Na2O, Na2S, Na2Se) affect rate performance. Our first-principles calculations indicate that the Na2S/Na2Se interface has the lowest sodium diffusion energy barrier (0.39 eV) compared to other interfaces (Na2O/Na2S, Na2O/Na2Se, and Na2S/Na2Se). This is attributed to its minimal interface deformation and similar electronegativity and lattice constants. Experimental results show that the metal sulfide/metal selenide (SnS/SnSe2) hierarchical anode delivers excellent rate performance, with a normalized capacity of 45.6% at 10 A g-1 compared to 0.1 A g-1. This design approach can facilitate the development of high-performance anodes for advanced battery systems.

Antimony/carbon (Sb@C) microspheres are synthesized initially using a simple self-catalyzing solvothermal technique, and their potential as anode materials for sodium-ion batteries is examined. Structural and morphological analyses show that Sb@C microspheres consist of Sb nanoparticles (approximately 20 nm) evenly enclosed within the carbon matrix. The self-catalyzing solvothermal process is confirmed through various comparative experiments with different starting materials. The synthesized Sb@C microspheres demonstrate excellent sodium storage capabilities, with a reversible capacity of 640 mAh g(-1), outstanding rate performance, and sustained cycling stability with 92.3% capacity retention over 300 cycles, highlighting their promise as anode materials for sodium-ion batteries.

Layered transition metal oxides with an O3-type structure based on sodium are promising candidates for sodium-ion battery cathodes. However, their application is hindered due to rapid capacity loss and poor rate performance, resulting from significant structural changes and interfacial degradation. This study presents the synthesis of a NaPO3 surface-modified O3-type layered NaNi1/3Fe1/3Mn1/3O2 cathode, which enhances high-voltage stability by providing a protective layer against acid attacks. This is accomplished through a solid-gas reaction between the cathode particles and gaseous P2O5. The NaPO3 nanolayer on the surface effectively stabilizes the crystal structure by reducing surface parasitic reactions and increasing average voltage. The surface-modified cathode demonstrates superior cyclic stability (80.1% vs 63.6%) after 150 cycles at 1 C over a voltage range of 2.0 V-4.2 V (vs Na+/Na). Additionally, leveraging the inherent ionic conduction of NaPO3, the modified cathode exhibits excellent rate capability (103 mAh g-1 vs 60 mAh g-1) at 10 C. This research outlines a viable strategy to advance high rate and long-lasting sodium-ion battery technologies.

Incorporating heteroatoms can effectively reduce phase transitions in layered sodium-ion battery cathodes, although the atomic-scale behaviors of these heteroatoms under operational conditions remain partially understood. This study combines density functional theory calculations with experimental analysis to examine the behavior and mechanisms of Mg dopants under operating conditions in P2-Na0.67Ni0.33Mn0.67O2. When Na ions are extracted, voids are created that move some Mg dopants from TM layers into Na layers. The diffusion of multiple Mg ions likely occurs when the TM layer is heavily doped with Mg, eventually leading to the formation of Mg-rich regions (i.e., Mg segregation) away from Ni vacancies. This Mg segregation, prompted by the void-pump effect, effectively hampers the P2-O2 phase transition due to a stronger Mg-O electrostatic attraction. This attraction enhances the cohesion of adjacent oxygen layers and reduces crack growth by limiting lattice volume changes during high-voltage cycling. This study offers a fundamental understanding of heteroatom mitigation behavior in layered cathodes at an atomic level, supporting advancements in next-generation energy storage technologies.

Sodium (Na) ion batteries (SIBs) offer the potential for cost-effective energy storage, yet they suffer from limited energy density. Introducing oxygen (O) redox in the Na-storage cathodes is currently seen as a viable method to enhance capacity and address the energy density limitation. However, this introduction brings the challenge of overcoming the irreversible electrochemical behavior associated with O release. Additionally, the chemistry of O redox and its resulting structural changes remain unclear. This paper examines the O redox mechanism in Na-storage transition metal oxides. It reviews challenges like reaction irreversibility and structural collapse, using advanced characterization techniques. Furthermore, strategies to improve the electrochemical performance of O redox and prospects for future research on viable O redox cathode materials are discussed.

The P2‐type layered oxide Na2/3Ni1/3Mn2/3O2 is a promising material for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), but it faces challenges due to a substantial P2–O2 phase transition during charging at high voltages, which leads to significant volume changes and reduced cycling performance. In this context, a Quasi‐zero strain P2‐Na0.75Li0.15Mg0.05Ni0.1Mn0.7O2 cathode has been developed, showcasing a minimized P2–O2 transition with only a 0.49% volume change, thereby achieving excellent cycling performance with 83.9% capacity retention after 500 cycles at 5 C. This low-volume strain results from two factors: (1) Mg2+ within the Na layer acts as a "pillar," stabilizing the crystal structure during sodium extraction and restraining structural changes at high voltage. (2) The incorporation of Li+ into the transition metal layer reduces electron localization during high desodiation states and effectively immobilizes coordination oxygen atoms, which curtails the P2–O2 transition slip. This research offers new insights into the synergistic effects of Li and Mg substitution on the structural stability of P2‐type cathodes and presents an effective strategy for creating SIB cathode materials with very low bulk strain.

Prussian blue is garnering the interest of researchers for its potential as a cathode material in sodium-ion batteries, attributed to its open structures and high working potential. Nonetheless, the presence of interstitial water in its crystal lattice, along with poor electronic conductivity, hinders its effectiveness in real-world sodium-ion battery applications. To address these issues, acid-assisted ball milling synthesis was utilized as a flexible method to produce surface-modified Prussian blue. This method used (CH3COO)2Fe as the starting material, resulting in a Prussian blue with a carboxyl group-modified surface, which reduced the interstitial water content and enhanced the electrochemical cycling performance. Moreover, the ball milling process endowed the resultant Prussian blue with a large surface area, thus boosting its electrochemical rate capabilities. When employed as a sodium-ion battery cathode, the synthesized Prussian blue exhibited a specific capacity of 145.3 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C and maintained 113.7 mAh g−1 at 1 C, retaining 54.5% of the initial capacity after 1000 cycles at 1 C (1 C = 170 mA g−1). Additionally, in a constructed solid-state sodium-ion battery, where the synthesized Prussian blue was used as the cathode alongside Na metal as the anode, a high specific capacity of 128.7 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C was achieved. This work proposes an efficient strategy to address the drawbacks of Prussian blue for its potential commercial use.

P2-type layered oxides using Fe and Mn have gained significant attention as cathode materials for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to their cost-effective metal composition and high specific capacity. However, these materials are hampered by rapid capacity loss and complex phase transformations. In this research, we alter the crystal structure and improve the electrochemical performance of Na0.67Mn0.5Fe0.5O2 through Al doping, replacing Mn or Fe, and explore the roles of Al in enhancing rate capability and cycling performance. (1) Substituting Al for Mn or Fe reduces lattice parameters a and c, while increasing d spacing and lengthening Na-O bonds, leading to improved Na+ diffusion and rate capability, especially for Na0.67Mn0.5Fe0.47Al0.03O2. (2) Al doping decreases the TMO2 thickness and strengthens TM-O/O-O bonding, improving the stability of the layered structure and capacity retention. (3) Al doping mitigates Mn3+ and Jahn-Teller distortion, decreasing irreversible phase transition. (4) Al doping also reduces lattice volume changes and structural strain, further enhancing the stability of the layered structure and cycling performance, particularly when doped for Fe. These insights into Al substitution may also guide the design of high-performance cathode materials for SIBs through strategic lattice doping.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) hold significant promise for large-scale energy storage applications. P2-type manganese-based layered oxides have garnered attention due to their high theoretical capacity, affordability, and eco-friendliness. Nevertheless, challenges such as water sensitivity and limited cycling stability impede their usage, with the underlying causes of these issues remaining unclear. This study employs copper substitution to mitigate the Jahn-Teller effect of Mn3+ and influence the lattice structure. We thoroughly examined the water sensitivity and charge compensation mechanism. Our findings reveal that the electrode's water sensitivity is linked to the order of Na+/vacancy in the Na interlayers, as water molecules more readily insert into charged state electrodes; however, the tendency to absorb water does not increase with Na+ extraction. Additionally, Mn2+ forms on the electrode surface during initial discharge, with bulk redox reactions occurring mainly between Mn3+ and Mn4+. Copper substitution in the TM layer influences the arrangement of Na+/vacancy and reduces Mn2+ formation on the Na0.7Mn0.9Cu0.1O2 electrode, resulting in enhanced air stability and improved storage characteristics.

In O3-type sodium ion battery (SIB) cathodes, phase transitions and changes in lattice parameters can lead to increased voltage hysteresis and diminished energy efficiency. With cost considerations hindering the widespread adoption of SIBs for large-scale energy storage, this study examines Co/Ni-free NaxCu0.18Fe0.3Mn0.52O2 (x = 0.8, 0.85, 0.9) and suggests a practical method to minimize voltage hysteresis. The investigation shows that at a Na content of 0.8, the material achieves a peak energy efficiency of 95.4% after activation (between 2.5-4.0 V, at 50 mA g-1 during the 50th cycle) while maintaining good capacity retention (approximately 0.056% decay per cycle). Further characterization indicates that Na0.8Cu0.18Fe0.3Mn0.52O2 experiences a smooth O3-P3 phase transition without O3 phase lattice parameter changes. The crucial factor is the material's ability to form an O3/P3 composite. This study presents a straightforward approach for designing O3-type cathodes with high energy efficiency and may inspire efforts to find layered oxides with higher critical Na content in O3/P3 configurations through elemental modifications.

Layered O3-type sodium oxides (NaMO2, where M represents a transition metal) often undergo an O3-P3 phase transition at a low redox voltage around 3 V (vs. Na+/Na) during sodium extraction and insertion. Consequently, nearly half of their total capacity is concentrated in this low-voltage region, resulting in insufficient energy density for use as cathode materials in sodium-ion batteries (NIBs). Enhancing high-voltage O3-type cathodes is challenging because increasing the phase-transition voltage through structure modification is difficult. This paper introduces a novel O3-type sodium insertion material intended for NIB applications. The engineered O3-type Na0.7Ni0.35Sn0.65O2 material demonstrates the highest redox potential of 3.7 V (vs. Na+/Na) among known O3-type materials based on the Ni2+/Ni3+ redox couple. This is achieved by increasing the Ni-O bond ionicity and reducing the orbital overlap between transition metals and oxygen in the MO2 layers. This research provides an orbital-level insight into the operating potentials of the nominal redox couples for O3-NaMO2 cathodes. The described strategy may be utilized to design electrodes with enhanced performance.

Sodium-ion batteries (SiBs) are being regarded as a viable substitute for the existing Lithium-ion batteries (LiBs). Nonetheless, SiBs represent an emerging technological advancement that is still in its nascent development phase, encompassing a broad range...

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) hold promise for developing affordable and secure energy storage solutions suitable for large-scale needs. In this study, we have created manganese oxide (α-MnO2) nanorods tailored for use in SIBs. We systematically analyzed the crystal structure of this metal oxide cathode, essential for achieving high-performance energy storage. The integration of sodium within the α-MnO2 framework was explored using theoretical density functional theory (DFT) analyses. The DFT results indicate that Na ions exhibit easy diffusion kinetics in the MnO2 lattice with a notably low diffusion barrier of 0.21 eV. When used as a cathode material in SIBs, MnO2 demonstrated a moderate capacity of 109 mAh·g–1 at a C/20 current rate and outstanding lifespan stability, retaining 58.6% capacity after 800 cycles in NaPF6/EC+DMC (5% FEC) electrolyte. In contrast, it achieved a higher capacity of 181 mAh·g–1 at a C/20 current rate in NaClO4/PC (5% FEC) electrolyte, but experienced rapid capacity degradation, retaining only 11.5% after 800 cycles. Our results suggest that the superior cycling performance is attributed to the high crystallinity and hierarchical nanorod structure of the MnO2, which facilitates fast and sustained charge-discharge processes.

Layered manganese-based cathode materials are highly valued for sodium ion batteries because of their substantial specific capacities. Nonetheless, their cycling stability and rate capability are often compromised by the Jahn-Teller effect and inevitable phase transitions. This study introduces a P2-type manganese oxide nanoplate cathode material that is modified through Mo-substitution, featuring an oriented stacking structure and exposed {010} active facets. This modified manganese oxide nanoplate delivers exceptional capacity retention of 87.8% after 1200 cycles at a 10C rate (2000 mA g-1). It also achieves a specific power density as high as 530 W Kg-1, with a specific discharge capacity of 143.9 mA h g-1 at 1C and 89.6% capacity retention over 100 cycles. These outstanding electrochemical properties are attributed to the effective chemical modification and the distinctive structural characteristics of the manganese oxide nanoplate. Mo-modification enlarges the lattice space and average oxidation state, promoting Na+ diffusion and mitigating the Jahn-Teller effect, which enhances structural stability for a significantly prolonged cycling life. Additionally, the multilayer oriented stacking nanoplate structure with exposed {010} active facets increases the number of surface active sites and shortens the Na+ diffusion path, thus improving rate capability.

Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are increasingly seen as a promising supplement to lithium-ion batteries, offering a broader range of options in the battery market. Nevertheless, developing cathode materials with high-rate performance and long-cycle stability remains a critical challenge for SIBs. In this context, the introduction of an ordered bicontinuous porous structure into SIB cathode materials is demonstrated as an effective method to enhance both rate and cycling performance. Prussian blue analogues (PBAs) have been chosen due to their promise as SIB cathode materials. The 3D continuous channels in these materials facilitate rapid Na+ ion diffusion, and the inherent mechanical stability of the bicontinuous structure contributes to superior performance. The resulting PBAs achieve remarkable rate capability (80 mAh g−1 at 2.5 A g−1) and an exceptional cycling life exceeding 3000 cycles at 0.5 A g−1, marking the highest performance among reported PBA-based cathode materials. This study paves the way for improving sluggish ion diffusion kinetics in rechargeable battery electrodes and offers a novel approach to addressing electrode failure caused by high-stress concentration during ion storage.

In layered oxide cathodes of lithium-ion batteries, cation migration frequently happens due to the similar ion radii of lithium and transition metals (TMs). Despite the notable difference in ion radius between sodium and TMs, these metals can still migrate into the sodium layer in sodium-ion battery (SIB) cathodes, causing significant electrochemical degradation. To investigate the causes of TM migration in layered SIB cathodes, we utilize NaCrO2, a representative layered cathode with pronounced TM migration, as a model system. Our findings indicate that TM migration originates from the irregular desodiation and subsequent formation of a sodium-free layer at high charging potentials. We propose a co-doping approach with ruthenium and titanium to mitigate this issue. In this method, the active Ru dopant is initially oxidized, promoting selective desodiation, while the inactive Ti dopant acts as a structural support to prevent full desodiation in Ru-rich TM layers, thereby reducing the formation of sodium-free layers and improving electrochemical performance.

P2-type Na2/3Ni1/3Mn2/3O2 (NNMO) is a promising cathode material for sodium-ion batteries, offering a high theoretical capacity and operating voltage that contribute to elevated energy storage density. Despite these advantages, NNMO experiences poor cycling stability mainly due to an unwanted P2-O2 phase transition. To address this, electrochemically active Fe3+ ions are incorporated into the NNMO lattice, resulting in Na2/3Ni1/3Mn2/3-xFexO2 (x = 0, 1/24, 1/12, 1/8, 1/6), effectively stabilizing the P2-type crystal structure. In these Fe-substituted materials, both Ni2+/Ni4+ and Fe3+/Fe4+ couples are involved in redox reactions, significantly controlling the P2-O2 phase transition during cycling, as confirmed by ex situ X-ray diffraction. Consequently, the optimized Na2/3Ni1/3Mn7/12Fe1/12O2 (1/12-NNMF) demonstrates excellent cycling stability with a fading rate of 0.05% per cycle over 300 cycles at 5 C. Additionally, the 1/12-NNMF material exhibits superior rate capabilities (65 mA h g-1 at 25 C) and outstanding low-temperature performance (94% capacity retention at -25 °C after 80 cycles) due to improved Na diffusion facilitated by Fe doping, as inferred from electrode kinetics studies. Notably, 1/12-NNMF also delivers impressive sodium-ion full-cell performance when paired with an LS-Sb@G anode, suggesting its potential for practical applications.

As the manufacture and use of lithium ion batteries (LIBs) rise, recycling used LIBs becomes necessary from environmental, economic, and health perspectives. This study examines the leaching behavior of Ni, Mn, Co, Al, and Cu from processed cathode active materials, which are extracted from a commercial LIB pack in hybrid electric vehicles, using ammoniacal leaching agents derived from ammonia, ammonium carbonate, and ammonium sulfite. Ammonium sulfite acts as a reductant to improve the leaching kinetics, particularly for Ni and Co in the ammoniacal leaching process. Ammonium carbonate serves as a pH buffer, ensuring that the leaching solution's pH remains relatively stable during the process. Co and Cu demonstrate complete leaching, while Mn and Al show minimal leaching and Ni has a moderate leaching efficiency. The cathode active materials are confirmed to be a composite of LiMn2O4, LiCoxMnyNizO2, Al2O3, and C, whereas the leach residue consists of LiNixMnyCozO2, LiMn2O4, Al2O3, MnCO3, and Mn oxides. The recovery of Co via ammoniacal leaching is considered to have a competitive advantage over traditional acid leaching by reducing the cost associated with sodium hydroxide for pH adjustment and eliminating the need for Mn and Al separation steps.

The 2019 Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded to three pioneers in the development of the modern lithium-ion battery. This article, authored by Professor Arumugam Manthiram, revisits the progression of cathode chemistry, focusing on the three main types of oxide cathode materials and the pivotal solid-state chemistry underlying these breakthroughs. Lithium-ion batteries have driven the portable electronics revolution for almost thirty years and are now crucial in vehicle electrification and are beginning to penetrate the utility sector. Their rise and predominance stem from their superior energy density compared to other rechargeable battery systems, a benefit of the design and innovation of high-energy density electrode materials. Fundamental scientific research, especially in solid-state chemistry and physics, played a crucial role in this progress, particularly throughout the 1970s and 1980s. With the 2019 Nobel Prize recognizing lithium-ion battery advancements, reflecting on the evolution of cathode chemistry is especially insightful. This review offers an overview of how foundational research has helped in the discovery, enhancement, and strategic design of three significant categories of oxide cathodes for lithium-ion batteries, along with a personal view on the future trajectory of this vital field.

Oxygen vacancies (OVs) are intrinsic defects in transition metal (TM) oxides, significantly influencing their physicochemical characteristics. These metal oxides are widely employed in lithium-ion battery (LIB) cathodes, yet the role of OVs in this context is not fully understood. In this study, we examine the behavior of OVs in a single-crystal LIB cathode during non-equilibrium charging and discharging states. Our findings reveal that microcrack development in a single crystal is driven by OV condensation along specific crystallographic directions, caused by the ongoing migration of OVs and TM ions. Furthermore, a deeper understanding of OVs' presence and diffusion in metal oxides sheds light on many conventional mechanisms behind capacity fading in LIBs and offers new perspectives for future electrochemical applications.

We present a novel design for germanium-based electrodes, featuring three-dimensional spherical microflowers with crystalline nanorod networks rooted in robust one-dimensional nanostems, which are directly grown on a metallic current collector through a straightforward thermal evaporation process. The germanium nanorod networks naturally replicate their tetrahedral structures, forming an internal network resembling a diamond cubic lattice. Once etched and coated with carbon, these treated germanium nanostructures exhibit excellent electrical conductivity and resist gradual degradation, leading to outstanding electrochemical performance when used as anode materials in lithium-ion batteries. They maintain a charge capacity retention of 96% after 100 cycles and achieve a high specific capacity of 1360 mA h g^−1 at 1 C. Additionally, they demonstrate high-rate capability with reversible capacities of 1080 and 850 mA h g^−1 at 5 and 10 C rates, respectively. This enhanced electrochemical performance is credited to the rapid electron transport and effective strain accommodation offered by the carbon-filled germanium microflower-on-nanostem hybrid electrode.

A new method for extracting transition metals, retrieving lithium, and regenerating cathode materials has been devised using straightforward co-extraction and co-precipitation techniques. This process enables the co-extraction and separation of 100% manganese, 99% cobalt, and 85% nickel from lithium using D2EHPA in kerosene. Lithium is then recovered from the raffinate as Li2CO3 with a purity of 99.2% through a precipitation approach. Subsequently, the organic load phase is stripped with 0.5M H2SO4, allowing for the direct regeneration of the cathode material LiNi1/3Co1/3Mn1/3O2 from the stripping solution by co-precipitation, without the need for individual metal separation. This regenerated cathode material has a microspherical morphology, free of impurities, complies with China's LiNi1/3Co1/3Mn1/3O2 production standards, and demonstrates excellent electrochemical performance. Additionally, a waste battery management model is proposed to ensure a consistent supply of materials for recycling spent batteries.

Research has been conducted on the diffusion times of lithium ions within the cathode of a lithium-ion battery, achieving a spatial resolution below 100 nanometers. The ingress and egress of lithium ions in electrodes are crucial for lithium-ion battery functionality. While this phenomenon has been thoroughly examined at the device level, its characterization at the nanoscale, particularly concerning grain clusters, individual grains, and defects, remains incomplete. In this study, we investigate the spatial variation of lithium-ion diffusion times within the LiCoO_2 battery-cathode material, employing an atomic force microscope to redistribute lithium ions and measure the subsequent deformation of the cathode. The study observed the interplay between diffusion and individual grains and grain boundaries, noting that the diffusion coefficient increases for specific grain orientations and boundaries between single grains. This insight enhances the understanding of the nanoscale processes that underpin lithium-ion battery operation.

The search for electrode materials with high volumetric capacity capable of reversible insertion and removal of large K+ ions is ongoing. Tellurium (Te) has emerged as a promising candidate for K+ ion storage, owing to its demonstrated high volumetric capacity in lithium-/sodium-ion batteries and inherent excellent electronic conductivity. Nevertheless, the charge storage potential and the underlying mechanism of Te in potassium-ion batteries (KIBs) had not yet been understood. In this study, a novel K–Te battery has been developed, unveiling the K+ ion storage mechanism in Te as a two-electron conversion-type reaction: 2K + Te ↔ K2Te. This reaction yields a theoretical volumetric capacity of 2619 mAh cm−3. The carefully designed tellurium/porous carbon electrodes achieve an exceptionally high reversible volumetric capacity of 2493.13 mAh cm−3 at 0.5 C (based on Te), exhibit a high-rate capacity of 783.13 mAh cm−3 at 15 C, and demonstrate remarkable cycling stability over 1000 cycles at 5 C. This exceptional electrochemical performance highlights the potential of using Te as a high-volumetric-capacity material for K+ ion storage, paving the way for the practical implementation of KIBs.

High-tap-density silicon nanomaterials are considered highly beneficial as anodes for lithium-ion batteries due to their reduced surface area and minimal first-cycle loss. Nevertheless, these materials present significant challenges for the design of polymeric binders. Binders must attach to the limited surface area to accommodate extensive volume changes during cycling; additionally, the low porosities and small pore sizes associated with these materials hinder lithium-ion transport. This research presents a novel binder, poly(1-pyrenemethyl methacrylate-co-methacrylic acid) (PPyMAA), for use in high-tap-density nanosilicon electrodes, which cycles stably with a first cycle efficiency of 82%. This efficiency is further enhanced to 87% when combined with graphite material. Incorporating MAA acid functionalities does not alter the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) characteristics or diminish the adhesion performance of the PPy homopolymer. Our single-molecule force microscopy analysis of PPyMAA shows similar adhesion strength between the polymer binder and anode surface compared to conventional polymers such as homopolyacrylic acid (PAA), while also being electronically conductive. The combination of conductivity and adhesion provided by the MAA and pyrene copolymer supports excellent cycling performance for the high-tap-density Si electrode.

A simple method is presented for creating a layered SiCN-MoS_2 structure through the pyrolysis of polysilazane-functionalized MoS_2 flakes. This layered configuration and the transformation from polymer to ceramic on MoS_2 surfaces were verified using electron microscopy and spectroscopic techniques. When used as a thick film electrode in a Li-ion battery half-cell, SiCN-MoS_2 exhibited a typical three-stage reaction, with enhanced cycling stability and capacity retention compared to pure MoS_2. The overall capacity contribution from the conversion reaction of the Li/MoS_2 system was only slightly affected by SiCN, whereas the Li-irreversibility due to electrolyte decomposition was significantly reduced. This was identified as a key factor in the reduced first cycle loss and improved capacity retention. The SiCN-MoS_2, used as a self-supporting paper electrode (at 6 mg·cm^−2), performed even better, recovering an initial charge capacity of around 530 mAh·g^−1 when the current density was returned to 100 mA·g^−1 after cycling at a continuous 2400 mA·g^−1 (192 mAh·g^−1). The cycled MoS_2 electrode showed mud cracks and film delamination, whereas the SiCN-MoS_2 electrodes remained intact with a uniform solid electrolyte interphase coating. Overall, these findings indicate that interfacing at the molecular level with precursor-derived SiCN is an effective way to suppress the degradation reaction between metal-sulfide and electrolyte at low discharge potentials.

A key obstacle in developing novel battery materials is comprehending their fundamental mechanisms of operation and degradation. Due to their microscopically inhomogeneous nature, it is essential to use characterization tools that offer operando and localized information from individual grains and particles. This paper outlines a method for imaging the nanoscale distribution of ions during the electrochemical charging of a battery in a transmission electron microscope liquid flow cell. By implementing valence energy-loss spectroscopy, we track both solvated and intercalated ions, identifying the electronic structure fingerprints of solvated ions using ab initio nonlinear response theory. With the aid of a new electrochemical cell holder, nanoscale spectroscopy, and theory, we have successfully determined the lithiation state of a LiFePO4 electrode and the surrounding aqueous electrolyte in real time with nanoscale resolution during electrochemical charging and discharging. We monitor lithium transfer between the electrode and electrolyte and image the charging dynamics within the cathode. We detect competing delithiation mechanisms, such as core-shell and anisotropic growth, occurring simultaneously in different particles under identical conditions. This technique offers a universal approach for operando nanoscale imaging of electrochemically active ions in both the electrode and electrolyte across various electrical energy storage systems.

This paper summarizes the latest advancements in lithium-ion battery anode materials, highlighting their crucial role in defining the overall efficiency of these batteries. It investigates the variety of anode materials available, detailing the unique performance attributes of each in practical applications. The paper also reviews and evaluates significant research challenges and limitations encountered in their development. Finally, it suggests pathways for future research in anode materials, covering areas like new material types, structural innovations, and electrode reactions, with a focus on promising innovative strategies.

High entropy oxides have been studied as potential conversion-type negative electrodes for Li-ion batteries, yet the specific contributions of each element are not fully understood. This study examines each element's role during electrochemical cycling and associates it with the nanoscale structure. High entropy oxides (HEOs) with a chemically disordered multi-cation composition are gaining attention as negative electrode materials for batteries. Their exceptional electrochemical performance is linked to high-entropy stabilization and the 'cocktail effect'. However, the configurational entropy of HEOs, which is only metastable at room temperature, does not fully support structural reversibility in conversion-type reactions, and the ‘cocktail effect’ has not been clarified. This research reveals the atomic and nanoscale interactions of multi-cations in the HEO Mg_0.2Co_0.2Ni_0.2Cu_0.2Zn_0.2O during electrochemical reactions and explains the 'cocktail effect'. The more electronegative elements create an inert 3-dimensional metallic nano-network facilitating electron transport. Meanwhile, the electrochemically inactive cation stabilizes an oxide phase that is semi-coherent with the metallic phase and accommodates Li^+ ions. This self-assembled nanostructure allows stable cycling of micron-sized particles, eliminating the need for nanoscale pre-modification typical of conventional metal oxides in batteries. This study highlights that elemental diversity is crucial for optimizing multi-cation electrode materials.

Iron pyrite (FeS2) is considered an attractive cathode material for lithium-ion batteries due to its affordability and exceptionally high energy density (1671 Wh kg-1). Nonetheless, its reaction mechanisms remain a topic of debate. This study reveals that contrary to the traditional view of forming an intermediate phase Li2FeS2 and subsequently Fe/Li2S composites at the initial discharge, FeS2 experiences either a one-step reaction (FeS2 → Fe + Li2S) or a two-step reaction (FeS2 → FeS + Li2S→ Fe + Li2S), depending on the current rate and temperature. During charging, it undergoes a two-step process: a phase transition from Fe + Li2S to FeS at approximately 1.74 V, followed by the generation of elemental sulfur (Li2S → S) at 2.30 V. The FeS formed is a mackinawite phase, which emerges on the Li2S interface through hetero-epitaxial growth. In subsequent cycles, a combination reaction takes place between FeS and S. The reaction pathway indicates that FeS2 faces challenges characteristic of conversion reaction materials like FeS and S, including significant volume change, voltage hysteresis, and polysulfide dissolution. These insights could aid in comprehending the inherent capacity loss of FeS2 and offer guidance for enhancing its electrochemical performance.

Silicon is a highly promising candidate for lithium-ion battery anodes due to its high theoretical capacity, abundant availability, and well-established infrastructure. Recent advancements in Si nanostructure-based lithium-ion battery anodes, involving detailed structural designs and process developments, have been substantial. Nonetheless, creating cost-effective, scalable processes for producing these Si nanostructures remains a challenge, hindering broader applications. We present a method to produce Si nanoparticles with controlled sizes in large quantities from low-grade Si sources using a scalable high-energy mechanical milling process. Additionally, our study examines Si nanoparticles derived from two primary low-grade Si sources: metallurgical silicon (~99 wt % Si, $1/kg) and ferrosilicon (~83 wt % Si, $0.6/kg). We discovered that nanoparticles from ferrosilicon sources include FeSi2, which functions as a buffer layer to mitigate mechanical fractures caused by volume expansion. In contrast, nanoparticles from metallurgical Si sources exhibit higher capacity and superior kinetic properties due to their higher purity and improved electronic transport properties. Post carbon coating, ferrosilicon and metallurgical Si nanoparticles demonstrate over 100 cycles of stability, with reversible capacities of 1360 mAh g(-1) and 1205 mAh g(-1), respectively. Thus, our method offers a novel strategy for the cost-effective, energy-efficient, large-scale synthesis of functional Si electrode materials.

The authors demonstrate that, following cycling, the model cathode material Li_2Ru_0.5Mn_0.5O_3 experiences ruthenium segregation and even exsolution at the reconstructed oxide surface, initiating a gradual degradation process. These insights present new avenues for selecting dopants to stabilize the cathode surface. Although it is crucial to investigate the instability of delithiated cathode materials, it remains challenging to elucidate the degradation mechanism of lithium-rich cathode materials due to the complex interplay of chemical and structural changes. In this study, we employ advanced electron microscopy, alongside synchrotron X-ray techniques and first-principle calculations, to examine the 4d-element-containing compound Li_2Ru_0.5Mn_0.5O_3. Unexpectedly, we observe that after cycling, ruthenium forms metallic nanoclusters as it segregates out on the reconstructed surface. Our calculations indicate that this unexpected segregation of ruthenium metal results from its thermodynamic insolubility in the oxygen-deficient surface. This insolubility disrupts the reconstructed surface, accounting for the porous structure formation in this material. This research underscores the importance of examining the thermodynamic stability of the reconstructed film on cathode materials and provides theoretical direction for selecting elements to substitute manganese in both lithium-rich and stoichiometric layer-layer compounds to stabilize the cathode surface.

Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries, known for their theoretical capacity of 1675 mAh g-1, which is 5-10 times greater than current commercial lithium-ion batteries, face challenges with rapid capacity fading due to polysulfide dissolution in typical electrolytes. To address this, we introduce a composite material comprising amorphous MoS3 and reduced graphene oxide (r-GO) as an alternative to pure sulfur cathodes. To improve electrode kinetics and stability, we precisely pulverize microsized MoS3 sheets into nanosheets and create an ultrathin nano-SEI layer on their surface via in situ electrochemical techniques. These nanosheets are then firmly anchored by the oxygen functional groups of r-GO. This electrochemically modified MoS3/r-GO electrode demonstrates superior performance over pure sulfur-based electrodes, achieving a capacity of approximately 900 mAh g-1 at a 5C rate for 2500 cycles without capacity degradation. Additionally, a full-cell battery with this MoS3/r-GO cathode paired with a silicon-carbon composite anode achieves a 3-5 fold increase in energy density (1725 Wh kg-1/7100 Wh L-1) compared to current lithium-ion batteries.

The recovery of cobalt and lithium metals from used lithium-ion batteries is crucial to prevent environmental pollution and ease resource scarcity. This study presents a hydrometallurgical method to recover lithium fluoride. Initially, lithium and cobalt are selectively leached into a solution using formic acid and hydrogen peroxide. By examining variables such as leaching temperature, time, stoichiometric ratio, H2O2 concentration, and solid-to-liquid ratio, the leaching efficiencies for Li and Co were determined to be 99.90% and 99.96%, respectively. Additionally, assessments of leaching kinetics and apparent activation energy calculations demonstrated that the leaching process aligns well with chemical control. Following fractional precipitation, lithium fluoride with a purity of 99.0% was achieved, effectively recovering materials from spent lithium-ion batteries.

Porous silicon nanowires have been extensively examined for various uses, yet their application in energy storage has been scarcely reported. In this study, we present both experimental and theoretical investigations of porous doped silicon nanowires created via direct etching of boron-doped silicon wafers. Utilizing alginate as a binder, these porous silicon nanowires demonstrated exceptional electrochemical performance and extended cycle life as anode material for lithium-ion batteries. Remarkably, the capacity remained stable above 2000, 1600, and 1100 mAh/g even after 250 cycles at current rates of 2, 4, and 18 A/g, respectively. This underscores the structural stability offered by the high porosity and electron conductivity of these porous silicon nanowires. To analyze the impact of porosity and pore size on structural stability, a mathematical model combining lithium-ion diffusion and strain from lithium intercalation was employed. Simulations indicate that silicon with high porosity and large pore sizes contributes to maintaining structural integrity throughout charge/discharge cycles.

Precise control over the morphology of nanostructured silicon is essential for enhancing the structural stability and electrochemical performance of lithium-ion batteries. Utilizing removable or sacrificial templates provides an efficient and straightforward method for synthesizing hollow materials. In this work, we present the formation of mesoporous silicon hollow nanocubes (m-Si HCs) based on a metal-organic framework (MOF) that serve as an anode material, exhibiting exceptional electrochemical properties. The design of the m-Si HC features a mesoporous shell approximately 15 nm thick and an internal void around 60 nm, enabling effective accommodation of volume changes and alleviating stress/strain caused by diffusion during repeated cycling. This cubic structure also ensures a significant electrolyte contact area owing to the exposed active sites, promoting efficient Li ion transport. With carbon coating, the m-Si HC achieves a high reversible capacity of 1728 mAh g-1, an initial Coulombic efficiency of 80.1% after the first cycle, and an impressive rate capability of over 1050 mAh g-1 at a 15 C-rate. Notably, the m-Si HC anode significantly reduces electrode swelling to approximately 47% after 100 cycles and demonstrates excellent cycle stability, maintaining 850 mAh g-1 after 800 cycles at a 1 C-rate. Furthermore, a complete cell featuring an m-Si HC-graphite anode paired with a LiCoO2 cathode achieves remarkable cycle retention of 72% over 100 cycles at a 0.2 C-rate.

Silicon's (Si) ability to store lithium can be improved by alloying it with germanium (Ge) due to Ge's excellent electronic and ionic conductivity. In this study, we created a three-dimensional nanoporous (3D-NP) SiGe alloy to serve as a high-performance anode for lithium-ion batteries (LIB) through a dealloying process, utilizing a ternary AlSiGe ribbon as the precursor material. By modifying the sacrificial aluminum content in the precursor, we can precisely control the morphology and porosity of the resulting SiGe alloy. When the aluminum content is set at 80%, the 3D-NP SiGe alloy exhibits a uniform coral-like structure featuring continuous ligaments and a network of hierarchical micropores and mesopores. This structure results in a high reversible capacity of 1158 mA h g-1 after 150 cycles at a current density of 1000 mA g-1, along with excellent rate capacity. This approach may offer insights for optimizing nanostructures and the large-scale production of energy storage materials.

Free-standing electrode (FSE) structures can significantly boost the gravimetric and volumetric energy density of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) by removing the unnecessary weight and space of conventional metal foil current collectors. However, existing FSE fabrication techniques often lack mechanical stability, electrochemical performance, or suitability for industrial use. Here, we present a scalable camphene-assisted method that enables the casting and templating of FSEs consisting of standard LIB materials, delivering higher performance than traditional foil-cast electrodes. These porous, lightweight, and sturdy electrodes enhance rate performance by facilitating mass and ion transport within the conductive carbon pore network while eliminating current collectors for effective and stable Li+ storage, maintaining performance over 1000 cycles in half-cells, with increased gravimetric and areal energy densities. Relative to standard foil-cast electrodes, those derived from camphene show about 1.5 times improved gravimetric energy density, better rate capability, and improved capacity retention in coin-cell setups. A full cell featuring both free-standing anode and cathode sustained over 250 cycles, retaining over 80% of its capacity at 0.73 mA h/cm² areal capacity. This method, adaptable to various active materials, offers the ability to design flexible, current-collector-free electrodes, allowing optimization of LIBs for either high power or high energy density Li+ storage. Moreover, this platform provides an adaptable electrode fabrication approach applicable to other electrochemical technologies and advanced manufacturing processes.

Nickel-rich cathode materials commonly experience reaction heterogeneity during electrochemical cycling, especially at elevated temperatures, due to their polycrystalline nature and secondary particle morphology. Despite extensive research on the morphological changes in polycrystalline nickel-rich materials, their practical implications at the electrode and cell levels are infrequently examined. This study reveals an intrinsic limitation of polycrystalline nickel-rich cathodes in high-energy full cells under industrial electrode fabrication conditions. Their highly unstable chemo-mechanical properties lead to degradation in the longitudinal direction of the high-energy electrode even after the initial cycle. This inhomogeneous degradation arises from the excessive use of active materials on the surface, resulting in a severe non-uniform potential distribution over extended cycling periods. This issue further decreases lithium ion reversibility. Therefore, the study proposes using robust single-crystalline LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 as a viable replacement to effectively prevent localized overutilization of active materials. This approach can stabilize the electrochemical performance of high-energy lithium-ion cells, achieving superior capacity retention of over 80% after 1000 cycles at 45°C.

The low performance of cathode materials is a significant barrier to the use of lithium-ion batteries (LIB) in advanced portable electronics and electric vehicles. This study introduces a versatile oxygen-deficient LiV3O8 (D-LVO) nanosheet, synthesized via a straightforward oxygen-deficient hydrothermal process followed by annealing in argon. As a cathode in LIBs, the D-LVO nanosheets demonstrate impressive capacity across varying current densities, achieving 335, 317, 278, 246, 209, 167, and 133 mA h g-1 at 50, 100, 200, 500, 1000, 2000, and 4000 mA g-1, respectively. They also maintain more than 88% of their initial reversible capacity after 200 cycles at 1000 mA g-1, indicating excellent lithium-ion storage stability. The enhanced electrochemical characteristics are attributed to the presence of tetravalent vanadium (∼15% V4+) and oxygen vacancies in the LiV3O8 nanosheets. This modification results in electrical conductivity that is over 10 times higher and a lithium-ion diffusion coefficient nearly 100 times higher than that of LiV3O8 without V4+ (N-LVO), facilitating easy lithium-ion diffusion, rapid phase transition, and outstanding electrochemical reversibility. Additionally, the more uniform nanostructure and larger specific surface area of D-LVO, compared to N-LVO nanosheets, may enhance electrolyte penetration and offer more reaction sites, promoting swift lithium-ion diffusion during discharge and charge cycles.

Lithium transition-metal oxides, such as LiMn2O4 and LiMO2 (where M represents elements like Ni, Mn, Co, etc.), are extensively used as cathode materials in lithium-ion batteries due to their significant capacity and energy density. Nonetheless, various interactions at the cathode/electrolyte interface contribute to a decline in overall performance. A primary failure mechanism is the dissolution of transition metals from the cathode. In this study, we combine scanning electrochemical microscopy with inductively coupled plasma (ICP) and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopies to investigate cathode degradation products. Using a LiMn2O4 (LMO) thin film as a model cathode, we monitor the Mn dissolution process, avoiding complications from conductive additives and polymer binders. We analyze the electrochemical behavior of LMO degradation products in different electrolytes, using ICP and EPR to gain insights into the properties of Mn complexes formed after metal dissolution. Our findings indicate that the type of lithium salt anion in the electrolyte systems [ClO4–, PF6–, and (CF3SO2)2N–] significantly influences both the Mn dissolution process and the electrochemical behavior of the resulting Mn complexes. This suggests the Mn dissolution mechanism is at least partially influenced by the lithium salt anion.

Hierarchical porous NiMn2O4/C tremella-like nanostructures are synthesized using a straightforward solvothermal and calcination process. These nanostructures, when used as the anode in lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), demonstrate an outstanding specific capacity and remarkable long-term cycling stability, even at elevated current densities. The discharge capacity stabilizes at 2130 mA h g(-1) over 350 cycles at a current density of 1000 mA g(-1). After an extensive cycling period of 1500 cycles, the capacity remains as high as 1773 mA h g(-1) at a high current density of 4000 mA g(-1), nearly five times the theoretical capacity of graphite. The porous NiMn2O4/C hierarchical nanostructure ensures substantial contact with the electrolyte and offers rapid three-dimensional Li(+) diffusion channels, significantly enhancing the capacity of NiMn2O4/C through interfacial storage.

Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are extensively utilized for energy storage in numerous applications, including electric vehicles. Despite their widespread use, LIBs encounter challenges such as energy density, durability, charging speed, and safety concerns. Nanomaterials, characterized by having at least one dimension on the nanoscale, offer potential solutions by enhancing the properties and performance of electrode materials. This study examines recent developments and obstacles in utilizing nanomaterials as electrode materials for LIBs. It discusses the pros and cons of various nanomaterials, including nanoparticles, nanocoatings, nanotubes, and nanocomposites, and their impact on the electrochemical behavior of LIBs. Additionally, it outlines key issues and future directions for the advancement of nanomaterials-based LIBs. This research seeks to provide a thorough overview and insights into the application of nanomaterials for improving LIB performance.

Currently, there are no established guidelines for creating solid electrolytes with lithium-ion conductivity sufficient to replace liquid electrolytes and push the boundaries of performance and design of current lithium-ion batteries. Utilizing the characteristics of high-entropy materials, we have engineered a solid electrolyte with high ion conductivity by increasing the compositional complexity of an existing lithium superionic conductor, effectively removing ion migration barriers while preserving its superionic conduction framework. The newly synthesized phase, characterized by its compositional complexity, demonstrated enhanced ion conductivity. We demonstrated that this highly conductive solid electrolyte allows for charging and discharging of a thick lithium-ion battery cathode at room temperature, thereby offering the potential to alter traditional battery configurations. Summary Solid electrolytes have been engineered to make solid-state batteries a viable competitor to those with liquid electrolytes; however, maintaining good contact with electrodes remains a challenge, limiting practical electrode thickness. Li et al. employed high-entropy material principles to enhance existing electrolytes by carefully substituting additional elements. Their study shows the integration of these materials into a cathode structure, achieving the high ionic conductivity essential for solid-state battery use. —MSL Adding compositional complexity to a known crystal framework facilitates the development of millimeter-thick battery electrodes.

Recently, "fast-charging" lithium-ion batteries have garnered significant interest due to their potential applications in energy storage sectors such as electric vehicles, power grids, and underwater operations. However, the remarkable energy density of these batteries may not be maintained efficiently under fast-charging conditions. The key determinant of electrode performance is the crystal structure of electrode materials. Therefore, utilizing anode materials with a low diffusion barrier can enhance the "fast-charging" capabilities of lithium-ion batteries. This review begins by outlining the "fast-charging" mechanism of lithium-ion batteries and the ion diffusion paths within the crystal structure. It then evaluates the potential uses of "fast-charging" anode materials with different crystal structures to identify materials that are stable, safe, and durable, addressing the challenges related to high power and safety. The review also summarizes recent advancements in typical "fast-charging" anode materials, including new preparation methods for advanced morphologies and cutting-edge techniques aimed at improving performance. Moreover, it provides an outlook on the latest developments in "fast-charging" anode materials for lithium-ion batteries. Intercalation materials such as niobium-based, carbon-based, titanium-based, and vanadium-based compounds, although possessing good cycling stability, often face limitations due to poor electronic conductivity and theoretical specific capacity. Enhancing the electrical conductivity of these materials is essential for achieving fast charging. Conversely, conversion-type transition metal oxide and phosphorus-based materials, which have high theoretical specific capacities, frequently experience substantial volume changes during charge and discharge cycles. Mitigating this volume expansion can significantly advance the application of these materials in fast-charging batteries.

Composite electrodes, which comprise active materials, carbon, and binder, are commonly utilized in lithium-ion batteries. Due to the electrode reaction occurring preferentially in areas of lower resistance, there can be a variation in reaction distribution within composite electrodes. We examine the connection between reaction distribution along the depth and the electronic/ionic conductivity in these electrodes as their porosities change. Utilizing two-dimensional X-ray absorption spectroscopy, we found that reaction distribution occurs in electrodes with lower porosity. Our newly developed 6-probe method allows measurement of electronic/ionic conductivity within composite electrodes. We observed that ionic conductivity decreases in lower porosity electrodes, influencing both the reaction distribution in composite electrodes and their performance.

Silicon anodes, known for their high specific capacity, have attracted global interest as potential candidates for the anodes in next-generation lithium-ion batteries (LIBs). However, challenges arise for silicon anodes to replace graphite anodes broadly due to unavoidable volume expansion and the formation of SEI films during the lithiation/delithiation cycles. Notably, advancements in nanotechnology have accelerated the development of silicon anodes. This paper reviews the application of nanotechnology in Si anodes to enhance battery performance. To mitigate Si's volume expansion, the size of the silicon anode is diminished to increase its specific surface area. Moreover, reducing the negative electrode size shortens the lithium ion travel distance, significantly boosting the efficiency of the silicon negative electrode. Currently, the primary silicon nano-anode materials include nanoparticles, nanowires, nanosheets, nanotubes, and nanoporous materials. This review aims to provide an insightful overview of the nano-silicon anode landscape. It covers pure silicon nanoparticles and silicon nanowires, as well as innovative nanomaterials formed with graphite, graphene, metals, and other elements.

Hydrogen boride (HB), which has a pseudo-two-dimensional sheet structure, was recently synthesized and is theoretically anticipated to show significant potential as a negative electrode material for alkali metal ion batteries, positioning it as an exciting new candidate. This paper presents the pioneering experimental assessment of HB's negative electrode properties. HB was synthesized through cation exchange from MgB2. Spectroscopic methods, including synchrotron radiation X-ray diffraction and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, as well as direct transmission electron microscopy, were used to confirm the synthesis of HB. The HB electrode was created by mixing the synthesized HB powder with conductive additive carbon black and a polymer binder. A test cell was assembled employing this HB electrode as the working electrode, coupled with lithium metal used as the counter and reference electrodes, to evaluate its performance as a battery electrode. While the charge-discharge curves exhibited good reversibility, the reversible capacity was measured at 100 ± 20 mA h g-1, which is notably less than the theoretical predictions. Nitrogen gas adsorption tests on the HB powder revealed the specific surface area, indicating that the HB sheets were stacked together. This stacking structure is likely responsible for the decreased lithium-ion storage capacity compared to theoretical expectations.

Co3O4 is being recognized as a potential anode material for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) because of its high theoretical capacity of 890 mAh g-1. However, its practical application is hindered by poor electrochemical cycling stability, which is caused by its low intrinsic electronic conductivity and significant volume changes during cycling. To address this, a novel electrophoretic deposition method was used to create a Co3O4/graphene (EPD Co3O4/G) hybrid electrode aimed at enhancing electrochemical performance. The EPD technique allows Co3O4 nanocubes to be uniformly integrated between graphene layers, forming a sandwich-like architecture. This structure benefits from the flexibility of graphene and the numerous voids it contains, which help maintain structural integrity and an efficient conductive network during cycling. Furthermore, the electrode demonstrates fast surface-controlled lithium storage kinetics. Consequently, the Co3O4/G hybrid electrode shows high specific capacity and superior electrochemical cycling stability. In situ electrochemical XRD studies further examined the structure-performance relationship of the electrode, revealing: (1) the presence of LixCo3O4, indicating minimal volume change during the initial discharge; (2) evidence supporting Co3O4’s theoretical capacity within the hybrid electrode; and (3) a detailed analysis of the connection between electrochemical performance and the structural changes of the Co3O4/G hybrid electrode.

Red phosphorus (RP) boasts a high theoretical capacity, making it an attractive anode material for lithium-ion batteries. Nevertheless, RP's substantial volume change during charge and discharge cycles negatively impacts cyclability and its rate performance is hindered by low conductivity. In this study, a straightforward solution-based approach is employed to integrate phosphorus into the pores of carbon hosts derived from zeolitic imidazole framework (ZIF-8) at moderate temperatures. This technique transforms blocky RP into polyphosphides anions (PP, mainly P5-) which can readily infiltrate the pores of the porous carbon hosts. Importantly, this prevents the formation of crystalline surface phosphorus, which is typically produced using the conventional vapor-condensation encapsulation method. Additionally, the highly conductive ZIF-8 derived carbon hosts with pores smaller than 3 nm are effective for loading PP and can effectively mitigate volume changes. As a result, the composite of phosphorus housed within the ZIF-8 derived porous carbon demonstrates significantly enhanced electrochemical performance as a lithium-ion battery anode, exhibiting a high capacity of 786 mAh g⁻¹ after 100 cycles at 0.1 A g⁻¹, strong stability over 700 cycles at 1 A g⁻¹, and excellent rate performance.

Layered lithium-rich cathode materials have garnered significant attention due to their high theoretical specific capacity of 320 - 350 mA h g⁻¹. Nonetheless, their practical use is limited by poor cycling stability and slow reaction kinetics. Following a period of dormancy, there is renewed interest in advancing layered lithium-rich cathode materials to address the growing demand for high-energy-density lithium-ion batteries. This paper reviews recent advancements and comprehensive insights into the structural characterization and reaction mechanisms of layered lithium-rich manganese-based cathode materials. Specifically, we thoroughly summarize the proposed reaction mechanisms involving both the cationic redox reactions of transition-metal ions and the anionic redox reactions of oxygen species. Finally, we explore the opportunities and challenges that lie ahead for the development of LLRM cathode materials in the context of next-generation lithium-ion batteries.

Rapid recharging of lithium-ion batteries is crucial for reducing electric vehicle charging times, yet the limited rate capability of graphite anodes poses a challenge. In this study, we introduce an innovative dual-gradient structure design characterized by variations in particle size and electrode porosity within the graphite anode, enabling extremely fast charging under strict electrode conditions. We create this novel dual-gradient structure using a polymer binder–free slurry method, achieving a practical graphite anode capable of reaching 60% recharge in just 10 minutes. Utilizing this dual-gradient graphite anode, we showcase an extremely fast-charging lithium-ion battery that achieves 60% recharge in 6 minutes, alongside a high volumetric energy density of 701 Wh per liter at a charging rate of 6 C.

Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), prevalent in daily life, are facing increasing demand for their raw materials. To support a circular economy and provide resources for new LIBs or other products, recycling of spent LIBs is essential. Current research focuses on recycling the active electrode materials. Existing recycling methods, such as pyro- and hydrometallurgy or flotation, have limitations like material loss, waste production, or poor selectivity. In this study, we investigate the behavior of commercially available LiFePO4 and two types of graphite microparticles in a dielectrophoretic high-throughput filter. Dielectrophoresis, a volume-dependent electrokinetic force often used in microfluidics, is being explored for applications requiring enhanced throughput. Our findings show that graphite particles exhibit substantially higher trapping efficiency compared to LiFePO4. The study reveals that nearly pure LiFePO4 fractions can be isolated from a mixture with graphite using this approach.

All-solid-state batteries (ASSBs) hold significant promise due to their potential to deliver high power and energy densities while enhancing safety features. Even though new solid electrolytes (SEs) offering sufficiently high ionic conductivities have been developed, reports on solid-state batteries with extended operational lifetimes remain scarce. Thus, understanding the intricate degradation processes at the electrode/electrolyte interfaces is crucial for advancing high-performance, long-lasting ASSBs. Although the lithium metal/solid electrolyte interface garners significant attention in the pursuit of greater energy density, addressing and studying the interface between active material and solid electrolyte particles in the composite cathode is arguably more challenging. In this study, various characterization techniques are employed to elucidate the processes occurring at the LiCoO2 cathode and Li10GeP2S12 solid electrolyte interface. Anode materials such as Indium and Li4Ti5O12 are chosen to mitigate the instability issues often linked to Li-metal anodes. Observations of capacity fading and increased impedances are made during prolonged cycling. Postmortem analyses utilizing scanning transmission electron microscopy, electron energy loss spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy reveal that electrochemically induced mechanical failure and degradation at the cathode/solid electrolyte interface contribute to heightened internal resistance and capacity fading. These findings imply that creating electrochemically stable SEs and engineering the cathode/SE interfaces are essential to ensuring reliable SSB performance.

A composite of hierarchical copper silicate hydrate hollow spheres and reduced graphene oxide (RGO) has been successfully synthesized through a straightforward hydrothermal method, using silica as an in situ sacrificing template. This study marks the first investigation of the composite's electrochemical performance as an anode for lithium-ion batteries. The composite benefits from the combined effects of its hierarchical hollow structure and the conductive RGO matrix, showing remarkable long-term performance and rate capability. It delivers a capacity of 890 mAh/g following 200 cycles at 200 mA/g and maintains a capacity of 429 mAh/g after 800 cycles at 1000 mA/g. These findings suggest that the integration of hierarchical hollow structures with conductive RGO could effectively address the volume expansion issue in high-capacity anode materials.

Recent investigations into lithium-ion battery (LIB) cathode materials utilize a variety of experimental and theoretical methods to comprehend the alterations in their bulk and local chemical and electronic structures during electrochemical cycling (charging and discharging). Although rich in valuable chemical insights, 17O NMR spectroscopy has been seldom applied in such studies. Many LIB cathode materials feature paramagnetic ions, leading to NMR spectra dominated by hyperfine and quadrupolar interactions, which result in broad resonances with complex spinning sideband arrangements. Careful interpretation of these spectra can theoretically disclose details about local structural distortions, magnetic exchange interactions, structural inhomogeneities (like Li+ concentration gradients), and even the presence of redox-active oxygen anions. In this Perspective, we explore the key interactions that affect 17O NMR spectroscopy in LIB cathodes and propose how 17O NMR can be leveraged to uncover the structure of both pristine cathodes and their structural changes during cycling, highlighting the difficulties in acquiring and interpreting the spectra. We further delve into the application of 17O NMR regarding anionic redox and its potential in elucidating charge compensation mechanisms in high-capacity cathodes, offering guidance for the implementation of 17O NMR in future research directions.

This article presents the process of atomic layer deposition (ALD) of tungsten nitride using tungsten hexacarbonyl [W(CO)6] and ammonia [NH3], applied as an anode in lithium-ion batteries. Techniques such as in situ quartz crystal microbalance (QCM), ellipsometry, and X-ray reflectivity (XRR) are utilized to verify the self-limiting deposition behavior. A saturated growth rate of approximately 0.35 Å per ALD cycle is observed within a temperature range of 180-195 °C. In situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy is employed to examine the reaction pathways of surface adsorbed species after each ALD half cycle. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is used to determine the elemental presence and chemical composition. Initially, the deposited material is amorphous but crystallizes into h-W2N when annealed at high temperatures under an ammonia atmosphere. These as-deposited materials exhibit n-type conductivity with an average carrier concentration of roughly 10(20) at room temperature. Electrochemical analyses of the films suggest potential for these materials as anode materials in Li-ion batteries. The inclusion of multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) as a supporting layer further boosts the electrochemical storage capability of the ALD-grown tungsten nitride (WNx). Ex situ X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis verifies the conversion-based reaction mechanism of the grown material with lithium during operation.

The dissolution of transition metal (TM) cations, such as the release of Mn ions from LiMn2O4 (LMO) into liquid electrolytes, negatively affects the cycling performance of Li-ion batteries (LIBs). Although this issue has received considerable attention, the specifics of Mn dissolution remain unclear. In this study, we employed a refined in-situ UV-visible absorption spectroscopy (UV-vis) technique to observe the fluctuations in dissolved Mn ion concentrations in the liquid electrolyte from LMO at different states of charge (SOC). We identified the peak dissolution concentration and rate at a charged state of 4.3 V and found Mn2+ to be the predominant species in the electrolyte. Using ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations, we demonstrated that the Mn dissolution process is closely linked to the evolution of surface structure, solvent decomposition, and lithium salt interactions. These findings will enhance the comprehension of TM dissolution mechanisms under operational conditions and aid in the development of stable cathodes.

The global energy crisis, the consumption of fossil fuels, and the resulting environmental challenges have spurred significant interest in developing sustainable energy storage and conversion systems. Rechargeable lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are widely implemented in mobile devices, as well as in hybrid and electric vehicles. The electrode-electrolyte interface significantly impacts battery capacity reduction and long-term cycling stability. To enhance the fundamental understanding of the relevant phenomena and accelerate the rational design of cathode materials and stable interfaces, Li(Ni,Co,Mn)O2 (NCM) is explored as a cathode material for rechargeable LIBs and as a promising electrocatalyst for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Their performance and catalytic activity are closely tied to their structures. Various processes at the cathode/electrolyte interface result in overall performance degradation. One failure mechanism includes the dissolution of transition metals from the cathode. Our research uses thin films as a model cathode to observe Mn dissolution. By employing LiMn2O4 and NCM as cathode materials, we aim to focus on electrochemical characterization, cation mixing, oxygen evolution, and thin film deposition with controlled crystal structures and composition. Additionally, we will present our work using the scanning electrochemical microscope to study LIB degradation and cathode-electrolyte interface both in situ and in real-time.

This study presents an advanced long-lasting lithium-ion battery, featuring a Pyr14 TFSI-LiTFSI non-flammable ionic liquid (IL) electrolyte, a nanostructured tin carbon (Sn-C) nanocomposite anode, and a layered LiNi1/3 Co1/3 Mn1/3 O2 (NMC) cathode. The IL-based electrolyte is evaluated for conductivity and viscosity across various temperatures, showing a Vogel-Tammann-Fulcher (VTF) pattern. Lithium half-cells incorporating the Sn-C anode and NMC cathode within the Pyr14 TFSI-LiTFSI electrolyte are examined via galvanostatic cycling under different temperatures, confirming the electrolyte's full compatibility with the chosen electrodes. The NMC and Sn-C electrodes are paired in a cathode-limited full cell and subjected to extended cycling at 40 °C, displaying a stable capacity of approximately 140 mAh g(-1) and retention above 99% over 400 cycles. Analysis of the electrode/electrolyte interface is conducted using electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) after cycling. The outstanding performance results here solidly establish that IL-based lithium-ion cells are suitable for use in electric vehicles.

The performance of lithium-ion batteries at below-freezing temperatures is significantly hampered by resistive interphases formed due to electrolyte decomposition, particularly on the anode surface. This study introduces a new method for creating an anode interphase with low impedance by using the electrolyte additive dimethyl sulfite (DMS). Electrochemical tests reveal that this newly constructed interphase enhances the low-temperature performance of graphite/LiNi0.5Co0.2Mn0.3O2 pouch cells, surpassing the performance of interphases formed with 1,3,2-Dioxathiolane 2,2-dioxide (DTD), a commonly used commercial electrolyte additive. Spectroscopic analyses combined with theoretical calculations show that the superior performance is due to DMS's unique molecular structure, which provides suitable reduction activity and forms a more stable and ionically conductive anode interphase. This is because the reduction product of DMS combines less strongly with lithium ions compared to DTD.
