The strategic design of interphases through additive structure has demonstrated to be an effective and cost-efficient method for optimizing the performance of lithium-ion batteries.

A Si nanoparticles@TiO2-x/C mesoporous microfiber composite with a core-shell structure has been created using the electrospinning technique. This core-shell composite demonstrates high reversible capacity, excellent rate capability, and enhanced cycling performance as an anode material for Li-ion batteries. Additionally, it effectively suppresses exothermic behavior, which may help prevent potential thermal runaway and related safety issues in the cells. These enhanced electrochemical and thermal properties are attributed to the mechanically, electrically, and thermally sturdy shell structure of the TiO2-x/C nanocomposite that encapsulates the Si nanoparticles, suggesting it as a promising architecture for a safe and reliable Si-based Li-ion battery with high energy density.

During solid-state calcination, as the temperature rises, materials experience intricate phase transitions accompanied by heterogeneous solid-state reactions and mass transport. Hence, precise management of calcination chemistry is essential in creating advanced Ni-rich layered oxides (LiNi1-x-yCoxMnyO2, NRNCM) which serve as cathode materials for lithium-ion batteries. Even though battery performance is influenced by the chemical heterogeneity occurring during NRNCM calcination, this aspect has not yet been fully understood. In this study, using techniques such as synchrotron-based X-ray, mass spectrometry microscopy, and structural analyses, it is demonstrated that the reaction kinetics, which are dependent on temperature, the diffusivity of solid-state lithium sources, and the surrounding oxygen influence the local chemical compositions of reaction intermediates within a calcined particle. Furthermore, it is discovered that differences in the reducing power of the transition metals (namely Ni, Co, and Mn) dictate the local structures at the nanoscale. This examination of the reaction mechanism through imaging analysis offers crucial insights for optimizing calcination chemistry and advancing high-energy/power density lithium-ion batteries.

The lithium-ion battery (LIB) revolutionized portable energy storage, but growing societal needs have spurred the development of a more advanced generation of LIBs. While research into battery active materials has been extensive since the 1980s, the most significant improvements in commercial LIBs over the last decade have resulted from innovations in overall cell design and engineering. Aiming for higher energy density and fast-charging capabilities, recent strategies have concentrated on modifying the properties of composite electrode architectures—such as porosity, conductivity, tortuosity, and spatial heterogeneity—by restructuring the inactive component matrix of LIB electrode films. This perspective examines the latest advances in electrode design with a practical approach, highlighting synthetic platforms and future research directions that are scalable, commercially viable, and applicable across a variety of active materials. It introduces and critically evaluates recent strategies for structuring electrode architectures, including spatial gradients of local composition and microstructure, alternatives to metal-foil current collectors, and electrode templating techniques, assessing their successes in battery performance and commercial potential. When combined with enhanced active materials, these new electrode architectures are poised to enable the next generation of LIBs.

Organic anion-hosting cathodes are highly promising candidates for lithium-ion-based dual-ion batteries (LDIBs) due to their diverse, designable, and adjustable nature. In this study, an innovative organic anion-hosting mixed-valence metal-organic framework cathode (CoⅡ2CoⅢ(DFc)2(OH)3·H2O, abbreviated as Co(DFc)x) is introduced for use in LDIBs. Redox reactions involving Fe2+/Fe3+ and Co2+/Co3+ enable PF6- anions to enter and be reversibly released from the cathode into the LiPF6-based electrolyte. Thanks to its distinctive structure and insolubility, Co(DFc)x achieves a high energy density of 632 Wh kg-1 (against a lithium anode), operates at a high potential of 3.63 V (vs. Li+/Li), and delivers a high reversible (discharge) capacity of 170 mAh g-1 at 50 mA g-1 (by the 3rd cycle). It also exhibits excellent rate performance (up to 2000 mA g-1, completing a cycle in 5 minutes) and remarkable cycling stability (sustaining an average capacity of 74.9 mAh g-1 over 8000 cycles at 2000 mA g-1).

Graphene, consisting of a single atomic layer of carbon, exhibits outstanding mechanical, electrical, and optical properties, making it a candidate for broad applications across physics, chemistry, information technology, energy, and device manufacturing. This paper provides a concise review of the concept, structure, properties, preparation methods of graphene, and its role in lithium-ion batteries. The formation of a continuous 3D conductive network by graphene significantly enhances the electron and ion transportation in electrode materials, thus greatly improving lithium-ion battery performance by offering superior chemical stability, higher electrical conductivity, and increased capacity. This review also summarizes recent developments in graphene-containing materials used for lithium-ion batteries and discusses future prospects.

Volume expansion poses a significant issue for tin oxide (SnO x), leading to poor cycle performance in lithium-ion battery anodes. To address this, bare tin dioxide (SnO2), tin dioxide combined with graphene sheets (SnO2@GS), and a bouquet-like nanocomposite structure (Mn2SnO4@GS) were synthesized via a hydrothermal method followed by annealing. The resulting composite exhibits a bouquet configuration composed of a network of manganese and tin oxide nanoparticles integrated with graphene sheets. This porous nanostructure benefits from the graphene sheets, which enhance electronic pathways and thus increase conductivity. Additionally, the evenly distributed particles facilitate faster lithium ion kinetics and minimize volume changes in the tin dioxide (SnO2) particles during charge-discharge cycles. As a result, the ternary composite Mn2SnO4@GS exhibited excellent rate performance and cyclability as an anode material for lithium-ion batteries. The electrode maintained a specific capacity of approximately 1070 mA h g-1 at a current density of 400 mA g-1 after 200 cycles and sustained a specific capacity of about 455 mA h g-1 even at a high current density of 2500 mA g-1. This ternary Mn2SnO4@GS material could advance the development of distinct structural and conductive networks for lithium-ion batteries.
